2447218.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Elise. Hello, everyone, and welcome to Red Hat's Earnings Call for the Second Quarter Fiscal 2015. Speakers for today's call will be Jim Whitehurst, President and CEO; and Charlie Peters, Executive Vice President and CFO.
Our earnings press release was issued after the market closed today and may be downloaded from redhat.com on the Investor Relations page. Also on this page, you will be able to find a historic reconciliation schedule of GAAP to non-GAAP financial metrics as well as the schedule on currency rates.
Various marks that we -- remarks that we may make about the company's future expectations, plans and prospects, including statements containing the words believe, anticipate, plan, project, estimate, expect, intend or will, constitute forward-looking statements for the purposes of the Safe Harbor provisions under the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially from those indicated by these forward-looking statements as a result of various important factors, including those discussed in the company's most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC as well as the Safe Harbor statement in today's press release.
In addition, any forward-looking statements represent our estimates or views only as of today, September 18, 2014, and these estimates or views may change. While the company may elect to update forward-looking statements at some point in the future, we specifically disclaim any obligation to do so even if our estimates or views do change. And therefore, you should not rely on these forward-looking statements as representing our estimates or views as of any date subsequent to today.
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Jim.

---

Thank you, Tom, and let me add my welcome to all of you joining us on today's call.
We delivered a strong second quarter as we continue to benefit from our position as a leading software provider enabling the new era of computing. We continue to drive our vision of the open hybrid cloud, and when combined with strong execution in sales, enabled us to exceed our guidance for the second quarter.
Some of the highlights of the second quarter include our fastest subscription revenue growth in 7 quarters, the 10th straight quarter of mid to high teens growth in total revenue and outperformance of the revenue line driven by strong sales execution and focused investment led to non-GAAP operating margins that were 140 basis points higher than our guidance.
We've had a busy summer as we continue to collaborate with our customers and partners to deliver innovative technologies to the enterprise. One of our top goals with customers is to enable their journey to the open hybrid cloud. We accomplished this through a broad portfolio of technologies, professional services and award-winning customer service. The journey to running applications anywhere any time starts with the core foundation of RHEL and JBoss middleware. As Charlie will discuss in a moment, we saw solid growth in these core technologies.
In addition, we continue to see traction in our emerging technologies. For example, customers in our early adopter program, which covers all our major verticals, are already using new functionality of Linux Containers, Active Directory and built-in performance profiles in RHEL 7.
Let me now discuss some of our recent technology releases that added new capabilities and functionality to our open hybrid cloud vision. Let me start with RHEL OpenStack Platform 5.0. This is our third enterprise version of OpenStack technology. RHEL OSP 5.0 technology is based on the OpenStack Icehouse release and is tightly integrated with RHEL to provide enhanced performance, reliability and a large certified ecosystem for applications deployed on OpenStack cloud. 
This version also includes several new features aimed at easing enterprise adoption of OpenStack in the existing data center and enhancing capabilities to make it the most reliable and dependable cloud platform. These features include, first, a new 3-year support life cycle provided by Red Hat's global support services team and the world's largest certified OpenStack partner ecosystem; second, support for integrations with VMware infrastructure, encompassing virtualization, management, networking and storage; third, enhanced security for virtual machines, which will now support new cryptographic security requirements for the United States and the United Kingdom; and fourth, improved interoperability of networking stacks. The new architecture provides a path for customers with heterogeneous networking environment who want to use a mix of networking solutions in their OpenStack environment.
Along with RHEL OSP 5.0, we launched an open virtual appliance for RHEL OSP, which eases the installation process and provides organizations considering OpenStack the ability to experience its power firsthand.  
In addition, we released the first Red Hat-branded version of our block and object storage solution, Red Hat's Inktank Ceph Enterprise 1.2. This version includes new features to help customers store and manage an entire spectrum of data from hot mission-critical data to cold archival data. The new functionality, coupled with enhancements to the solutions management and monitoring platform, make the Red Hat's Inktank Ceph Enterprise storage solution a flexible and cost-effective storage platform for enterprises managing data-intensive applications, including OpenStack deployments.
We also continue to invest in the future innovation with the announcement earlier today of the signing of an acquisition agreement for FeedHenry, a Mobile Backend-as-a-Service vendor. Mobile computing is changing the way enterprises conduct business and engage with their employees, partners and customers. It's a rapidly growing segment of IT, and enterprises are looking for solutions that enable them to extend existing applications to mobile devices and to build new applications that embrace mobile users from the beginning.
FeedHenry is an early adopter in cloud-based enterprise mobile applications platforms, has expertise in delivering on mobile applications needs for enterprises. With the completion of the acquisition, Red Hat will be better able to support customers in the end mobile application development, integration and management needs at enterprise scale.
FeedHenry is a natural fit with Red Hat's strengths in Enterprise Middleware and OpenShift Platform-as-a-Service technology. In fact, our OpenShift Online recently achieved the milestone of 2 million applications created on the platform. That's double year-over-year. This combination of application integration technologies will allow our customers to meet their growing mobile requirements.
On the partner front, we recently announced an expanded strategic partnership with Cisco involving Red Hat's broad portfolio of cloud technologies. Red Hat and Cisco jointly served many large customers with complementary solutions for running new workloads. Accordingly, Cisco is interested in promoting Red Hat's open source-based solutions, Linux, OpenStack, OpenShift, our Middleware storage, Red Hat Cloud Infrastructure and management.
Cisco is also the market leader in integrated infrastructure, the fast-growing market segment that combines server, networking, storage and management software. Cisco is rolling out its largest update to their UCS platform, which will include a new UCS bundled solution based on the RHEL OpenStack platform. Part of the thinking for this new family of Cisco UCS solutions was strongly affirmed by Cisco's largest customers. 19 of 20 -- 19 of Cisco's top 20 customers told them that they plan to use OpenStack. Customer demand, our successful history of partnering around RHEL and Red Hat's leading position in OpenStack made Red Hat the logical choice for Cisco to bring these solutions to market.
In addition to the Cisco announcement, Red Hat and Nokia jointly announced that we will be expanding our work together to enable mobile operators to create a more efficient, flexible, telco cloud infrastructure. The agreement bundles Nokia Networks' carrier-grade virtualized core applications and cloud application management products with Red Hat's Enterprise Linux OpenStack platform.
With Alcatel-Lucent, Dell and now Nokia, we are building a commercial ecosystem to deliver network function virtualization or NFV technology to the carriers.
In summary, our global team of Red Hat associates executed well and delivered a strong first half of fiscal 2015. We've enhanced our position with customers, partners and the open source community. We're excited about the second half of the year as we will look to further strengthen and benefit from our leadership position over the long term while we continue to drive enterprise innovation. That innovation also caused Forbes to recently recognize Red Hat as one of the most innovative companies.
Before turning the call over to Charlie, I want to thank Red Hat associates around the globe for their continued contributions that will enable us to remain at the forefront of driving innovation in our industry.
With that, let me turn the call over to Charlie.

---

Thanks, Jim. I'm pleased to report another strong quarter at Red Hat. Our great team of Red Hat associates generated strong growth in all major geographies, routes to market and across our portfolio of technologies. Our Q2 financial metrics reflect their effort. 
Let me share with you some of the highlights from the quarter. First, as background, foreign exchange rates have once again become volatile, especially towards the end of the quarter. The result was fairly minimal impact on our P&L when compared against Q2 last year, last quarter or against guidance since we use an average rate for the quarter. But in contrast, the balance sheet, which is translated using spot rates, at the end of the quarter reflects the near quarter-end weakening of many currencies against the U.S. dollar, including the yen, the euro and the pound. As a result, I will focus on U.S. dollar results and add constant currency equivalents where there was significant change.
With that, some of the Q2 highlights include: Year-over-year Q2 total revenue grew 19%, which exceeded the high end of our revenue guidance due to a combination of strong demand for subscriptions and services and rapid revenue growth from Red Hat certified public cloud providers, which I'll describe in more detail in a moment; Non-GAAP operating margin was 24.4%, higher than expectations due to the top line outperformance and leverage in our business model; And non-GAAP EPS at $0.41 was up 17% year-over-year and also above guidance.
Here are some additional details that led to these results, starting with a look at the largest deals that closed in the quarter. The large deals are big, and they're continuing to get bigger. First, all of the top 30 deals in Q2 were greater than $1 million, as was the case in Q2 last year. We also had 6 deals that were $5 million or greater, a record for Q2, and one of these deals was greater than $10 million. Cross-selling was good with 70% of these deals, including one or more components from our application development and emerging technologies offerings such as Middleware, OpenStack, OpenShift, CloudForms and Storage. 4 of the top 30 deals were standalone deals comprised solely from offerings from our application development and emerging technologies. The top deals came from a broad range of industries, but the top verticals were government and technology and media. 
On the renewal front, I'm pleased to share that once again, we renewed all of the top 25 deals that were up for renewal. Largely due to a high concentration of federal deals, most of which renewed at 100%, the total value of the top 25 deals expected to renew was approximately 110% of last year's total. I would add that the top 25 commercial customer deals were renewed at greater than 120%, as usual. 
In considering the adoption of our solutions, it's worth also noting that 3 of the top 6 largest deals this quarter, each $5 million or over, were not included in the top renewal metric because they were not large deals prior to this quarter. That's a first.
Now let's turn to our financial performance. On a geographic basis, this quarter produced solid double-digit growth across all of our major geographies. 59% of bookings came from the Americas, 24% from EMEA and 17% from Asia Pacific versus a 60-23-17 percent split in Q2 last year.
Q2 sales route mix was relatively consistent with 69% from the channel and 31% from our direct sales force versus a 70-30 percent split in Q2 last year. As we said before, our long-term annual goal is a 70-30 percent split, but we would expect seasonal quarterly fluctuations over the course of the full fiscal year.
As I said last quarter, it is my belief that the rolling 4-quarter average billings metric is the appropriate billings metric. A rolling 4-quarter average billings proxy, which we calculate by adding revenue plus the change in deferred revenue on the cash flow statement for the previous 4 quarters, was $465 million, up 20% year-over-year.
Now let's shift to the income statement. Second quarter revenue was $446 million, an increase of 19% year-over-year and 5% sequentially. Both subscriptions and services drove this outperformance in revenue, meaningfully exceeding our second quarter revenue guidance. Subscription revenue of $389 million was up 19% year-over-year, and rapid revenue growth coming from the relatively new channel of distribution was one of the contributors to this strong performance. I'm referring to the roughly 80-plus Red Hat-certified public cloud providers that deliver our technologies on demand in their clouds and report usage and revenue to us monthly in arrears. Since our services have already been provided, we recognize revenue from this channel immediately, and there is also no deferred revenue.
A couple of important takeaways from this cloud -- this public cloud revenue. First, we estimate that more than half of this cloud revenue is from small- to medium-sized businesses, many of which are new to Red Hat. Second, this public cloud revenue has grown sequentially every month since we began tracking it and is growing at a faster rate than any other part of the business. While the growth in this channel contributed to our revenue upside in the quarter, it's important to also appreciate that it serves as a headwind to 2 other metrics that we track in the more traditional subscription model. Billings and deferred revenue do not fully reflect the acceleration we have seen in this channel because we are billing 1 month in arrears rather than 1- or 3-year subscriptions billed in advance.
Here is a breakdown of revenue by technology. Subscription revenue for infrastructure-related offerings was $332 million, up 16% year-over-year, whilst subscription revenue for application development and emerging technologies offerings was $57 million, up 44% and now approximately 13% of total revenue. As a reminder, our infrastructure-related offerings include mainly RHEL and RHEL-related offerings, while our application development and emerging technology offerings include Middleware, OpenStack, OpenShift, Storage and our new cloud management offerings.
The training and services component of revenue was $56 million, up 18% year-over-year and up 9% sequentially. This acceleration is due to increased training revenues related to the introduction of RHEL 7 and for OpenStack and increased consulting revenue principally for OpenStack and Middleware.
Now I'll discuss the rest of our results on a non-GAAP basis, excluding stock compensation, amortization expense and business acquisition-related costs, starting with gross margin. Subscription gross margin was 93.9%, 20 basis points better than Q1. Training and services gross margin was 33.4%, up 120 basis points from Q1. And overall gross margin was 86.3%, 20 basis points better than Q1 and modestly lower than Q2 last year due to services.
Now moving on to non-GAAP operating expenses. Q2 non-GAAP operating expense came in at $276 million, up 20% year-over-year. R&D grew 22% as we continued hiring engineers for our emerging technologies and added a full quarter of expenses from our acquisitions of Inktank and the OpenStack engineering team from eNovance. We continue to show leverage on the G&A line, which is now 7.6% of revenue, 30 basis points lower than Q2 last year.
Q2 non-GAAP operating income was $109 million, producing an operating margin of 24.4% and well above our guidance. This higher result was due to the outperformance on the revenue line. Net interest and other income was modestly lower than Q2 last year at approximately $2 million.
Our estimated annual effective tax rate was 29% for both GAAP and non-GAAP results. Non-GAAP diluted earnings per share came to $0.41, which is $0.03 above the high end of our guidance range and up 17% year-over-year.
Now let's turn to the balance sheet and the cash flow statement. We ended the quarter with cash and investments of $1.3 billion after spending $66 million on the cash component of the eNovance acquisition and $80 million to repurchase approximately 1.5 million shares of Red Hat common stock. We have repurchased $160 million in Red Hat shares year-to-date and now have $80 million remaining on our share repurchase authorization.
Quarterly operating cash flow was $108 million, while CapEx remained low at $14 million, producing free cash flow of $94 million. Year-to-date, free cash flow is now $250 million, up 18% year-over-year. FX-adjusted days sales outstanding at 60 days continue to be within our target range and up 3 days from Q2 last year. As a reminder, since day sales outstanding is traditionally a measure of receivables compared to billings, our DSO is calculated using our billings proxy.
Total deferred revenue at quarter end was $1.25 billion, an increase of $192 million or 18% over the same quarter a year ago. Current deferred revenue grew 16%, and long-term deferred revenue grew 26% from 1 year ago. Sequentially, deferred revenue decreased approximately $21 million from last quarter due mainly to the volatility of foreign exchange spot rates, which I discussed earlier. The FX impact on deferred revenue was $15 million of this decrease.
To isolate the FX impact, let me break down the components of deferred revenue for you. Short-term deferred revenue, which ended Q1 at $947 million, had a real decrease in Q2 of $16 million and decreased $10 million more as a result of changes in currency spot rates, ending Q2 at $921 million. Long-term deferred revenue, which ended Q1 at $325 million, had a real increase in Q2 of approximately $10 million but decreased $5 million as a result of changes in FX spot rates, ending Q2 at $331 million. The total decrease in deferred revenue, without the impact of currency changes, was $6 million and can be found on our statement of cash flows.
Now I'd like to turn to guidance. For purposes of this guidance, I have assumed that average FX rates for Q3 and the balance of the year are as they were recently. For example, the euro was at $1.29 and JPY 107 equals $1. These rates are significantly weaker versus the dollar than the FX rates I used in providing guidance in June, and these rates create a headwind of approximately $15 million to our updated full year revenue guidance being provided today.
I am also incorporating estimates related to the announcement this morning of the acquisition of FeedHenry, which is expected to close within a few weeks. FeedHenry is an early stage, venture-backed company with innovative technology to address the rapidly growing mobile platform market. Although it has immaterial revenue now, in time, we expect this early-stage business to add to our fast-growing emerging technologies efforts. For the remainder of this fiscal year, FeedHenry may add $1 million to revenue, but it will have a dilutive impact on operating margins of 30 basis points and $0.02 to non-GAAP EPS. However, organic growth is strong, and we expect improved performance of our base business to offset the dilution from this acquisition.
With these assumptions in mind, the new full year revenue guidance is $1.770 billion to $1.785 billion or 16% growth at the top of the range at these assumed currency rates. By raising the bottom of our previous U.S. dollar revenue guidance and maintaining the top end of that range, we have increased the midpoint of our fiscal year revenue guidance by $5 million despite the $15 million incremental foreign exchange headwind that I just noted a moment ago.
In addition, by maintaining the high end of our revenue guidance, we are effectively raising the constant currency revenue guidance by $15 million at the top of the range. It is our intention to continue to invest in sales and engineering, and therefore, we are maintaining our operating margin guidance at around 23%. Please note, this includes absorbing the dilution from all 3 acquisitions this year.
The estimated annual effective tax rate remains at 29%, and earnings per share is expected to be in the range of $1.53 to $1.55, pushing the EPS range higher by $0.01 per share. Our operating cash flow guidance is unchanged at $580 million to $600 million. Free cash flow is expected to show nice improvement this year in percentage terms since CapEx is expected to be in the $50 million range for the full year, down from almost $80 million last year.
For Q3 specifically, I offer the following outlook. Q3 is estimated to be approximately -- Q3 revenue is estimated to be approximately $449 million to $452 million. This reflects approximately $7 million of foreign exchange headwind from my previous guidance and from all the sell-side models I've seen. Operating margin is estimated to be in the 23% area, and interest and other income should be around $2 million. And non-GAAP EPS is estimated to be approximately $0.40, assuming the same 29% tax rate. Consistent with my past practice, I do not forecast quarterly cash flow.
In summary, we continue to believe that we are only at the beginning of the open hybrid cloud opportunity, and Red Hat is uniquely positioned to capitalize on this major market opportunity. With focused investment and adept execution, we will increase our position.
Operator, I'd like to turn now back over to you for the first question.

So a specialized cloud provider is more likely to be working with a large enterprise. They'll bring their own subscription, and that shows up in our regular subscription. So this is the big names that you would normally think about as general public cloud providers.

---

Just continuing on the cloud thing. How many of these 80-plus providers are fully ramped up? Or is there still room for them to improve their output? Also, what's your road map to expand the channel? And lastly, what are the things that give you comfort that this revenue is not cannibalistic to your core business or won't be cannibalistic down the road?

---

So the first part of the question about is there growth, in my view, there's definitely room for growth through the public clouds. I just look at some of the names there. Some of the really big clouds are just getting started. And so there's -- in my view, there's clearly room for growth. The second part of the question about whether it is cannibalistic or not, is there a trade-off? We have had some data, which we've seen from one of our large cloud providers, that basically provided the confidence for me to say that we think more than 50% of this business thus far, at least, has been from small- and medium-sized businesses, many of whom have never before been Red Hat customers. So there's a large percentage of new business here. We also have the Cloud Access program, which Jim was referring to. That's the existing Red Hat customers that have a fully paid subscription in the Cloud Access program. They are allowed to move that subscription from their own data center onto a public cloud. Now that, as Jim said, that would not be accounted for in the number I'm using because they've already paid us for the subscription. But there's another form of usage in the public cloud. And I think there's still plenty of room for growth with these cloud providers.

---

And really quickly, did you disclose the average deal length? As deal sizes are getting bigger, is there any change in duration or is that mainly more products?

---

I did not disclose it, but it's 21 months. So it's been pretty consistent now at 21 months for quite a long time, average deal length.

---

I thought I'd ask a question on the Middleware side. You guys clearly have -- you have a big JBoss installed base. I'm curious if there's still a large percentage on older versions and what you may be doing to kind of push more upgrade to drive more upselling with the broader portfolio you have today.

---

Well, first off, just a reminder on our business model, we sell a subscription to a product, not to specific versions. So if someone has a subscription, they can use whichever version they choose. But I do think you bring up a good point where JBoss, there is still a substantial amount of free JBoss out there. And one of our core go-to-markets on JBoss is going out and explaining why I paid subscription with updates and support and all the things that go along with that is a good business. So there are really 3 main go-to-markets on JBoss. One is the Free to Pay. We have a substantial business of WebSphere and WebLogic to JBoss replacements. And then thirdly and probably most importantly, a lot of companies are standardizing. So all their new application development happens on JBoss. And that's probably the single largest of the 3. But they're all reasonable drivers of growth in Middleware.

---

Another cloud question. I think I heard from comments a moment ago that about 50% of the business is from customers you did not have a relationship with previously. How would you say that skews as far as the value of those deals? I mean, I would anticipate that most large companies already have relationships. So this is -- those 50% of people that are new are probably on the lower end of the scale for dollar volume and subscription size, correct?

---

Well, in the value of the deals that are in the cloud, they're probably representative of a large portion of what's actually in the cloud. Comparing their volume in the cloud, however, to some of our larger deals like the $5 million and $10 million deals that we've done -- talked about this quarter, they're not -- definitely not in the same ballpark. I like to think about it as you planting seeds over time, we -- almost every one of our customers started in a very small way with a few subscriptions. And over time, they've grown now to $5 million and $10 million types of transactions. The 3 I talked about before that moved to something over $5 million this quarter from not a large deal last time is interesting, and it's unusual, and we simply hope that keeps going. But most deals -- most customers will just progress over time, and we think these small deals will do the same.

---

Just to clarify, that 50% is 50% of dollars, not 50% of customers that Charlie was referring to that are new to Red Hat.

---

Maybe I should -- thank you for that color. Maybe I should ask the question differently. When you look at the landscape of customers that you have going through your certified public cloud business, does it skew towards Fortune 2000? Or is there a pretty even distribution between large enterprises and smaller enterprises? Maybe some color on that.

---

Frankly, it's hard to know exactly because we don't necessarily get the end-user customer data for all of it. From what we can tell, it certainly skews substantially smaller, right? This is -- the certified cloud provider recognizes the Cloud Access. Larger customers in that subscriptions can also run those on cloud. That's a different component of revenue that shows up in traditional RHEL, right? These are people who are giving their credit card or doing a different payment, which is why I think it heavily skews to new users.

---

Just 2 quick ones. On the cloud service providers, are most of those deals in U.S. dollar? As that continues to grow, could we see a little bit of a dampening effect from the currency swings we see on the deferred revenues -- or in revenues overall, I should say?

---

From a dollar perspective, I think it's safe to say that the majority of the business is done in U.S. dollars, that's true, yes. And I think your second comment is actually what I was trying to say, is the business model is a little bit different. We've got the revenue is recognized in arrears. So there is no billing for 1 year in advance or 3 year in advance, the longer subscriptions that we would normally do. So it does have an effect on deferred revenue.

---

Okay. And my second question is going either from Free to Pay or going to a more premium subscription. With all the security breaches that we've had over the last few months, are you seeing your customers beginning to want greater comfort in security from having more up-to-date software, better support that comes with the needing to pay for premium subscription?

---

We offer the same bit stream regardless of which subscription. You get higher level of support on the higher level. And so don't think you necessarily see people buying up the higher SKUs. You certainly get customers looking to say I want to make sure that everything I'm running is running RHEL or JBoss and not free alternatives because of some of the scares. So I do think it's helpful for the business, but it's more in the Free to Pay versus a step-up in the specific product.

---

Thank you, operator, and thank you, everyone, for joining our call. We look forward to catching up with you over the quarter. Thank you.

【質問: Sitikantha Panigrahi (Analysts)】
I just wanted to ask about the growth opportunity in your core Linux market. You talked about in the past that there's still opportunity left in the UNIX to Linux migration and then share gain from Windows. And also, with this upcoming release of Grantley from Intel, which will probably drive more server refresh, how much of that will be tailwind for your RHEL business?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Well, we feel really good about RHEL 7. It's one of our largest releases in terms of new features and ease of use that we've ever had. Our RHEL business continues to grow solidly in the mid-double digits. I was just out talking to customers this week. There's still substantial opportunity in UNIX to Linux. We have a lot of interest in Windows to Linux. But as you rightly say, new workload, particularly ones that are targeted to cloud, run on Linux. And so I think we win a disproportionate share of net new workload. So we still see continued growth there far off into the future.

---

【質問: Sitikantha Panigrahi (Analysts)】
And any thoughts on Grantley?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Grantley, again, whenever we get improvements in price performance, that is another reason for people to look to drive workloads. And so we certainly think it will help. We haven't quantified the degree of help, but each time there's a new chip generation out, it does help provide a bit of a tailwind for us.

---

【質問: Matthew Hedberg (Analysts)】
Clearly you guys are seeing the benefit of the cross-sell of emerging products, 70% this quarter in top deals. I'm curious, how much of that can be attributed to the RHEL 7 cycle here? And could we see that accelerate here as you guys start layering on these new products like Storage into the existing base?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Well, I doubt you'd see much out of RHEL 7 at this point. While we have people early interest in using, until you get the dot-1 [ph] release, you don't really see people putting it in production. So most of the large deals, it's still RHEL 6 related. I do think that there's more than usual interest in RHEL 7 because of its support of containers with cgroups and other performance improvements to optimize it for cloud. So I do think we'll see that, but I think the strength you're seeing now is frankly a payoff of our last 18 months of investments in our new products, which are starting to show, obviously, a lot better traction.

---

【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
And Matt, I'd add one other thing. Probably what's quite interesting, of the top 30 deals, once we had a very good cross-line, what was more impressive is that 9 of those top deals actually took between 5 and 10 different technologies. So it wasn't just them buying RHEL and one other thing. It was a broad portfolio in 9 of the top 30 deals.

---

【質問: Imtiaz Koujalgi (Analysts)】
It's actually Taz on behalf of Karl. I have a question on your sales and marketing line this quarter. It actually went down sequentially. Can you give more color on that, please?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Yes. Just to clarify, in the first quarter, we had the Red Hat Summit, which is a large event that we run. And we also had the OpenStack Summit, and we had a number of sales kickoffs. So I -- we had actually expected it to be flat to down for the quarter. So it performed as expected, but it was really the timing of major events that happened in the first quarter that weren't repeated in the second quarter.

---

【質問: Heather Bellini (Analysts)】
I had a question about RHEL 7. And just knowing that customers who are obviously paying maintenance will get that version, how do you think about it from the new capabilities that it might offer that might drive people to add on more products, like Charlie was just mentioning, or the ability maybe to move to higher-end SKUs? I'm just trying to get a sense of how fast you think the new capabilities you're delivering will kind of be absorbed into the market and then potentially help accelerate things on the billing side as we look to next year.

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Well, I think that the single feature that I hear about the most are -- is around containers, right? There's tremendous interest around containers. It's just a new way to build, deploy, manage applications. And I'm hearing that from the most staid European banks, right? It's not just on the West Coast of the U.S. Across the board, people are really looking at containers. And where that starts to drive things, as soon as you start saying containers, you start saying, "Well, What kind of infrastructure do I need? How do I manage those?" And that immediately starts bringing in the rest of our portfolio and we're having discussions around OpenShift, OpenStack. So -- and we have a lot of credibility around containers because all the work we've done in cgroups and other areas within Linux to build the foundation for containers opens up just a large strategic conversation with our customers. And that really just help the drive the whole portfolio. So again, we'll see how this develops. I will say I think we've all been surprised at how fast containers have really, I want to say, kind of hit the mainstream in terms of discussion, and therefore, it really does help drive the portfolio. 【質問: Matt Lemenager (Analysts)】
This is Matt Lemenager on for Steve. Question around OpenStack. And you acquired eNovance and you did this to get engineers. Are you taking any other steps to develop or acquire OpenStack engineering talent?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Well, let me start off. Yes, we got some OpenStack engineers. We got 3 things. So they were one of the 10 largest contributors to OpenStack, and so we got those. We'd certainly look for other ways to continue to augment -- just to try to catch up with demand that we're seeing to augment our skill set. So that's really the 3 reasons for eNovance.

---

【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
And I would add to that in terms of your second part of the question was, looking for other engineering skills for OpenStack. We're looking for great OpenStack engineers all over the world. We've got our own training programs internally. We've got OpenStack training programs that we're offering through our own external training and certification program. And we're actively recruiting where we can find good talent.

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
If you know somebody [ph], let us know.

---

Questions on billings, and I know you're focusing on the trailing. But if I try to look at the short-term billings, as you break that out for us in terms of the constant currency deferred, it looks like it grew slower than long term and then billings overall. So I'm wondering what drove that and whether or not that's related to this shift towards cloud Linux sales and if that means we'll be seeing billings growth rates trail revenue growth rates on a full year basis.

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
I think -- so Michael, I told you -- the last time I saw you I told you I wasn't ever going to talk about the current year billings because I do think trailing 4 quarters is the right metric. ---

【質問: Michael Turits (Analysts)】
And anything in the short-term versus long-term mix. It seemed to be not as good on short term, better on long term this quarter.

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Well, so some -- obviously, on the cloud, there is -- there's no deferred revenue at all. But on some of the large deals, some of the very large deals we did, those are multiyear deals. ---

【質問: Gregg Moskowitz (Analysts)】
Jim, wondering if you could just talk about your expectations from Atomic Host, the container-based optimized lightweight OS, as well as when that might be generally available. And then just a quick one for Charlie, I think you mentioned that federal renewals came in at about 100%. I'm just kind of wondering if that's typical historically speaking?

---

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Yes. So well, I'll start on the Atomic Host. A lot of interest not only from developers but from some cloud providers. So we have a number of discussions going on around the technology. I mean, when you start looking at the best way to run containers, we think it's the best way out there not only because it's a tailored operating system for running containers. It has all the benefits and certifications and the other benefits associated with RHEL. So a lot of interest there. Obviously, we don't talk about GA dates in advance, but we do think it can be a driver for us going forward not just as a product but as part of a portfolio of solutions to best run containers in a true production environment. So a key part of the strategy going forward.

---

【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
On the second part of the question about the renewal, in the period of time we've been tracking this metric, it probably goes back 6 or 7 years now, I think, the lowest we've seen is 103%. We've had a couple of quarters around 105%. We've had a couple of quarters as high as 130%. And generally, the course have been around 120% uplift. The difference this quarter was the preponderance of government deals in there. And what's different with government is many times we're measuring deals, many times the deal has to do with the program. And when the government buys for a program, they typically buy the whole thing. They run the program, and there's no need for -- to go bigger than that. So I don't believe that this is a trend. I think it's a onetime thing. And as I said, there was a couple of other things which were pretty interesting. The top 25 commercial deals still were over 120%. ---

【質問: Keith Weiss (Analysts)】
I was wondering if you could tell me a little bit about sort of the OpenStack ecosystem and the competitive environment. 【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
You might want to mention Cisco.

【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】
Cisco's been a great relationship. We continue to do more work with them jointly at customers. They've obviously announced partnerships in a lot of areas. 【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
Just in terms of guidance, I'll just say again, we have effectively raised the constant currency guidance by $15 million. 【回答: James Whitehurst (Executives)】

【質問: Abhey Lamba (Analysts)】

【回答: Charles Peters (Executives)】
I did not disclose it, but it's 21 months. So it's been pretty consistent now at 21 months for quite a long time, average deal length.

I thought I'd ask a question on the Middleware side. You guys clearly have -- you have a big JBoss installed base. 【質問: Scott Zeller (Analysts)】

2497406.eventHeadline: The Kroger Co., Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Sep 11, 2014
2497406.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Laura. Good morning, and thank you, everyone, for joining us today.
Before we begin, I want to remind you that today's discussion will include forward-looking statements. We want to caution you that such statements are predictions and actual events or results can differ materially. A detailed discussion of the many factors that we believe may have a material effect on our business on an ongoing basis is contained in our SEC filings and Kroger assumes no obligation to update that information. Both our second quarter press release and our prepared remarks from this conference call will be available on our website at ir.kroger.com.
After our prepared remarks, we look forward to taking your questions. [Operator Instructions] We are hopeful that you can join us for our 2014 Investor Conference in Cincinnati, beginning on the evening of October 28 and ending early afternoon on October 29. Details will be coming soon and we are looking forward to seeing many of you then. 
I will now turn the call over to Rodney McMullen, Chief Executive Officer of Kroger.

---

Thank you, Cindy, and good morning, everyone and thank you for joining us today. With me to review Kroger's second quarter 2014 results are Mike Ellis, Kroger's President and Chief Operating Officer; and Mike Schlotman, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Kroger achieved a strong and balanced second quarter. As we improved our connection with customers, we are also executing our growth plan and delivering on our key performance indicators, all of which is fueling strong financial results for our shareholders. Our second quarter performance highlights Kroger's continued growth momentum. 
We continue to deliver on the performance targets we outlined at our October 2012 Investor Conference, including: positive identical store sales growth; slightly expanding rolling 4 quarters FIFO operating margin, excluding fuel; and improving return on invested capital.
For the period, we achieved our 43rd consecutive quarter of positive identical supermarket sales growth. We exceeded our goal to slightly expand FIFO operating margin, without fuel, on a rolling 4-quarter basis; and we increased our return on invested capital, while also increasing capital investment. Based on our strong quarter results, we are raising our net earnings per diluted share guidance and our identical supermarket sales growth guidance for the year. We expect to deliver a net earnings per diluted share growth of 13% to 15% for fiscal 2014. As you know, this is partially due to the benefit of Harris Teeter. We expect to return to our long-term growth rate of 8% to 11%, plus the dividend, in fiscal 2012 -- 2015, sorry. Thanks, Cindy. 
And we are not done growing and differentiating to better serve our customers. We are proud to welcome the incredible Vitacost.com team to The Kroger family. We are excited about the opportunity the merger creates to transform the customer experience and move Kroger directly into the e-commerce space much faster than we could have done on our own. The merger closed last month and our teams are hard at work developing our combined business plan. Mike Ellis will have more to say about Vitacost in a few minutes. 
Our merger with Harris Teeter is going very well and we are learning a lot from each other and we can't say enough great things about our Harris Teeter associates.
We continue to see positive indicators in customer shopping behavior, both what our customers tell us and what their actual shopping behavior says. Kroger's data suggests some greater confidence in the economy and less caution in spending, consistent with what we saw in the first quarter. Even so, confidence in the economy and the economic recovery is not pervasive across the board. Many of our customers are still struggling and we continue to pursue our strategy of connecting meaningfully with all customers, wherever they are in the economic spectrum. 
It is worth noting that our definition of a loyal customer is based on a combination of how often a customer shops with us and the amount of products they purchase from Kroger. We have loyal customers in every segment of the customer spectrum, from value customers to upscale shoppers and everywhere in between. 
We continue to see our loyal households grow at a faster rate than total households. As you know, we developed the 4 Keys of our Customer 1st Strategy more than 10 years ago because we recognized that customers wanted a grocery retailer that would deliver not just 1 or 2 key advantages, but a total combination, including a great overall shopping experience, excellent customer service, a full assortment of both national and corporate brand products and everyday low prices and promotional offerings. 
Today, our customer research tells us that this is even more important. Our customers don't want to compromise by choosing retailers who do only well in only 1 or 2 areas. In short, customers are looking for a food retailer that can offer it all and that is Kroger's sweet spot. That is exactly where we've positioned ourselves to win, it is where we are winning and it is where we intend to continue to win. 
Now I'll turn it over to Mike Ellis to outline our operational performance. Mike?

---

Thanks, Rodney. Good morning, everyone. First, I'd like to thank our associates for their solid performance. Strong and consistent execution is what allows us to continue making investments in all the 4 keys of our Customer 1st Strategy, including investments in our associates and ongoing price investment.
As Rodney said, loyal households grew at a faster rate than total households, which also grew for the quarter. This is important because it tells us that we are connecting with our customers across the entire spectrum and that we are connecting in the right areas: people, products and shopping experience and price. 
As expected, inflation continued to increase during the quarter, especially in meat, dairy and in pharmacy, which continued to produce solid growth in both script count and ID sales. We estimate inflation, excluding fuel and pharmacy, was 2.4% in the second quarter and 2.8% with pharmacy. Even with higher inflation, we saw strong tonnage growth during the second quarter.
Our corporate brands portfolio continues to resonate with our customers. During the second quarter, our corporate brands represented approximately 26.3% of total units sold and 25.2% of sales dollars, excluding fuel and pharmacy. We saw strong double-digit unit and sales growth in Simple Truth and Simple Truth Organics. Our new entry-level price point brands and premium tier Private Selection brand all had strong positive sales and unit gains in the second quarter as well.
Another driver of sustainable growth is Customer 1st innovation. For the past few quarters, we have highlighted innovations that are improving our connection with customers and growing our market share. This quarter, I would like to focus on our merger with Vitacost.com. 
First, I'd like to echo Rodney's welcome to the Vitacost team. You're now part of team Kroger and we couldn't be more excited about that. This is a compelling transaction because of the incredible potential for transformation and growth. We believe Kroger is uniquely positioned to blend the art of retailing and deep customer insights with a superb online experience. Vitacost people and extensive e-commerce platform, coupled with Kroger's customer insights and loyal customer base, will really be a powerful combination that we can leverage to create new levels of personalization and convenience for our customers. We intend to build on Vitacost's robust technology platform and integrate it with our existing digital footprint to do just that. 
This is one of the reasons we recently asked Kevin Dougherty, who has been serving as Kroger's Group Vice President and Chief Supply Chain Officer, to lead this effort in a new role as Group Vice President of Digital and Vitacost. Kevin has been a leader on the Vitacost merger team from the beginning and, for the past several years, he has been increasingly focused on building our digital organization here at Kroger. We look forward to combining our teams to do great things for our customers together.
Now I'd like to provide a brief update on labor relations. We recently completed several successful contract negotiations, covering Food 4 Less associates in Southern California and Kroger associates in Cincinnati and Dayton. We are currently negotiating contracts with the UFCW for store associates in New Mexico, Toledo and agreements with the teams just covering several distribution and manufacturing facilities. Our objective in every negotiation is to find a fair and reasonable balance between competitive costs and compensation packages that provide solid wages, good quality affordable health care and retirement benefits for our associates. 
Kroger's financial results continue to be pressured by rising health care and pension costs, which some of our competitors do not face. Kroger and the local unions, which represent many of our associates, should have a shared objective, growing Kroger's business and profitably, which will help us create more jobs and more career opportunities and will enhance job security for our associates.
Now Mike Schlotman will offer more detail on Kroger's financial results and update our guidance for 2014. Mike?

---

Thanks, Mike, and good morning, everyone. When we outlined our accelerated growth strategy at our October 2012 Investor Conference, we also identified the key performance targets for shareholders to measure our progress. I'd like to spend a few minutes discussing the results in each metric. 
Our first metric is identical supermarket sales without fuel. We're very pleased with our second quarter ID sales growth of 4.8%. This strong performance was supported by ID sales growth in every department in every supermarket division. Our natural foods department continues to grow in the double digits, accelerated by significant household gains. Rolling 4 quarters FIFO operating margin, excluding fuel and adjustment items, expanded by 7 basis points. Over time, we expect our FIFO operating margin growth rate, excluding fuel, to return to slightly expanding on a rolling 4 quarters basis.
The third target metric is return on invested capital. We reported a return on invested capital on a rolling 4 quarters basis, excluding adjustment items of 13.6%, which was an increase from 13.5% in the same period last year. Increased capital investments will make it more difficult to grow ROIC in the near term, however, we expect these investments to be accretive to ROIC as they mature. We expect our year-end ROIC, which will factor in a full year of increased capital investments and fully reflect Harris Teeter in our calculation, to show a slight decline compared to the end of fiscal 2013.
Now I'll share our second quarter 2014 results in more detail. Please note that this quarter includes Harris Teeter and Kroger's statement of operations, so year-over-year percentage comparisons are affected as a result. 
In the second quarter, our net earnings totaled $347 million or $0.70 per diluted share. Net earnings in the same period last year were $317 million or $0.60 per diluted share. As Mike said, we are seeing higher inflation than originally anticipated. We recorded a $26 million LIFO charge during the quarter, compared to a $13 million LIFO charge in the same quarter last year. We began fiscal 2014 estimating LIFO for the year at $55 million. At the end of the first quarter, we increased our LIFO guidance to a charge of $90 million. As reported this morning, we are increasing our LIFO estimate for the year to $100 million, which is an incremental $0.01 charge to net earnings per diluted share in the second quarter and $0.05 to $0.06 for the full year.
As we have mentioned in the past, we manage the company without regard to our LIFO charge and many of the items we discussed are on a FIFO basis. So when we develop our expectations for every given year, we estimate LIFO last. The reason for this is LIFO is merely an accounting convention. Typically, a higher LIFO charge would be a headwind to results, but our strong sales helped us overcome the higher-than-expected charge and increase our guidance. FIFO gross margin decreased 12 basis points from the same period last year, excluding retail fuel operations. 
Operating, general and administrative costs, plus rent and depreciation, excluding retail fuel operations, were essentially flat as a percent of sales compared to the prior year. Increases in workers' compensation and general liability reserves negatively affected this comparison by 8 basis points.
Now for retail fuel operations. About half of our supermarkets have fuel centers today. In the second quarter, our cents per gallon fuel margin was approximately $0.18 compared to $0.165 in the same quarter last year. 
Our long-term financial strategy continues to be: maintain our current investment grade debt rating, repurchase shares, have an increasing dividend and fund increasing capital investments. Achieving the 2x to 2.2x net total debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio by mid to late 2015 remains a key objective. Kroger took on debt to finance the Harris Teeter merger and has not yet final -- realized a full year of Harris Teeter EBITDA. This has caused a significant increase in the company's net total debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio, which is 2.33x as of the close of the second quarter compared to 1.77x during the same period last year. This is, however, an improvement from the 2.42x we reported last quarter.
Kroger's net total debt is $11.2 billion, an increase of $3.5 billion from a year ago. This includes the debt related to the Harris Teeter transaction and the share repurchases activity so far this year. Kroger's strong financial position allow the company to return more than $1.9 billion to shareholders through share buybacks and dividends over the last 4 quarters. During the second quarter, Kroger repurchased 1.6 million common shares for a total investment of $78 million. All $500 million of the buyback authorization in June, granted in June, is still available.
Capital investments, excluding mergers, acquisitions and purchases of leased facilities, totaled $672 million for the second quarter compared to $507 million for the same period last year. We continue to expect capital investments to be in the $2.8 billion to $3 billion range, including Harris Teeter for fiscal 2014.
Now I'd like to update our growth objectives for 2014. Based on our strong second quarter results, we raised and narrowed our adjusted net earnings per diluted share guidance to a range of $3.22 to $3.28 for fiscal 2014. The previous guidance was $3.19 to $3.27 per diluted share. The company's long-term net earnings per diluted share growth guidance remains 8% to 11% and shareholder return will be further enhanced by dividend expected to increase over time.
We raised our identical supermarket sales growth guidance, excluding fuel, to 3.5% to 4.25% for fiscal 2014. The previous guidance was 3% to 4%. We are optimistic, as we look forward to the remainder of the year but, keep in mind, we had a very strong fourth quarter last year to compare to.
Now I'll turn it back to Rodney.

---

Thanks, Mike. As I've said this before, this is an exciting time to be at Kroger. We are accelerating growth in our core business and investing in unique competitive positioning for today and the future. Integration with Harris Teeter is going exactly the way we would hope and we continue to learn from each other in ways to improve our customers' experiences. We see transformational potential in Vitacost's e-commerce platform. We are currently hiring to fill an estimated 20,000 positions in our supermarket stores. Next week, we will open our 2,000th fuel center location and we are well on our way to exceeding our long-term earnings per share growth rate for fiscal 2014.
Now we look forward to answering your questions. Laura, we'll take our questions now.

If you look at the level of maturity.

---

Okay. And when you look at the performance of the projects that you've done, are they all following the pro formas that you had built? Are you -- do you feel like they're -- or are they beating them?

---

Well, it's like anything, all would be an overstatement of all hitting that or overperforming. It's a mixed bag. Some are a little below, some are exceeding it in a big way. But, by and large, most of them, many of them are right at the kind of expectations we laid out. The key there will be to continue to generate the sales and the EBITDA that those stores were expected to generate and then, in turn, hold our divisions accountable to give that EBITDA back to our shareholders and either back to us to continue to invest in the business or back to the shareholders so we can grow it. But clearly, as a group, these stores are performing very well and, I would say, are at a point right now of exceeding our expectations as a group.

---

And then my final question would be, is it right to think about this level of investment as being something that will continue? I know you don't want to talk about moving into a new market. Or should we see this as sort of opportunistic and we'll see a moderation in, say, '17?

---

I would not expect to see a moderation in the capital plans. We've got some great markets where we have average market shares or below average market shares when you look at some of our stronger markets. And the strong connection we see between market share and return on invested capital is one of the reasons we've gone down the fill-in strategy format. And I would expect to continue to see us have a very strong capital expenditure program. When we laid it out in 2012, we expected this to -- a couple of hundred million dollar increase for 5 years and it was going to start in '13. So that really gets you to the '17, '18 kind of time frame. And as we go through that process, we'll go through the report card like you just asked on the stores we've opened. And to the extent we continue to be happy with those investments as a group because, in the end, that's what affects our shareholders, is the group, we'll make ongoing decisions about how much we'll invest in capital. But based on where we are right now, I don't see any cause for pause.

---

So as we -- I guess, just following up on Kate's questions earlier on natural and organics, you mentioned innovation as a big part of some of the growth you're seeing in the channel and the response from the consumer. Can you just provide a little bit more detail on the number of SKUs you've added in these categories, what additional rollouts are still planned and maybe, how much of the sales you think has been incremental? And then, kind of as a corollary there, how do you think about margin associated with this category versus other areas of the store?

---

Well, in terms of incremental, it's hard to say. There's a lot of switching that goes on today between natural and basic type of products. As we've mentioned, we expect our Simple Truth brand to be a $1 billion brand this year. So customers are as interested today and as engaged in natural and organic as they've ever been. Also, we don't talk a lot about organic produce, but that's a category that continues to grow. Could probably grow faster if supply was better, but we continue to enjoy large sales growth in that particular area.

---

And so just, again, on the -- I guess, any additional SKUs that you're planning to roll out on top of what you've done already? And also how you think about the margin in these categories, I guess, now and going forward?

---

SKU count continue to increase and the departments continue to grow in many cases, both on the private label side as well as the branded side. Margins, I'll tell you what, there's more margin pressure now on natural and organic than there's ever been. It seems that it's becoming more and more of a competitive category. And so although margins tend to be better in natural and organic, I don't know if that's going to continue for the foreseeable future.

---

Before we end today's call, I'd like to take a moment to acknowledge that this morning is the anniversary of the attacks of September 11. We all continue to mourn the loss of the brave men and women who perished on that tragic day. And I know that many of the folks on the call today were personally affected by those events. We continue to honor the memory of the fallen through our support of police, firefighters, the military and their families. On behalf of all of us here at Kroger, we want to say our heartfelt thank you to the everyday heroes who work every day to keep us all safe.
Finally, I'd like to share some additional thoughts with our associates listening in today. September is Hunger Action Month and I'd like to take this opportunity to thank our associates across the company who help support our customers and neighbors in need. According to our partners at Feeding America, the nation's largest hunger agency, there are 46.5 million Americans who don't know where their next meal will come from. Together, we are working to combat poverty, in partnership with 106 local Feeding America food banks. 
Last year alone, Kroger contributed the equivalent of 200 million, that's right, 200 million meals, nearly 4 million meals every week, to feed hungry families in our community, which I just find an amazing number and my hats off to our team.
Of that, our Perishable Donations Partnership Program provided more than 50 million pounds of fresh meat, produce, dairy and bakery items directly to local food banks in 2013. Our associates play a vital role in helping us get this fresh, healthy food to those who need it most. Without your help and support, our Perishable Donations partnership would not be possible. Thank you.
That completes our call for today and thanks for joining us.

【質問: Steven Forbes (Analysts)】

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
Yes, on your second question, I wouldn't necessarily agree or disagree with that. And as you know, inflation is -- you really do have to look at it item by item. And as Mike mentioned, even with the inflation, we still had strong tonnage growth and we're very happy with the results in total. A lot of the inflation right now is in some of the perishable areas, the fresh departments and that, as you know, is very seasonal. And if you look at, like, some of the produce inflation, as soon as the next crop comes on, that can heavily impact it. On percentage, I would hesitate to give it because in some areas, we feel comfortable we probably passed 100%, others, not so. And as you know, overall, as I mentioned, tonnage is strong. We continue to reduce our pricing for our customers as we take cost out of the business to do that.

---

【質問: Steven Forbes (Analysts)】
Okay. And then, secondly, so if you think about Harris Teeter, how much scope is there for that organization to accelerate unit growth? I know there's a lot of potential for new stores, but -- and I don't know if that's spread out over more years, can they accelerate unit growth? ---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
John, I think you'll see Harris Teeter have a little bit higher store growth over the next several years than they otherwise would have. They had a lot of projects in the pipeline as the 2 companies came together with the merger and the nice thing about joining Kroger for them is it gives them a little bit more capital capacity to be a little faster on getting some of those store projects up and running. It is true, in many of the markets they operate, where we have growth opportunities, the D.C. area, the Baltimore area, markets like that, the lead time is a little bit longer, but they've always had a very strong and forward-thinking capital plan. It's really just the ability now for them to accelerate some of those a little faster than they may have on their own. So we would expect that their unit growth will kick up from where it has been historically.

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
[indiscernible] average, the lead time is probably, what, 1 to 2 years longer than what we've been traditionally used to, unless you go to the West Coast.

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
Right.

---

【質問: Rupesh Parikh (Analysts)】
So I wanted to dive a little deeper into your expenses for the quarter. So compared to the past few quarters, we saw less expense leverage and I know you guys called out the more difficult comparison. Was there anything else that was unusual this quarter? And were the expenses in line with your internal plans?

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
Yes, they were generally in line with our internal plans. The item that we called out in both -- well, that I just spoke of in the conference call, some increases in workers' comp and general liability reserves, a little bit of increase for this year, as well as some prior year increases in the allowances for that caused about an 8-basis-point negative effect on the OG&A lines. So we would've had a little bit better improvement or we would've shown some improvement if not for the need to increase those allowances. And I can tell you, that is certainly a point of focus for our operators and our loss prevention folks. The key to that isn't the dollars, it's making sure the accidents never happen.

---

【質問: Rupesh Parikh (Analysts)】
Okay. And then shifting to e-commerce, we've seen a lot more noise lately, whether it's from Amazon or Whole Foods and some of your competitors and you guys have clearly made investments with Vitacost. I mean, how do you feel about your current capabilities versus the competition right now?

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
It's a good question. I would say we feel very good, but we're not satisfied. And the changes that we've made over the last couple of years, we feel increasingly happy about what we're seeing. As you know, it's one of the things when we merged with Harris Teeter that we were really excited about. They have an incredibly strong click and collect operation that we're spending a lot of time on. So I feel very comfortable where we are positioned from a food standpoint relative to our competition. I feel even more excited about some of the things that we've put in place to take advantage of the future. Mike or Mike, do you want to add to that?

---

【回答: Michael Ellis (Executives)】
Nothing, other than the fact that the merger just closed a month ago and we are working hard to bring both companies together and see all the benefits we can come up with here.

---

【質問: Karen Short (Analysts)】
I just wanted to dive a little bit into gross margins. So obviously, there's been a lot of news and press about Harris Teeter taking prices down and it's hard to know how much that would've impacted your gross margins on your P&L. But by my math, your core FIFO margins, excluding Harris Teeter, could actually have been up this quarter. Is that a fair statement? And then, I guess, maybe talk about how generics might have impacted your gross margin and other points that might be relevant.

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
Relative to Harris Teeter, I won't go to that level of transparency. Harris Teeter is not the only place that we continue to invest in price. They've -- it's been fairly public about the price reductions they've done and where they've done them, but we continue to refine our pricing strategy in all the geographies we operate. And our goal always remains to grow our operating profit margin on a rolling 4-quarter basis slightly. We were 7 basis points and I've never given a specific number, although Rodney and Cindy both pitted me a little bit yesterday that I've always said, "By that, it's a handful or less," and most people can count how many digits are on both of my hands. And it would be only 1 hand, not 2. So that's why we said we actually exceeded that goal a little bit this time and that's what we always focus on. And when we get the operating leverage, we can accelerate things that we plan to do later. And if things aren't quite trending the way we want to grow operating profit margin, we can slow a few things down. We've become very nimble on that arena, which has been a huge help.

---

【質問: Karen Short (Analysts)】
Okay. So then, just on your quarter, in general, did you guys -- you guys came in above plan in the second quarter, is that fair to say? And then, I guess, it was ahead of plan on earnings. Was that more gas margin related? And I guess, I'm wondering because you didn't beat the Street by much, but your gross margins came in quite a bit higher and yet, you're raising your full year guidance on the low end by $0.03, so...

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
I think it's a combination of things, Karen. The strong sales, certainly, are encouraging for us and that momentum is always good. If you look at everything that has happened and the fact that we've increased our LIFO charge by what will amount to $0.05 or $0.06 more charge than we expected at the beginning of the year, we've now raised our earnings guidance twice, we've now raised our ID sales guidance. It's the combination of those factors that has allowed us to remain quite positive. While we only beat the Street by $0.01, LIFO cost us $0.01 and the 8 basis points from workers' comp and general liability would've been somewhere between $0.015 and $0.02, probably, at least, $0.02, depending on how things round. So despite those headwinds, the underlying strength of our core businesses, we're very happy with it.

---

【質問: Karen Short (Analysts)】
And the top line strength has continued into the third quarter?

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
Yes. So far, through the third quarter, it's very similar to where we were in the first and second quarters and I'm pleased with the continued progress.

---

【質問: Charles Cerankosky (Analysts)】
If we look at the P&L just for the third quarter, are there any Vitacost acquisition expenses worth calling out, Mike?

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
We haven't really called out any merger-related expenses for Harris Teeter for a while. We had some, actually leading up to the merger, there's been a few small ones out there, nothing amounting to much of anything, although a lot of the heavy lifting on -- as we convert systems and maybe happened to write some of the assets off of their books that they have capitalized as we convert to our systems. Those things might face us in the future. But those aren't cash expenditures, they're things that were spent in the past. And Vitacost is just so new. Sure, there was a handful of expenses leading up to the merger. While we used outside counsel, we didn't use an outside financial advisor, so it's not like we had any kind of a fee to pay a third party in that. So there really wasn't much at all.

---

【質問: Charles Cerankosky (Analysts)】
And then, in your guidance for the remainder of the year, Mike, how much dilution from Vitacost is built into that number?

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
It's negligible for the back half of the year and it's certainly contemplated in our guidance. They were actually operating here, very recently, at very close to a breakeven kind of a level. And we have a little bit of dilution built in, but nothing dramatic that we don't think we can overcome with the strength of the underlying operations.

---

【質問: Charles Cerankosky (Analysts)】
So something like less than $0.05 per share?

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
Yes, sir.

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
Less than a handful of pennies.

---

【質問: Scott Mushkin (Analysts)】
Most of my questions have been asked, but I just wanted to delve into the balance sheet. Mike, I know you talked about 2.33x and your 1.7x -- and I probably got the numbers all messed up, but you want to get them -- you want to get down to 2x. But clearly, there's been a lot of activity in the space. I just wonder, from your perspective, does your balance sheet right now preclude you from doing other things? Or would it -- it's a factor? Or how are you thinking about your balance sheet, given the fact that there's been so much activity in the space vis-à-vis M&A?

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
We were 1.77x last year and we were at 2.33x this year, which was 9 basis points down from the first quarter. We feel very comfortable we're on track to get to the 2x to 2.2x. We'll be happy at the high-end of the range. We don't necessarily have to get to the 2.0x, Scott. That's just the range we winded up giving. I don't know that our balance sheet necessarily precludes us from doing anything. If the right opportunity is out there and we go to the rating agencies and they understand the uniqueness of an opportunity, like they clearly did with Harris Teeter, and our follow-through, when we make a commitment to them that we actually follow through on what we do, whether it's how we expect to grow the dividend, how we expect to use cash flow to buy in shares, how we expect to use capital to grow our business organically, we're very open with the rating agencies and follow through on the commitments we make. And if it's the right set of assets with the right growth opportunity, like Harris Teeter was with all the new markets, I don't think we would be precluded from continuing to participate in industry consolidation.

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
The other thing is the 1.77x was unusually low because we had stopped buying back stocks and some other things because we had already announced the Harris Teeter merger and we wanted to position ourself well to being able to merge with Harris Teeter.

---

【回答: J. Schlotman (Executives)】
That's an excellent point. We were actually out of the market on shares for quite a while, as we were blacked out while we were looking at it as well. So it was a combination of factors.

---

【質問: Scott Mushkin (Analysts)】
That's perfect. And if I could have one more. ---

【回答: Michael Ellis (Executives)】
Well, we've had good success with our marketplace format. It is driving a lot of our sales and growth right now. So really pleased with how they're performing, although we are still working on small-format stores. We're doing some work and research around that. 【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
When we look at our Customer 1st tracker, customers can -- rate us very high in our marketplace stores. And I realize 120,000 square feet, it depends on where you start from, it's a good-sized store but it's not so big that you can't manage getting around the store reasonably easy either. And it just gives you a lot of flexibility from a space utilization standpoint. And obviously, the key is making sure what you put in is exciting and something the customer wants.

---

【質問: Vincent Sinisi (Analysts)】
Wanted to ask a little bit more about Harris Teeter, if you guys can give further color in terms of the order online pick up at store capability that, obviously, was one of the big draws from Harris Teeter. Where are you in that process today? And any color that you can give in terms of, maybe, as you roll that capability out further?

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
It's still pretty early in the process. I can tell you that our teams have spent a ton of energy, but it's not something that we are to a point of announcing publicly. I don't know, Mike, if you'd like to...

---

【質問: Vincent Sinisi (Analysts)】
On the -- in the Harris Teeter brand itself, has there been further rollout?

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
Yes. Harris Teeter has continued to roll it out and they continue to have strong growth where they already have it. So it's really both pieces.

---

【質問: Vincent Sinisi (Analysts)】
Okay, great. And just a quick follow-up, switching over to Vitacost. Any work that's been done so far that you can just kind of incrementally share in terms of maybe what some of those other products, when we may start to see them flowing onto the shelves throughout your banners, your other banners?

---

【回答: Michael Ellis (Executives)】
Well, again, we just really closed the transaction and we're right in the middle of putting plans together and going through all of the steps that you would during a merger of this sort and size and really trying to develop our plans for the future and how do we grow the platform, the Vitacost business. So we're still in that discovery phase, but there is a lot going on and we're learning every day that there's more to learn.

---

【質問: Robert Ohmes (Analysts)】
For Rodney or Mike and Mike, the guidance obviously implies a little bit of a slowdown in the ID sales x fuel in the back half. Can you guys just maybe talk about what -- why IDs would slow? Would it -- and maybe what some of the support was? Is your expectation of support from fuel rewards potentially slowing? Is there an expectation of less benefit from inflation? Or is there an expectation that tonnage could slow? Just sort of any color we should think about as far as your opportunity to continue to beat those ID guidance you're giving us.

---

【回答: W. McMullen (Executives)】
Thanks, Robert. First of all, obviously, we're going to strive to make sure the identicals are as strong as we can. If you remember, in the fourth quarter of last year, we had a lot of weather benefits. We didn't really talk about it that much in the earnings call, but there were quite a bit of weather benefits.
