2740809.transcript_text1:
Thank you, Jackie, and good morning, everyone. We welcome you to our second quarter conference call. On the call with me are John Standley, our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Ken Martindale, our President and Chief Operating Officer; Darren Karst, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Vitrano, our Chief Administrative Officer. 
On today's call, John will give an overview of our second quarter results and discuss our business, Ken will give an update on some of our key initiatives, Darren will discuss the financial highlights and fiscal 2015 outlook and then we will take questions. 
As we mentioned in our release, we are providing slides related to the material we will be discussing today. These slides include annual earnings and sales guidance. These slides are provided on our website, www.riteaid.com, under the Investor Relations information tab for conference calls. This guidance is a point-in-time estimate and the company expressly disclaims any current intention to update it. 
This conference call and the related slides will be available on the company's website until the next earnings call, unless the company withdraws them earlier, and should not be relied upon thereafter. We will not be referring to the slides directly in our remarks, but hope you will find them helpful as they summarize some of the key points made on the call. 
Before we start, I'd like to remind you that today's conference call includes certain forward-looking statements. These forward-looking statements are made in the context of certain risks and uncertainties that can cause actual results to differ. These risks and uncertainties are described in our press release, in Item 1A of our most recent annual report on Form 10-K and other documents we file or furnish to the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
Also, we will be using a non-GAAP financial measure. The definition of the non-GAAP financial measure, along with the reconciliations to the related GAAP measure, are described in our press release. Also included in our slides are the non-GAAP financial measures of adjusted EBITDA gross profit and adjusted EBITDA SG&A and the reconciliations of these measures to their respective GAAP financial measure. 
With these remarks, I'd now like to turn it over to John.

---

Thanks, Matt, and thank you, all, for joining us to review our results for the second quarter of fiscal 2015. We are pleased with our results for the second quarter, which included our eighth consecutive quarter of profitability, growth in net income and adjusted EBITDA and significant increases in same-store sales and prescription count. 
Our total comparable store sales increased by 4.1% in the quarter, driven by a 3.7% increase in comparable scripts. Higher utilization in Medicaid expansion states drove this increase as well as the results of our pharmacy initiatives. The increased sales helped us drive net income of $127.8 million and adjusted EBITDA of $364.2 million, both of which were increases over the prior year second quarter. 
Our new Chief Financial Officer, Darren Karst, will provide additional details regarding our financial results for the quarter during his remarks. Darren is a proven leader with a track record of success throughout various financial disciplines, and we are very excited to have him as a member of our team. 
One of the most significant initiatives we focused on during the second quarter was the continued implementation of our new drug purchasing and distribution process with McKesson, which provides our pharmacies with direct-to-store delivery 5 days a week. We have now completed the conversion of all stores and our 4 pharmacy distribution centers to this new distribution process. 
The Rite Aid and McKesson teams did a great job of executing this conversion. We expect that this new process will provide the company with working capital benefits and improved customer service through better in-stock position. The agreement is also generating purchasing savings that are in line with our expectations. 
Pharmacy gross profit improved due to higher revenues, the benefits of our purchasing agreement with McKesson and the impact on inventory valuation related to our transition to this new process. The net effect on inventory valuation resulting from this transition is not expected to be material for our fiscal 2015 results but did increase gross profit, adjusted EBITDA and pretax income by approximately $40 million in the second quarter. Pharmacy gross profit was negatively impacted by lower reimbursement rates. 
Our second quarter results certainly show that we've generated significant sales momentum in both front-end and pharmacy. While we believe that our key initiatives will continue to drive top line growth, we expect pharmacy gross margin in the second half of fiscal '15 to be lower than previous estimates based upon current estimates for reimbursement rates and anticipated lower profitability due to a delay in the introduction of a generic equivalent to Nexium and due to higher costs for generic drugs that recently lost their exclusivity. Therefore, we have lowered our guidance for adjusted EBITDA, net income and net income per diluted share. 
In other developments, we made progress in our continued efforts to more aggressively pursue opportunities for long-term growth while transforming Rite Aid into a growing retail health care company. We continue to expand our pilot for Rite Aid Health Alliance, our innovative program that improves physicians -- that empowers physicians, in-store care coaches from Health Dialog and Rite Aid pharmacists to work together in providing a higher level of care to patients with one or more chronic conditions. 
Early in the second quarter, we announced our largest Health Alliance partnership to date with Heritage Provider Network in Southern California. Most recently, we partnered with a sixth medical practice, Physician Direct ACO in Detroit. We also plan to begin opening RediClinics in select Rite Aid stores during the back half of the fiscal year as we look to deliver yet another convenient layer of health care support to the communities we serve. And as we continue to expand our health care offering, we're also making progress in building up our real estate pipeline to execute our relocation and new store program over the next several years. 
At this time, I'd like to turn it over to our President and Chief Operating Officer, Ken Martindale, who has additional information regarding our key initiatives. Ken?

---

Thanks, John, and thanks, everybody, for joining us in the call this morning. We continue to make excellent progress on our key initiatives as we build a unique and engaging brand centered around health and wellness while actively working with our customers to keep them well. Our Wellness Store program is perhaps the most visible component of our ongoing transformation, and these stores continue to deliver strong results in the second quarter, once again, outperforming the rest of the chain in terms of same-store front-end sales and script count. Our teams are doing an excellent job of completing additional wellness remodels while minimizing the impact this process has on the customer experience during construction. Thanks to their efforts, we now have a grand total of 1,433 Wellness Stores, which represents about 31% of our entire chain. 
We remain highly focused on leveraging our Wellness Store program to launch innovative merchandising concepts that significantly enhance the shopping experience. A great example is our new OTC presentation. This unique research-based consumer solution was developed and tested in conjunction with several key suppliers during the past year. The new design makes shopping navigation much easier and incorporates consumer education and product cross-selling to deliver a much better customer experience. This concept has been very well received by shoppers and is now rolling out to most future Genuine Well-being stores. 
In addition, Wellness Stores will continue to play a key strategic role in launching initiatives that expand our health care offering. Initiatives such as the Rite Aid Health Alliance and RediClinics are taking our overall health and wellness experience to a new level. 
Another critical component to our health and wellness strategy is our highly successful wellness+ customer loyalty program. During the quarter, we continue to further develop our customer relationship marketing program, which is helping us to better understand the individual needs of our wellness+ members. Our increasing number of targeted campaigns, we've been able to drive incremental growth not only in terms of basket size, but also trip frequency. Our gold membership continues to increase, which is significant because these members represent our most valuable and loyal customers. 
This month, we launched the promotion that gives all wellness+ members the opportunity to earn triple points on qualifying front-end purchases. Known as Member September, this promotion is designed to further engage our plus and bronze level members to incent them to advance to the silver or gold tiers, where they can experience the value of receiving a 10% or 20% discount the entire year. 
We now have more than 2.1 million senior members enrolled in the wellness65+ program. A specific area of success has been our monthly wellness65+ Wednesday events, which allows 65+ members to receive a 20% discount on most items in the store for the entire day. While they're in the store, these members can also participate in our monthly wellness-focused events that are designed to help our senior customers experience all the benefits wellness+ has to offer. 
And finally, we've incorporated wellness+ into our new comprehensive Quit For You smoking cessation program. Launched in late August, this free program centers around the counseling skills of our nearly 11,000 Rite Aid pharmacists who have received special training to meet one-on-one with these patients who want to quit smoking. Our pharmacists actively work with these patients to develop a personalized quit plan based on a variety of effective smoking cessation methods. We are also providing free in-store and online educational resources as well as discounts and incentives to wellness+ to encourage them to follow through on their quit attempt. 
The Quit For You program is an excellent example of how we continue to look for ways to make wellness+ even stronger while positioning our Rite Aid pharmacists to play a more active role in helping patients achieve their wellness goals. 
Our flu immunization program is now in full swing as our teams engage with customers about getting their annual flu shot from a Rite Aid pharmacist. Once again, we're supporting these efforts with a comprehensive marketing campaign, which includes radio spots as well as television commercials airing on national networks through November. Our chain-wide goal for the year is to administer 3 million flu shots. We're also using the annual flu shot campaign as an opportunity to educate our customers about the additional vaccines we offer on a state-by-state basis to strengthen Rite Aid's position as an immunization destination.

Yes. I think we're tracking right on target. And we're going to start opening in several months, so you're going to see them aggressively rolling out. And we're very excited about the opportunity that lies ahead of us here.

Yes, it's a combination. Some of it are going into existing Wellness Stores. But probably, we're not in a position to give you guidance today.

---

【質問: Steven Valiquette (Analysts)】
So just to clarify, the pharmacy reimbursement pressure, is that still related primarily to your MAC-based contracts instead of the AWP deals? And also, is the pressure there related more -- potentially more to Medicare Part D? Or is it commercial? Or is it both? Just trying to get more color on the reimbursement.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Sure. It's -- it is not solely related to MAC-based contracts. It also has to do with, again, contracts that have been under negotiation, contracts that we know are coming up in our view and estimates of those impacts, migration amongst plans, migration inside of plans. All of those things are starting to get to really blend the numbers that make up our estimates today and have in the past. In terms of where it is, it is not isolated to Med D. It's really we're looking at our total look of business and we see impacts across that book of business.

---

【質問: Steven Valiquette (Analysts)】
Okay. And then just quickly on the McKesson deal. Obviously, it's been talked about a little bit already here. But I think -- for me, I think of it, as something that would just sort of gain momentum and improve over time. So I guess I'm still trying to better understand the mechanics on how this sort of hurt your fiscal 1Q, and it seems to provide some pretty good upside, obviously, in the just-reported fiscal 2Q. But then based on the guidance, it seems like it's going to be kind of neutral to negative in the back half of the fiscal year. So I'm just trying to figure out just more color on what you said about some of those negative offsets and why it wouldn't just sort of improve as time goes on.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Well, I think -- yes. The first quarter was a difficult transition for us. We were working our way into the relationship. And I think as we talked about, we were pretty unsupported in the marketplace during that first quarter. We really had no levers to work with to help mitigate some of the generic cost inflation that we saw during the first quarter and the reimbursement rate pressure. I think, in the second quarter, we saw pretty much a good strong benefit from the purchasing arrangement with McKesson that really helped drive the second quarter results. And I think if reimbursement rates stayed right where they are right this second, we think the third and fourth quarter would be good, too. But we think the reimbursement rate pressure is going to be tougher in the third and fourth quarter, and it's going to erode some of the savings that we're generating from the McKesson arrangement. I guess it's the best way I can describe it.

---

【質問: Steven Valiquette (Analysts)】
In your mind right now -- it's the final one here. With McKesson, do you think that once they add in the Celesio volume, will that lead to a lot of incremental savings from your perspective?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
I hope so.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
Welcome, Darren, by the way.

---

【回答: Darren Karst (Executives)】
Thanks, Ed.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Whatever this next question is, Darren is going to answer it.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
So, John, my question is, again, on reimbursement rate pressure, so we'll continue to beat this horse. It's always been there, right? I mean, you've talked about reimbursement rate pressure for as long as I can remember, but it hasn't historically been this type of forecasting problem. So why is the pressure intensifying? Why is the outlook for the business changing so rapidly? What's different here today?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Well, I think touched on a couple of things. One is we have much lower profitability from new generics this year versus other years. And so to some extent, we probably agreed to some rates based on some assumptions we had that haven't fully come to bear, so that's a piece of the puzzle right there. I think it's a competitive marketplace out there. I think there are some probably dynamics at work in the PBM marketplace as well as in the federal and state governments that are also playing in to some of the activity that we see from a reimbursement rate perspective. Those are probably the broader trends I can point at.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
Now rates are not set sort of beginning of the year, but I guess what you're saying is that they can continue to move around throughout the year.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Yes, so a couple things there to think about. I mean, one, as you'd expect, there's probably some variation in rates amongst our book of business, so there is migration that occurs throughout the year amongst payers. There's also various rates inside of an individual payer, and we do have movement inside of those plans within a year. And then we have contracts that come up throughout the year.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
All right. And this is probably a hard question to answer because things continue to move around here. But what do you think the outlook is for reimbursement rates on sort of an ongoing basis? I mean, the calendar sort of picks up next year. But if we think about the underlying business, do we just assume this level of intensity each year as we think about your business?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
We do. We think the reimbursement rate environment remains competitive for some of the reasons that we just talked about, but we also believe that the strategic arrangement with McKesson will help us continue to be an efficient provider in the marketplace. We think we will continue to have opportunities to drive our top line growth through the various initiatives that we're working on that seem to be getting some traction. So reimbursement rate is just always going to be there. I think this is a bit of a unique year with some different dynamics that we have going on inside our own company as well as some dynamics in the marketplace. But overall, we remain optimistic about the future of our business and our company.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
John, just a bigger-question picture question. Is -- I know you can work on the cost side, right? But is there an answer, strategically, for reimbursements? When you think about these models, right, I mean, obviously, Walgreens has had some problems as well. But CVS doesn't seem to be having as many problems. I mean, is there the opportunity for a better mouse trap? I mean, just how do we think about the business in that light?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
I'll tell you -- I mean, I'll tell you this. I do think that, at the end of the day, we do bring value to the equation in terms of what we do, and I think we're increasing that value every day with the various initiatives that we're working on in terms of things we're doing for chronic care and polychronic care, the counseling services that we continue to extend at the pharmacy. And so I think the strategic answer to this thing down the road is, while today, we have kind of a gross margin -- honestly, a gross margin model, it's a buy low, sell high kind of negotiation that we have with these PBMs. Ultimately, I think the marketplace will recognize us for the value that we bring in patient care. And I don't think that -- that's not something that's going to happen overnight. But in terms -- from a strategic perspective, over time, that's where the real value in this relationship is created.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
Great. And just one final question for you, just so we don't run the risk of blowing things out of proportion here. But as we think about your guidance where we started off the year, we're 9%, 10% lower on EBITDA. How much of that do you think is McKesson ramped up maybe slower than what you initially thought. Nexium gets delayed versus sort of structural things like rate pressure?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Probably 1/2 to 2/3 of it.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
1/2 to 2/3 is...

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Is the McKesson and Nexium and all that stuff.

---

【質問: Edward Kelly (Analysts)】
And the rest is the rate pressure?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
The rest is the rate pressure. And I think the first quarter really suffered from the transition, and that's going to be a chunk of our decline year-over-year.

---

【質問: George Hill (Analysts)】
Maybe -- you can probably guess I'm going to drill on kind of reimbursement a little bit more. I guess, can you talk about maybe the earnings cadence of the year? And how should we think about the changes in reimbursement? I think a lot of us think of these reimbursement changes as kind of kicking up in the beginning of the year as that indicated. So like is there -- is Q4 going to be meaningfully weaker than Q3? And I guess any color you can give us kind of on earnings cadence and how we should think about the timing, that's helpful.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Yes. I -- we don't normally kind of give you a quarterly guidance, but it is a factual statement that we do have planned changes going on in January 1. So that is one of several timing factors that impact reimbursement rates.

---

【質問: George Hill (Analysts)】
Okay. So I guess -- so the answer to that might be, yes, we should probably think of Q4 as weaker than Q3.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
I'm going to -- I'm not going to take the bait.

---

【質問: George Hill (Analysts)】
Okay. I'll keep fishing then. And then...

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Try some different bait.

---

【質問: George Hill (Analysts)】
And then let's talk about like you talked about the mix a little bit. And should -- how much of the change in the reimbursement should we think of as the change -- what I'll just call pressure from payers in aggregate versus movement of the plan members and mix between different benefit products? Like is more of the pressure being caused by...

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
They're both kind of the same thing, to some degree, because we're filling that same script at a lower rate, whether they migrated to a narrow network plan or some other product or they migrated between payers or a payer just flat-out lowered their rate. It is all those things combined together.

---

【質問: George Hill (Analysts)】
Okay. And then this last one, kind of also asked another way. I think you just answered this with the last question. I just want to hear it one more time. I'm trying to kind of understand the amplitude of the impacts. So it sounded like you said in the previous question that if we look at the step-down in the guidance on the year, reimbursement is about half and McKesson is about half. I'm trying to get the sense for if we look at the $125 million EBITDA reduction for the year, it sounds like half of that is the delay in McKesson coming on and half of that is the delay of -- or changes in reimbursement. And just given it's like -- it's kind of a half year impact for McKesson, McKesson could potentially double that on an annualized basis and we should expect...

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Ed, I'm not following any of that math. I mean, I think in terms of McKesson, what happened with McKesson was really a timing issue in terms of when we got the bid to market, when we were able to purchase the products at the new cost, those kinds of things. That really incurred during the first quarter. That, in my mind, is a bit of a onetime issue. And I think our second quarter results -- or kind of proof in pudding on that as McKesson arrangement is now producing some savings in the current quarter that you're looking at right now, which is probably the reason why it came out as nicely at as it did. So -- and then we sort of look at impacts and the occurrence of kind of have the $60 million from the first quarter, which is really a bit of a timing play, I think, with McKesson. We look at the current guidance exchange, I think with talked about 3 things there. We talked about Nexium, really, that we thought we would get some benefit from in the fourth quarter that's slipping into next year. We talked about a number of newer generics that lost exclusivity that will get more manufacturers as time goes on, which will drive some cost out, which we thought we would get this year, which probably falls into next year. And then we talked about reimbursement rate pressure here in the back half. So again, I think you got to stir all those things together in your thinking.

---

【質問: George Hill (Analysts)】
Okay. And just last tack-on maybe. As I understand the McKesson contract, you guys have a good level of kind of price visibility and price certainty on the generics side that you see with them, I guess. Can you talk about how long that price visibility or price certainty extends? Is that just for this fiscal year? Does that extend beyond this year?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Well, prices in the marketplace change all the time. I mean -- so there's no guarantees in life as it relates to any price on any one product. Our relationships with vendors supply us, allow us things like price protection and things like that can help us have more certainty about prices over a short period of time. But over a longer period of time, it's going to be a constant purchasing effort no longer -- no different than it has been in the past. We work very closely with McKesson in that process. We have visibility to drug cost every day in terms of what's in the marketplace and what we're purchasing at.

---

【質問: Lisa Gill (Analysts)】
I first have a bigger strategic question and that's really around your comment around valuing patient care. How do you think you get paid for that over time? I mean, we talked a lot today about reimbursement pressure. Do you think that it'll be narrow networks and you get more volume? Is it do you, in some way, get a better reimbursement? Or you actually get paid for the cognitive services that you're providing to the patient? How do we think about that going forward? And then just going back to something Ed said earlier, do you think you need to have a closer relationship with someone like a PBM, where you're their preferred pharmacy or something along those lines of JV type of relationship in order for this to really help to alleviate some of the reimbursement issues?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
So I think the concept that I think we have to understand a little bit is that the value that we create through what we do today is not by having the absolute lowest cost on the pill that we purchased. I mean, honestly, average generic drug cost that we sell is maybe $25, $27, something like that. And so how much money are we going to save on a $25 or $30 prescription? That's not really the question at the end of the day. The question is, is the patient compliant? Are they getting the counseling they need? Do they understand what they need to do to improve their health and stay out of emergency rooms and doctors' offices? So again, we're talking philosophically here. I do not have the specific answer on how this migration is going to occur. But I think, over time, there's only so many dollars we're going to be able to squeeze out of the drug spend, particularly on the generic side. And so it's really going to come down to then what differentiates you in the marketplace is not that you can fill that script for $24 versus $25. It's what did you do to help the patient? So at some point, I think the model migrates to something more where maybe there's a reimbursement for the service that you're providing to the patient versus trying to make gross margin on the script. Is that going to happen tomorrow? It's not. But I think if we look over the longer term, that's really probably the model that our industry needs to begin the migration to over some period of time.

---

【質問: Lisa Gill (Analysts)】
And do you think you need to have a closer relationship? I mean, clearly, the numbers have spoken that CVS has performed better than the peers and they have Caremark. Do you think you need a closer relationship with a PBM entity to be able to capture some of these things that you're talking about?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
I don't think necessarily that's the case. I'm not -- again, here, I don't want to get into an argument whether if the Caremark model is the right model or the wrong model. It has certainly been an effective model in the marketplace. And I think you can see it certainly provides certain advantages relative to where we sit today on a stand-alone basis. I guess I wouldn't argue with that. But if I look down the road again and think about drug spend and kind of where it's going, I think the real question is, can we bring value at retail? We touch patients more than anybody else in the whole equation here. So as I kind of come back to it, at the end of the day, I think what we have to sort of work towards is it's just -- it isn't so much about, again, putting the cheapest pill in the bottle. It's really about what kind of value can we bring to the patient relationship. Do we need a PBM necessarily to do that? Not necessarily, quite honestly. The direct relationships that we're building with providers gives us a lot of information and capabilities to directly interact with that patient in a way that we would never be able to get that information from a PBM. They don't have that information either. The provider does. And by working directly with the provider, we're gaining access to a view of the patient that we just never had before and now have the capabilities to help that patient in ways we never had before. And somehow, that's got us stir [ph] into the long-term, I think, strategic landing for where we're going.

---

【質問: Lisa Gill (Analysts)】
Okay. And then I know that you talked about the $115 million to $125 million of EBITDA, and you talked about 2/3 -- 1/2 to 2/3 being McKesson, Nexium and generics. And so therefore, the other 1/2 or 1/3 is reimbursement. I just want to make sure that we have this correct. So as we think about going forward, maybe not necessarily towards the back half of this the this year, but as we go into next year, is it correct to think that McKesson is going to reverse itself, we're ultimately going to get Nexium as we move into next year? And as you talked about a number of these generic drugs that have an application will come to market, so that aspect should somewhat reverse itself and the reimbursement is just going to continue to be reimbursement pressure?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
I think that's right. I'll just clarify a couple of things. And the thing with McKesson was really a timing issue in terms of just getting a thing implemented, and it's important to understand that it was a massive transition for our company. I mean, we've put in a huge amount of effort, and so did McKesson, to get this thing done in the timeframe that we did. I really believe, strategically, we're headed in the right direction here. I mean, I think our combined purchasing power is going to help us get the lowest cost over time, so we're really excited about where we came out here on this thing. And I got to tell you, our stores love the service that they're getting. This 5 deliveries a week is such a big change from once a week for the vast majority of our stores where we were before. It's really helping from a customer service perspective. So that piece right there, I think, was just a timing transition thing that we had to work through. The Nexium, we've talked about. On the loss of exclusivity, I'll just clean that up a little bit. Those are drugs that are already generics. The generic manufacturer that got it had an exclusivity period. That exclusivity period expired. And either no one else has come to make that drug or those that have come are not as many as we expected. The more manufacturers we get for that drug, the lower the cost. What we can see is that, for some of those drugs, there will be more manufacturers next year, so we do think there's some benefit there for us next year instead of this year, same thing with Nexium. That's going to move into next year. So to your point, as we sort of stand back and look at it, we know reimbursement rate will continue to be a challenge next year. As we get closer to guiding for next year, we'll have more view towards what that pressure is going to be and how all these other things will stir together to help us navigate through that.

---

【質問: Mark Wiltamuth (Analysts)】
It's Mark Wiltamuth from Jefferies. Well, amidst all this concern on the margin rates, you did show some solid expansion from Medicaid states. If you could maybe quantify how much that helped the comp and if you think there's more expansion to go there on the comp front.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
It is a very significant part of the comp, having a big impact to, I think, on the pharmacy margin. I think that's going to continue to grow over time as patients utilize the benefits that they receive there. On a much, much, much smaller basis, there is a -- starting to be a developing trend there. As we talked about before, there are some plans, Mark, where they are fairly specific to exchange-based health care. It doesn't cover all the exchange, but there's a few that are pretty focused on the exchanges. And even those are starting -- they're not material yet to the total number, but those are actually growing pretty rapidly right now, too. So we're hopeful that as more and more patients gain access here to health care, we're going to continue to see opportunities to grow our script count.

---

【質問: Mark Wiltamuth (Analysts)】
Okay. And as you head down the strategic path and kind of provided more value at retail, obviously, the RediClinics factor into that. How aggressive are you going to be on adding those this year and next year?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
We're going to -- I think we're pretty much in line with our original expectations there. Ken, I don't know if you have any other...

---

【回答: Kenneth Martindale (Executives)】
Yes. I think we're tracking right on target. And we're going to start opening in several months, so you're going to see them aggressively rolling out. And we're very excited about the opportunity that lies ahead of us here.

---

【質問: Mark Wiltamuth (Analysts)】
And is there a sizable CapEx investment to do that remodel? Or does that just get folded into the broader remodel plans you have?

---

【回答: Darren Karst (Executives)】
It's in our numbers, guidance numbers.

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
It's in our guidance. But it's -- some or both, there'll be some stores we put them in that have either already been remodeled and then there are going to be ones we put them in as we remodel. Is that right?

---

【回答: Kenneth Martindale (Executives)】
Yes, it's a combination. Some of it are going into existing Wellness Stores. When we're putting these things up, we're trying to make sure that if the store hasn't been modified, we're going in and trying to update it and do a wellness remodel. But again, that would be tracking with our original plan. So there's not a lot of CapEx above and beyond what we already talked about.

---

【質問: Mark Wiltamuth (Analysts)】
And do you have any thoughts on if you got any incrementality on scripts coming out of those clinics?

---

【回答: Kenneth Martindale (Executives)】
We certainly hope we're going to get some incremental scripts and probably, some incremental front-end business will come along with it as well.

---

【質問: Karru Martinson (Analysts)】
When we look at the takeout of the 10.25% notes with the revolver, I mean, is the expectation that we would use the free cash flow just to kind of pay that off as it comes in?

---

【回答: Darren Karst (Executives)】
Yes, that is the expectation.

---

【質問: Karru Martinson (Analysts)】
Okay. And then with your competitor, CVS, exiting the tobacco market, I mean, what have you seen in terms of traffic in that category for sales for you guys?

---

【回答: Kenneth Martindale (Executives)】
It's -- whatever's happening out there is -- it's not much. I think, really, what's happening at our stores -- and it's been a little quiet because of all the noise that they've made -- but we rolled out a fairly extensive smoking cessation program about 3 or 4 weeks ago. And we're pretty excited. We're getting some early takeaway and the patients seem to be reacting well to it, and so we're really focused on smoking cessation more than we are in retail sales of tobacco, at this point.

---

【質問: Karru Martinson (Analysts)】
Okay. And just lastly, and I really don't want to ask another question on reimbursement, but...

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Go ahead, come on.

---

【質問: Karru Martinson (Analysts)】
Just so I'm clear, in terms of that period of exclusivity, I mean, you just mentioned you thought there would be more production and hopefully, there's from production on the horizon for some of these drugs that have lost exclusivity. It is my kind of takeaway here that the reimbursement rates kind of on those drugs have already come down, but the cost just hasn't until that manufacturing picks up? Is that the disconnect that you guys are seeing right now in the market?

---

【回答: John Standley (Executives)】
Well, also, just -- I hate to even bring it up. But remember that for many of our contracts, the reimbursement rate is fixed. So had the cost been lower on those drugs, we would have made more profitability. 
And I think that wraps up today's call. Thank you very much for joining us.

---

【回答: Matt Schroeder (Executives)】
Yes. Thank you, everybody.

3208986.eventHeadline: Next Plc, H1 2015 Earnings Call, Sep 11, 2014
3208986.transcript_text1:
We're ready to start. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our 6-month's results. We've had a good first 6 months to the 2014-15 year, sales up 10%, profits up 19%, earnings per share up 20%. In the paper, there are various reasons given why we think we've done well, but I think, actually, probably the biggest ones is, there's some evidence that the U.K. economy now has turned the corner, and we are some real growth come through. 
Our strategy in NEXT is fairly straightforward, and I'll reiterate it for you. Again, it's improving and then developing our products, expanding and upgrading our retail estate, developing our Directory customer base and, of course, returning cash to our shareholders. Since I became Chairman 8 years ago, that strategy has remained unchanged. It's held us in good stand, it's not likely to change going forward. Looking ahead, we've given some pretty clear indicators of growth in the statement, 10% in this quarter, and 4% in the last quarter of the year. If we achieve that, we would have a good year. Simon?

---

Thank you very much. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for making the effort to be here, now I know you've got far more -- many other more important retailers to talk to this morning. Thank you also, I don't know if you got caught in the queue coming in. But a little [indiscernible] thing going on, getting into the UBS this morning, which I've got caught up in myself. There we are, right. The first half of the year, good first half, sales up 10%, profit up 19%. In terms of that -- the difference in sales growth and profit growth, is not quite as big a gap as it looks, full price sales up 11.5%, of the 19%, 2% of it comes off from a swing in the valuation of currency instruments at the half year, there was a GBP 6 million swing in this valuation, that takes it down to around 17%. Ground grew at 16%, most of the margin gain, by far, the biggest elements of the margin gain has come from growth in our existing store sales. 
Interests, up on last year, this is all about the issuing of a bond, our underlying interest rates remain broadly flat. We have about -- we have growth debts around GBP 160 million more than last year. Taxation, 20.5%. Last year in the first half, 20%, but for the full year last year, 20.5%, we're expecting the full year of 20.5% this year, the profit after tax up 18.6%. Earnings per share, expected to be up 22%. This is a combined effect of last year's buybacks in the second half and this year's buybacks. Ordinary dividend, increasing from 36p to 50p, that's a very big percentage increase, but the percentage increase in the half-year dividend is really about rebalancing our dividend, and getting it back to where we wanted it to be, which is 1/3 at the half-year, 2/3 at the end. We are forecasting estimates of 150p dividend for the full year, up 16.5%, in line with the central forecast for earnings per share that we've given for our profits. 
Moving on to cash flow. Capital expenditure, this is just a reminder of last year's CapEx of GBP 105 million, pretty much the same amount on new space, of GBP 71 million, and we'll open around the same amount of that space this year as last year. GBP 12 million on what we -- maintenance CapEx, this is CapEx that just so -- that keeps the stores looking nice, we don't get a return on it. At the beginning of the year, we estimated that number was going to be GBP 5 million or GBP 6 million having taken a look at our whole portfolio, in particular, the stores, whose assets have depreciated to 0, where we have more than 3 or 4 years left on the lease. We've looked at those stores and decided to spend a little bit of money getting then back in better shape. GBP 34 million on other. I spent some time explaining this at the full year results, 6 months ago, so I'm just going to bring it up as a reminder how that breaks down. The only number that's changed on here since the beginning of the year is the warehouse number. The warehouse number was near GBP 17 million, and it's about, it's GBP 12 million now. The difference is that, at the beginning of the year, actually, it's about GBP 6 million higher. The difference is that at the beginning of the year, we thought we were going to buy the land for our new furniture warehouse, as it is, we're going to lease it, so that comes out of CapEx, but will obviously be a -- there'll be a rental costs there at some point in the future. 
In terms of operating cash flow, GBP 200 million this year in the first half, as against GBP 130 million, GBP 129 million last year. This is the cash flow before special dividends and buybacks. The increase of GBP 70 million is mainly driven by the profit growth at the top, but also, there's a change in the ESOT number. Last year, we were continuing to increase the percentage of the options in outstanding, that we cover in our ESOT. And that meant, we spent GBP 30 million more increasing the cover, that's a permanent reduction in share capital if we keep the ESOT topped up. And so it's -- about GBP 30 million of that is really a buyback in disguise. 
In terms of special dividends, 2 special dividends in the first half, are share buybacks of GBP 105 million. 
Moving onto the balance sheet. Assets down 4%, fixed assets down 4%, this is all about depreciation, and running slightly ahead of CapEx. Stock up 15%. Of that stock increase, around 10% is because we expected our sales to be up 10%. The balance is really a timing issue in terms of the stock that was bought in. We bought in stock a little bit earlier for the launch of our autumn season, and our sale was a week later, which meant that at this point in time, we had a little bit more sales stock in the business, that figure has now fallen back to being near in line with sales. 
Debtors, up 9%, and that is driven by, mainly by Directory debtors, up 11%, and that, is driven by credit sales, which are up 10%. The increase in credit sales is not because it increased our credit customers, actually, our credit customers have declined in number, and this is about credit customers spending more with us on their account, partly as a result of increasing credit limits for the very best of our customer base, best credit risk that is. And partly, as a result of increased use of our directory account in-store. 
Net debt at the half year, GBP 571 million. Just looking forward to the cash flow to the end of the year, we started the year with GBP 517 million of net debt, and we expect to generate around GBP 330 million of operational cash flow, after ordinary dividends, CapEx, interests, et cetera. Off that, we'll, we'd have already spent GBP 223 million in special dividends, 2 in the first half and 1 in August. And on top of that, GBP 105 million of share buybacks, which will take us back to pretty much where we started in terms of debt. You'll notice that our net debt figure for the business is pretty much similar to what it's been for the last 5 or 6 years, and obviously, as our profits have grown, some of you might remark that we could afford to increase our debt in terms of -- and our balance sheet is beginning to look less efficient, and that will be a correct observation. However, we are -- beyond the upper price limit of our share buyback limit, and the time to extend that debt is when we can retire equity, we wouldn't increase debt in order to pay special dividends, that doesn't seem a sensible thing to do. 
Retail is the -- the detail of the retail accounts, revenue up 7.5%, 3.8% growth from net space. Increase in space in terms of the percentage increase in the square footage was 4.4%, you'll notice that that is a much higher return on the square footage. We would normally expect to around a 65% return, that's a -- pretty much for the last 10 years the average will be around 60%, between 60% and 65%. The reason for that is just the small number of very high density big shops we've owned: Camberley, Northampton and Braehead Glasgow, be 3 of the -- are the 3 stores that have driven that the most. In terms of profit, profit margins, moving forward significantly in retail, marked down a positive movement, 0.3. Two opposing things going on here: First of all, the good news is, we had less stock to go, into the sale and full-price sales round ahead of marked down sales. The bad news is, we had only 1% less stock, but 4% lower markdown sales. We think that's partly because we delayed the sale a week. Every 6 years we have to push it back a week as it comes to, ticks forward, looking partly, there's an effect there. Partly, it's a return to more normal levels of clearance. The clearance rate we achieved in both Retail and Directory was in line with, if not slightly ahead of our 5-year average. The net effect of that was a gain in retail. However, the drop in retail stock was driven, in part, by a transfer from directory, being much lower than it was last year. Bought-in gross margin, so that -- did I lose you there a little bit? Don't worry. I'm going to - okay good. Bought-in gross margin, positive movement of 0.2%. This is all about currency. We costed a GBP 1.52. We actually bought the currency at GBP 1.54, so we made a very small currency gain. Achieved gross margin up 0.5%. Payroll, positive movement, 2 things going on here: First of all, better productivity in the stores, partly driven by increasing sales in existing stores which meant that our cover at the beginning and end of day, which is where we're at our least efficient, that we've got some productivity gains there, partly, because we reorganized our man-hour planning system. And those 2 effects offset the cost of living pay raise that we all awarded last October. That improvement in margin will reverse out by the end of the year to around flat because we increased our pay rates by around 6% in June. 
Store occupancy costs, big positive movement here. Rental inflation running at around 0.6%, rates at 2.5%, depreciation and one-off movements in occupancy costs, flat on last year. Warehouse, small gain in margin here. Again this is all about leverage over fixed overheads, so a big improvement in margin in the first half. We're not expecting for the same level of improvement in margin in the second half, it will be near a 1% rather than 2%. 
In terms of Directory, revenue up 16%, in terms of the contribution to that growth, 2/3 of it -- of the growth coming from our U.K. business. U.K. business actually grew at slightly more than 10%, and we're at about 11%, 12%. Overseas, contributing 5.5% to the total sales growth of Directory. And I think what we're going to see over the next few years, is that as the U.K. business slows, we're hoping that the growth that we lose from that, as the business matures in the U.K., we will be able to make up for some of that through growing our overseas business. Active customers' up 9%, growth in cash customers, these are customers that come on to the website and pay with a credit card or debit card. That's where the main driver of U.K. growth is coming from. Credit customers down slightly, that's not because credit customers are giving up their accounts. It's because through the churn we're losing more customers -- credit customers than we're recruiting. Most of the new customers we're getting now are cash customers. 
Profit analysis. A drop in margin in direction. I'm just going to walk you through that. We're not -- we are expecting a drop in full-year margin for Directory but not as big as the one we've seen in the half year. Markdown, adverse movement here. The opposite effect to what happened in retail. In the full-price sales or markdown sales, the markdowns were slightly less than full-price, but stock for sale was much higher at 26%. So the clearance rates dropped and that meant that we had a bigger markdown charge. It wasn't actually the markdown charge it was more the obsolescence for the stock that we hadn't sold by the end of the season. And in fact, as the sale has progressed beyond the half year, looking at it, that number will probably nudge up to about 0.3%, because the clearance rates have been a bit disappointing since then. 
Just to give you a picture of what's happened to the total sale stock in the business. Full-price sales across Retail and Directory up 12%, stock for sale was up 8%, markdown sales were up 3%. So across the whole business, we've put less stock into the sale but our clearance rates were reduced. Overall, across retail and Directory the financial effect of that is broadly neutral. 
'14 gross margins in Directory, down 0.1%. Two things going on here. We get the same currency gain that we got in retail but it would've given us 0.2%, but price reductions in some of our overseas territories, we'll be making high profitability, and we took the opportunity to reduce margins to drive sales. And in some currencies, some countries where the currency moved heavily against us, we moved our prices up but not by quite enough to make up for the currency swing and that's pulled our margin down a bit. Achieved gross margin down 0.3%.
Interest income. This is all about interest income. You remember from the credit sales, credit sales grew by 10%, so our credit is still growing but not by as much as sales. Adverse movement on marketing. This is all about direct mail costs. We started doing direct mail this time last year. Direct mail has not been a profitable form of recruitment for many years. Last year we started to do it again and got some positive response to it. That increased our marketing costs and also increases our U.K. sales but marketing costs went up us a percentage of sales. That process will annualize in autumn, winter so we're expecting that marketing, the adverse movement on marketing to reverse out in the second half. 
A similar story on creation and print. This is all about new publications. There were 2 publications that we published in the first half, new publications. The LABEL publication, and the autumn New In publication. Both of which were published in the first half but their sales will come through in the second half. So again we expect that margin, adverse margin movement to drop out in the second half. 
Overall, central overheads, leveraged or fixed overheads, gives us a 0.2% gain. 
For the full year, in terms of Directory, we expect about half of the loss we've seen in the first half. 
Moving on to growth, a subject that we haven't really talked about for many years, sales growth, but a little bit of around it at the moment. I thought it'd be useful to break the sales growth down into its constituent's parts. So in terms of our total growth, there are 5 drivers; new space, existing stores, U.K. Directory, Directory overseas and brands. Retail contributed 4.7%, Directory contributed 6%. And then, of those, you can see that new space and existing store growth gave us about the same growth in sales, 2.5% each. U.K. Directory sales still the biggest driver of growth for the brand at 3.2%. Overseas, 2% of our growth. And brands, particularly, and part of that is this new label business that I'll talk a little bit more about later on, contributing 0.8%. 
What I'm going to do is just talk through some of the initiatives that have driven the different parts of the business. Space, we've actually lost stores in the first half, but put on about 100,000 square feet. Looking forward to the end of the year we're going to have very good visibility of what we will open. We expect stores to decline by 1%. A total square footage to go up in the order of 350,000 square feet. In terms of -- it's quite interesting, in terms of the average size of the shops that we're opening, the average size of the new stores are around 20,000 square feet, the average size of the ones we're closing are around 7,000 square feet. Please don't take that number and multiply it by the numbers on the left-hand side, because obviously the 21,000 is a gross number, not a net -- not a net increase. 
More of our new spaces going to Home and Fashion, and we now have 25% of our total space given over to Home sales. That would account for around 16%, 17% of our retail sales. Large format stores. This is our store in York, and these are stores where we have a, what looks like a home stand-alone shop on one side, 2 floors, downstairs, going each on the ground floor, kitchen, et cetera. Upstairs, bedroom, furniture and bathroom. And on the other side, a traditional fashion store. What we've found is that, unsurprisingly, when we put the 2 together, each element does better than it would have done on its own. These new large format stores account for 70% of the new space that we'll be opening in the current year. 
These are the ones that we've opened. We've opened 11, of which, 6 we've opened in the current year. Hedge End is an interesting new departure for us. This is a store that we -- for the first time, we actually built the shop ourselves. In terms of the economics of it, it's 58,000 square feet. We appraised the turnover at GBP 19.5 million, appraised profit of 3.5 -- around GBP 3.5 million. We did take a view on the payback here. We think this is a very long-term site, and to a degree, it's an experimental shop, so we took a view of a 35-month payback on the shop. For cost turnover it's actually slightly better, that will drop to around 30 months. We're hoping that in time, as we get used to building these shops we'll be able to get the payback back to our more normal 24 months. But we still think for a site that we're going to occupy for the next 20 years in a good location, the 30-month payback is acceptable. 
In terms of new shops, we've got 10 planned, 26 under negotiation. Of those, 7 of them will be bespoke buildings. 
We haven't forgotten about town centers. This is Skipton as was. This is our new superstore in Skipton. It's right on the High Street but on the edge of the High Street and there's a cut-through to the carpark. And these towns were a typical sort of expansion, old sales were GBP 1.4 million, new store sales GBP 3.5 million, and we're getting a good return from those. We do still have 25 proposals for existing towns and cities, some of them are large scale -- are large-scale developments. And I think it will be a mistake to think that the towns and cities of Great Britain were dead. There are some really good towns and cities, and the cities that have invested in better roads, better parking, and who are more ambitious in terms of what they're allowed to happen, prepared to let happen in their towns, those places, not only are they continuing to survive but actually in many cases, moving forward. 
In terms of the performance of new space, obviously, underlying sales did really well this year so we beat out sales targets. 12%, we were 12% ahead of target, payback in 15 months. That's not because we've set our payback targets lower. If we hit our target, we would have done 22 months payback. 
Stock profitability, still very healthy. This is the profit before any essential overheads, 24%. In terms of our existing stores, service has been our big drive this year. You remember this graph that I showed you which -- this was a survey that was done in June last year, where customers, this is independent research, customers were asked how they rated different retailers, service, and since you see it's quite a long way down the pack, with only 46% saying outstanding or very good. Since a year ago, we've changed our recruitment methods. We've changed our staff bonus scheme to make it purely gauge of service, we trained -- changed our training scheme, our appraisal system, our planning system, and we've improved our rates of pay. I mentioned the increase in rates of pay earlier, but that's not because we're having difficulty recruiting people, it's because we think that if we pay a little bit more, we will get the best people. And that's a part of improving our service. We just did the survey again, we've got the results of the survey again in June this year, we've gone up 56% and we're now sort of fourth in the pack of competitors on the High Street, still in my view not good enough, but we're making progress. 
Transitional stock has been another thing that has really helped our ranges succeed this year. You'll remember that we used to plan 2 seasons, spring/summer, autumn/winter, which meant that, particularly, in the first few phases of those seasons, our stock was often weather inappropriate. When people are buying closer and closer to the point at which they want to wear their clothing, it was becoming less and less productive. We divided our seasons now into 4 seasons. We're not allowed to talk about spring/summer season or autumn/winter season unless we're talking financial half year, but then I'd much rather be using the word half year around spring/summer, and so one of the -- it's amazing how effective that sort of -- the whole control of language thing has been. That's what our shop would have looked like this time last year, this is taken in our mock shop, and this is the same part of the shop this year. So a step-change in the transitional content of our ranges. It's very difficult to measure this, but when our buyers have been categorizing the stock, between transitional and nontraditional stock, we think we're taking around GBP 20 million more on transitional stock this year than last year. 
In terms of Directory, a number of things going on here. The most important things is publications. In line with retail, we have changed the way that we -- buy for the seasons. Last -- in 2012, we would have 4 publications bought for our spring/summer season and autumn/winter season, the first book would've had a lot of the summer stock in it, and we only had 4 books. We trialed a number of smaller New In publications last year, and this year, we have rolled that out in earnest. So in terms of what the publication timetable looks like now, still the same 4 books to coincide with the launch of each season. 
And in addition to that, 4 New In brochures -- these brochures are around 150 to 250 pages. The 250 page limit is a postal limit, actually. If you've got over that level, and suddenly, you have to pay a fortune for that. We're looking at ways around that. Next year, we hope to be able to increase the size of these, most around 300 to 350. But what you can see is that every 6 weeks our Directory customers in line with our retail customers are getting an injection of new stock. There's obviously one gap that we've left in the middle there, and next year, we will fill that with a high summer New In brochure that will be for the stock that we launched in retail 6 weeks before the sale, but then carryover into autumn. 
In terms of deliveries, we've made some progress here as well. By far, the most important thing has been the introduction of free Next data store delivery. That service covered stores which accounted for 72% of our sales in October. We sold the brochure over the last 2 -- or so over the last year, we've increased the coverage, and it's now running at -- at the moment, it's running at 94%. As a result of that, we have seen a dramatic increase in the percentage of customers who ordered from home, that had their stock to stores. So 52%. Just over half our orders are now being delivered to stores having been ordered at home. That's not as big a number as it looks, because the orders that go to store, because they have free delivery, and the customers don't want to pay money to have small deliveries sent to them, and actually, it still accounts for 30% of our sales, because these orders tend to be the smallest orders that go to store, it's efficient for the customer and it's obviously also efficient for us. 
We'll be moving the cutoff for our store orders, from 10:00 p.m. to midnight in October. Actually, that service is up and running at the moment, but we're not marketing it until October. But if you go on the website during September, you should be able to order up to midnight for next-day delivery to store. 
Directory overseas, a huge number of very small initiatives, new countries, local languages, new tender types, domestic currencies, these are the ones, these are the changes that we've made this year, the type face in black get the things we've already done, the red ones are changes to come. 
In terms of our sales forecast for the full year, we expect the sales to go from GBP 100 million to around GBP 150 million for this year. What you can see is that the sterling increase we're forecasting is broadly the same as last year, but the percentage increase is much lower. And we think that it's very important not to do the sort of the old analyst trick of taking the 50% growth and compounding it for the next 20 years, and coming up with Amazon. We think that growth in percentage terms will moderate over the next 2 or 3 years, as the changes that we've made to the site in terms of currencies, languages, as those annualize. So you don't get too excited about these numbers. 
The one area where we are uncompetitive overseas is on speed of delivery. Actually our pricing, we believe, in most countries where we're trading, we're delivering stock directly from the U.K. at prices that are competitive with the local market. But our speed of delivery is somewhere between 3, and 5 or 6 days and that is obviously something that our local operators can beat. We are doing a trial in Ireland where at the moment we deliver to Northern Ireland and Era from our trucking stock across -- from our warehouses each day. What that means is that in Northern Ireland, rather than having a 10 PM cutoff for next-day delivery, it's midday. And in Era, it's taking us 2 to 3 days to get the stock to our customers. We are building a small hub in Belfast. It's not huge expenditures, about GBP 1.1 million, and it's included in the CapEx numbers that I've given you already. GBP 1.1 million, that will be a mirror image of our warehouse in Yorkshire. In that, it will hold all the items that we expect to sell in Northern Ireland. Many of those items will only be holding 1 or 2 pieces that we stored as singles in a small warehouse. We will replenish that every day by truck to keep the -- those forward locations topped up with stock. And the stock the customer’s order, inevitably, the customers that order stock that isn't in that warehouse. We'll get it wrong on occasions. We think that the majority of those orders we will be able to fly and get into the warehouse before the parcel leaves the next day, on the majority of items. What that means is that we'll have 10:00 p.m. for Northern Ireland for the next-day delivery. We will also have 10:00 p.m. for next-day delivery in the Republic of Ireland. This operation is something of an experiment. So we're not worried about it. We don't think there's enormous risk. The risk, if you like, is on the cost and management side, rather than the service side. But there is a -- there are, there will be lots of things that we have to learn, not least, about the sort of volumes we need to hold in order to service the demand from these countries. Because it's close to home, because it's an English-speaking country, it's a good place to experiment. If that is successful, and once you've got all the operating systems sorted out, it's our intention to open an Eastern European hub sometime in 2015 stroke, '16. 
Finally, our brands business. Earlier on we were talking about Directory U.K., contributing around 3% growth to the company. Actually, Directory, the whole Directory business, including brands is nearer 4%, and we think the introduction of LABEL, which allows us to bring in brands that don't want to sit in for the Next Directory, gives us another opportunity of growth in the U.K. as our core Directory business matures. We did a trial, we printed 4,000 -- 400,000 books, and it was profitable. And interestingly, and actually, slightly, to our surprise, we saw no evidence of deflection amongst those people who we sent the LABEL brochure to. So we have succeeded, we think, in limiting the brand to noncompeting brands. 
Two modes of operation: Wholesale and commission. The vast majority at the moment are on wholesale. We, over time, we anticipate that more and more retailers will work with us on a commission basis. We make less profit that way, but we think that it is -- the upside of that, is that our partners make more profit, and therefore, we think that will encourage them to give us better stock. 
In terms of the advantages to our brand partners, obviously, we've got an access to the 4 million customer base of the Next Directory, many of whom are already buying their brands. But a lot of them don't live near a High Street that actually sell those brands. They've got the next-day delivery service, so it'd be exactly the same promise, 10 PM cutoff for next-day delivery, the stock can be delivered any one of our stores, for the 52% of our orders that we get from Home to Store. Obviously, we have a catalog production team and photography team, which enables us to put together, the brochure. And the other thing, that I think is important about this business is that it will have exactly the same approach to this to discounting as NEXT. So we will not discount any of the -- of our partners' products, or promote them, price promote them in season. And we think that, that actually -- brands who we're selling to lots of different people, that price integrity will become more and more important. 
It will have its own labels and packaging. And at some point, we will introduce a dedicated sort of stand-alone website, but that's still under construction and in some way off. 
In terms of total brands business, 77 -- we've grown the business from GBP 65 million to GBP 77 million and we estimate it will be in the order of GBP 110 million in the year ahead. The profitability is around 15%, so less than our core business, and that 15% exclude -- on the label profit, that 15% excludes the startup costs, and -- but it also excludes interest income as well. But it is a profitable business. 
In terms of -- this is one of these slightly, airy fairy things that I can't put numbers on, so it will be of no interest to the analyst community. But in terms of what is driving the business, more than anything else, I think it is our -- the emphasis that we are putting as a business on design. We've -- over the last -- this is something that we've been working on, really, for 3 years, and it's this belief, that if we're at the top-end of the mass-market, ultimately, there are always going to be people to be able to sell clothes cheaper than us. And if we are going to succeed, it has to be through the design of our clothing. What we're attempting to do is that every point that we interact with our customers, we want to give them something that is well-designed, and whether that be the clothes that we design -- and we design all of our -- pretty much, all of our clothes, particularly, all of our clothing that we design in-house including the prints which we designed ourselves. Whether that be our shops, where we're beginning to change people's expectations. We've already, I think, changed people's expectations in terms of what they expect on the inside of our shop. But we are slowly, but surely, over the next 10 years, we want to change people's expectations, as to what they can see by way of architecture, particularly, in our out-of-town stores. And we're investing in that in the business. 
So on the left-hand side this is our campus in -- campus is one a bit of a posh word actually. But you know what I mean, our offices in Leicester. This is a new design studio that we've built right in the middle of our campus. And again, it's sort of -- not only is it investing in design, but it's also the message to the rest of the business, is that design is literally at the heart of the business. 
In terms of outlook, economic environment -- and in terms of economic environment we need to talk about the weather. Obviously retailers are allowed to talk about the weather as an excuse for good sales, never as an excuse for bad sales. But really, what I'm doing is, I'm getting excuses in early for next year in a not too subtle way. But what I would point out is that this is the average temperature this year. You can see that actually we have had a much, much better summer than last year, and that has definitely had an effect on our sales. And we can see on a week-by-week basis, when the sun comes out in the summer season, sales go up. That has been a factor. The rest of the economy, employment is still growing, credit is still flowing back into the economy, housing transactions are at very healthy levels, and that's good for our Home business. Real wages, although the gap is narrowing, and has narrowed from where it was in the middle of the credit crunch, but still, there is still a small gap. And I have to say, that is slightly at odds with our general experience and anecdotal evidence we're getting from how our customers are feeling. But the official figure still show a small, although much narrower gap in real earnings. And interest rates remain low. Think caveat, obviously, interest rates remaining low is good for NEXT, because we're at the top-end of the mass-market, which means, our customers have -- a lot of them have mortgages and we have a big tune in that business which means that a lot of our customers are at the peak of their mortgage cycle, obviously good news while they stay low, but health warning on that. Obviously, when they go up, NEXT is likely to be disproportionately affected by interest rate rises in the U.K. 
Outlook for sales, and really, this is just a repetition of what we said in our trading statement. But just to remind you, that's what our growth pattern looked like last year, 1% in the first quarter, 4%, 4% and then 11% in the fourth. In the first 2 quarters, we've grown 11%. The third quarter, we're expecting to be 10%, the fourth quarter, as we reach these very tough comparatives we're expecting that to be 4%. And after everything that we've seen this year so far, in terms of when we come up against the big weeks last year we are seeing an inverse effect. So we do believe that 4% figure. And to give you some comfort on the realism of it, the 2-year growth, if we look at the 2-year growth in quarter 1, quarter 2, 12%, 15%, this is this year's growth from 2 years ago, we're forecasting the same in quarter 3 and actually slightly more in quarter 4. If we achieve our sales range of between 7% and 10% we expect profits to rise somewhere between 11% and 17%. Earnings per share to rise more than that as a result of buybacks, 13% to 19%. Total shareholder return, which in our lingo is earnings per share, plus dividend yield, we expect to be somewhere between 17% and 23%. And just to remind you of the graph that we first put up 5 years ago, in terms of our target range of return, dividends, plus earnings per share, somewhere between 9% and 15%, that's what we've achieved in the past. Last year, it boosted by a big tax gain. This year, we're expecting 17% -- between 17% at the worst case, 23% at the best case.

【プレゼン: Simon Wolfson (Executives)】
Thank you very much. Good morning, everybody. Thank you for making the effort to be here, now I know you've got far more -- many other more important retailers to talk to this morning. Thank you also, I don't know if you got caught in the queue coming in. But a little [indiscernible] thing going on, getting into the UBS this morning, which I've got caught up in myself. There we are, right. The first half of the year, good first half, sales up 10%, profit up 19%. Ground grew at 16%, most of the margin gain, by far, the biggest elements of the margin gain has come from growth in our existing store sales.
