GBP 12 million on what we -- maintenance CapEx, this is CapEx that just so -- that keeps the stores looking nice, we don't get a return on it. At the beginning of the year, we estimated that number was going to be GBP 5 million or GBP 6 million having taken a look at our whole portfolio, in particular, the stores, whose assets have depreciated to 0, where we have more than 3 or 4 years left on the lease. We've looked at those stores and decided to spend a little bit of money getting then back in better shape. GBP 34 million on other. I spent some time explaining this at the full year results, 6 months ago, so I'm just going to bring it up as a reminder how that breaks down. The only number that's changed on here since the beginning of the year is the warehouse number. The warehouse number was near GBP 17 million, and it's about, it's GBP 12 million now. The difference is that, at the beginning of the year, actually, it's about GBP 6 million higher. The difference is that at the beginning of the year, we thought we were going to buy the land for our new furniture warehouse, as it is, we're going to lease it, so that comes out of CapEx, but will obviously be a -- there'll be a rental costs there at some point in the future. 
In terms of operating cash flow, GBP 200 million this year in the first half, as against GBP 130 million, GBP 129 million last year. This is the cash flow before special dividends and buybacks. The increase of GBP 70 million is mainly driven by the profit growth at the top, but also, there's a change in the ESOT number. Last year, we were continuing to increase the percentage of the options in outstanding, that we cover in our ESOT. And that meant, we spent GBP 30 million more increasing the cover, that's a permanent reduction in share capital if we keep the ESOT topped up. And so it's -- about GBP 30 million of that is really a buyback in disguise. 
In terms of special dividends, 2 special dividends in the first half, are share buybacks of GBP 105 million. 
Moving onto the balance sheet. Assets down 4%, fixed assets down 4%, this is all about depreciation, and running slightly ahead of CapEx. Stock up 15%. Of that stock increase, around 10% is because we expected our sales to be up 10%. The balance is really a timing issue in terms of the stock that was bought in. We bought in stock a little bit earlier for the launch of our autumn season, and our sale was a week later, which meant that at this point in time, we had a little bit more sales stock in the business, that figure has now fallen back to being near in line with sales. 
Debtors, up 9%, and that is driven by, mainly by Directory debtors, up 11%, and that, is driven by credit sales, which are up 10%. The increase in credit sales is not because it increased our credit customers, actually, our credit customers have declined in number, and this is about credit customers spending more with us on their account, partly as a result of increasing credit limits for the very best of our customer base, best credit risk that is. And partly, as a result of increased use of our directory account in-store. 
Net debt at the half year, GBP 571 million. Just looking forward to the cash flow to the end of the year, we started the year with GBP 517 million of net debt, and we expect to generate around GBP 330 million of operational cash flow, after ordinary dividends, CapEx, interests, et cetera. Off that, we'll, we'd have already spent GBP 223 million in special dividends, 2 in the first half and 1 in August. And on top of that, GBP 105 million of share buybacks, which will take us back to pretty much where we started in terms of debt. You'll notice that our net debt figure for the business is pretty much similar to what it's been for the last 5 or 6 years, and obviously, as our profits have grown, some of you might remark that we could afford to increase our debt in terms of -- and our balance sheet is beginning to look less efficient, and that will be a correct observation. However, we are -- beyond the upper price limit of our share buyback limit, and the time to extend that debt is when we can retire equity, we wouldn't increase debt in order to pay special dividends, that doesn't seem a sensible thing to do. 
Retail is the -- the detail of the retail accounts, revenue up 7.5%, 3.8% growth from net space. Increase in space in terms of the percentage increase in the square footage was 4.4%, you'll notice that that is a much higher return on the square footage. We would normally expect to around a 65% return, that's a -- pretty much for the last 10 years the average will be around 60%, between 60% and 65%. The reason for that is just the small number of very high density big shops we've owned: Camberley, Northampton and Braehead Glasgow, be 3 of the -- are the 3 stores that have driven that the most. In terms of profit, profit margins, moving forward significantly in retail, marked down a positive movement, 0.3. Two opposing things going on here: First of all, the good news is, we had less stock to go, into the sale and full-price sales round ahead of marked down sales. The bad news is, we had only 1% less stock, but 4% lower markdown sales. We think that's partly because we delayed the sale a week. Every 6 years we have to push it back a week as it comes to, ticks forward, looking partly, there's an effect there. Partly, it's a return to more normal levels of clearance. The clearance rate we achieved in both Retail and Directory was in line with, if not slightly ahead of our 5-year average. The net effect of that was a gain in retail. However, the drop in retail stock was driven, in part, by a transfer from directory, being much lower than it was last year. Bought-in gross margin, so that -- did I lose you there a little bit? Don't worry. I'm going to - okay good. Bought-in gross margin, positive movement of 0.2%. This is all about currency. We costed a GBP 1.52. We actually bought the currency at GBP 1.54, so we made a very small currency gain. Achieved gross margin up 0.5%. Payroll, positive movement, 2 things going on here: First of all, better productivity in the stores, partly driven by increasing sales in existing stores which meant that our cover at the beginning and end of day, which is where we're at our least efficient, that we've got some productivity gains there, partly, because we reorganized our man-hour planning system. And those 2 effects offset the cost of living pay raise that we all awarded last October. That improvement in margin will reverse out by the end of the year to around flat because we increased our pay rates by around 6% in June. 
Store occupancy costs, big positive movement here. Rental inflation running at around 0.6%, rates at 2.5%, depreciation and one-off movements in occupancy costs, flat on last year. Warehouse, small gain in margin here. Again this is all about leverage over fixed overheads, so a big improvement in margin in the first half. We're not expecting for the same level of improvement in margin in the second half, it will be near a 1% rather than 2%. 
In terms of Directory, revenue up 16%, in terms of the contribution to that growth, 2/3 of it -- of the growth coming from our U.K. business. U.K. business actually grew at slightly more than 10%, and we're at about 11%, 12%. Overseas, contributing 5.5% to the total sales growth of Directory. And I think what we're going to see over the next few years, is that as the U.K. business slows, we're hoping that the growth that we lose from that, as the business matures in the U.K., we will be able to make up for some of that through growing our overseas business. Active customers' up 9%, growth in cash customers, these are customers that come on to the website and pay with a credit card or debit card. That's where the main driver of U.K. growth is coming from. Credit customers down slightly, that's not because credit customers are giving up their accounts. It's because through the churn we're losing more customers -- credit customers than we're recruiting. Most of the new customers we're getting now are cash customers. 
Profit analysis. A drop in margin in direction. I'm just going to walk you through that. We're not -- we are expecting a drop in full-year margin for Directory but not as big as the one we've seen in the half year. Markdown, adverse movement here. The opposite effect to what happened in retail. In the full-price sales or markdown sales, the markdowns were slightly less than full-price, but stock for sale was much higher at 26%. So the clearance rates dropped and that meant that we had a bigger markdown charge. It wasn't actually the markdown charge it was more the obsolescence for the stock that we hadn't sold by the end of the season. And in fact, as the sale has progressed beyond the half year, looking at it, that number will probably nudge up to about 0.3%, because the clearance rates have been a bit disappointing since then. 
Just to give you a picture of what's happened to the total sale stock in the business. Full-price sales across Retail and Directory up 12%, stock for sale was up 8%, markdown sales were up 3%. So across the whole business, we've put less stock into the sale but our clearance rates were reduced. Overall, across retail and Directory the financial effect of that is broadly neutral. 
'14 gross margins in Directory, down 0.1%. Two things going on here. We get the same currency gain that we got in retail but it would've given us 0.2%, but price reductions in some of our overseas territories, we'll be making high profitability, and we took the opportunity to reduce margins to drive sales. And in some currencies, some countries where the currency moved heavily against us, we moved our prices up but not by quite enough to make up for the currency swing and that's pulled our margin down a bit. Achieved gross margin down 0.3%.
Interest income. This is all about interest income. You remember from the credit sales, credit sales grew by 10%, so our credit is still growing but not by as much as sales. Adverse movement on marketing. This is all about direct mail costs. We started doing direct mail this time last year. Direct mail has not been a profitable form of recruitment for many years. Last year we started to do it again and got some positive response to it. That increased our marketing costs and also increases our U.K. sales but marketing costs went up us a percentage of sales. That process will annualize in autumn, winter so we're expecting that marketing, the adverse movement on marketing to reverse out in the second half. 
A similar story on creation and print. This is all about new publications. There were 2 publications that we published in the first half, new publications. The LABEL publication, and the autumn New In publication. Both of which were published in the first half but their sales will come through in the second half. So again we expect that margin, adverse margin movement to drop out in the second half. 
Overall, central overheads, leveraged or fixed overheads, gives us a 0.2% gain. 
For the full year, in terms of Directory, we expect about half of the loss we've seen in the first half. 
Moving on to growth, a subject that we haven't really talked about for many years, sales growth, but a little bit of around it at the moment. I thought it'd be useful to break the sales growth down into its constituent's parts. So in terms of our total growth, there are 5 drivers; new space, existing stores, U.K. Directory, Directory overseas and brands. Retail contributed 4.7%, Directory contributed 6%. And then, of those, you can see that new space and existing store growth gave us about the same growth in sales, 2.5% each. U.K. Directory sales still the biggest driver of growth for the brand at 3.2%. Overseas, 2% of our growth. And brands, particularly, and part of that is this new label business that I'll talk a little bit more about later on, contributing 0.8%. 
What I'm going to do is just talk through some of the initiatives that have driven the different parts of the business. Space, we've actually lost stores in the first half, but put on about 100,000 square feet. Looking forward to the end of the year we're going to have very good visibility of what we will open. We expect stores to decline by 1%. A total square footage to go up in the order of 350,000 square feet. In terms of -- it's quite interesting, in terms of the average size of the shops that we're opening, the average size of the new stores are around 20,000 square feet, the average size of the ones we're closing are around 7,000 square feet. Please don't take that number and multiply it by the numbers on the left-hand side, because obviously the 21,000 is a gross number, not a net -- not a net increase. 
More of our new spaces going to Home and Fashion, and we now have 25% of our total space given over to Home sales. That would account for around 16%, 17% of our retail sales. Large format stores. This is our store in York, and these are stores where we have a, what looks like a home stand-alone shop on one side, 2 floors, downstairs, going each on the ground floor, kitchen, et cetera. Upstairs, bedroom, furniture and bathroom. And on the other side, a traditional fashion store. What we've found is that, unsurprisingly, when we put the 2 together, each element does better than it would have done on its own. These new large format stores account for 70% of the new space that we'll be opening in the current year. 
These are the ones that we've opened. We've opened 11, of which, 6 we've opened in the current year. Hedge End is an interesting new departure for us. This is a store that we -- for the first time, we actually built the shop ourselves. In terms of the economics of it, it's 58,000 square feet. We appraised the turnover at GBP 19.5 million, appraised profit of 3.5 -- around GBP 3.5 million. We did take a view on the payback here. We think this is a very long-term site, and to a degree, it's an experimental shop, so we took a view of a 35-month payback on the shop. For cost turnover it's actually slightly better, that will drop to around 30 months. We're hoping that in time, as we get used to building these shops we'll be able to get the payback back to our more normal 24 months. But we still think for a site that we're going to occupy for the next 20 years in a good location, the 30-month payback is acceptable. 
In terms of new shops, we've got 10 planned, 26 under negotiation. Of those, 7 of them will be bespoke buildings. 
We haven't forgotten about town centers. This is Skipton as was. This is our new superstore in Skipton. It's right on the High Street but on the edge of the High Street and there's a cut-through to the carpark. And these towns were a typical sort of expansion, old sales were GBP 1.4 million, new store sales GBP 3.5 million, and we're getting a good return from those. We do still have 25 proposals for existing towns and cities, some of them are large scale -- are large-scale developments. And I think it will be a mistake to think that the towns and cities of Great Britain were dead. There are some really good towns and cities, and the cities that have invested in better roads, better parking, and who are more ambitious in terms of what they're allowed to happen, prepared to let happen in their towns, those places, not only are they continuing to survive but actually in many cases, moving forward. 
In terms of the performance of new space, obviously, underlying sales did really well this year so we beat out sales targets. 12%, we were 12% ahead of target, payback in 15 months. That's not because we've set our payback targets lower. If we hit our target, we would have done 22 months payback. 
Stock profitability, still very healthy. This is the profit before any essential overheads, 24%. In terms of our existing stores, service has been our big drive this year. You remember this graph that I showed you which -- this was a survey that was done in June last year, where customers, this is independent research, customers were asked how they rated different retailers, service, and since you see it's quite a long way down the pack, with only 46% saying outstanding or very good. Since a year ago, we've changed our recruitment methods. We've changed our staff bonus scheme to make it purely gauge of service, we trained -- changed our training scheme, our appraisal system, our planning system, and we've improved our rates of pay. I mentioned the increase in rates of pay earlier, but that's not because we're having difficulty recruiting people, it's because we think that if we pay a little bit more, we will get the best people. And that's a part of improving our service. We just did the survey again, we've got the results of the survey again in June this year, we've gone up 56% and we're now sort of fourth in the pack of competitors on the High Street, still in my view not good enough, but we're making progress. 
Transitional stock has been another thing that has really helped our ranges succeed this year. You'll remember that we used to plan 2 seasons, spring/summer, autumn/winter, which meant that, particularly, in the first few phases of those seasons, our stock was often weather inappropriate. When people are buying closer and closer to the point at which they want to wear their clothing, it was becoming less and less productive. We divided our seasons now into 4 seasons. We're not allowed to talk about spring/summer season or autumn/winter season unless we're talking financial half year, but then I'd much rather be using the word half year around spring/summer, and so one of the -- it's amazing how effective that sort of -- the whole control of language thing has been. That's what our shop would have looked like this time last year, this is taken in our mock shop, and this is the same part of the shop this year. So a step-change in the transitional content of our ranges. It's very difficult to measure this, but when our buyers have been categorizing the stock, between transitional and nontraditional stock, we think we're taking around GBP 20 million more on transitional stock this year than last year. 
In terms of Directory, a number of things going on here. The most important things is publications. In line with retail, we have changed the way that we -- buy for the seasons. Last -- in 2012, we would have 4 publications bought for our spring/summer season and autumn/winter season, the first book would've had a lot of the summer stock in it, and we only had 4 books. We trialed a number of smaller New In publications last year, and this year, we have rolled that out in earnest. So in terms of what the publication timetable looks like now, still the same 4 books to coincide with the launch of each season. 
And in addition to that, 4 New In brochures -- these brochures are around 150 to 250 pages. The 250 page limit is a postal limit, actually. If you've got over that level, and suddenly, you have to pay a fortune for that. We're looking at ways around that. Next year, we hope to be able to increase the size of these, most around 300 to 350. But what you can see is that every 6 weeks our Directory customers in line with our retail customers are getting an injection of new stock. There's obviously one gap that we've left in the middle there, and next year, we will fill that with a high summer New In brochure that will be for the stock that we launched in retail 6 weeks before the sale, but then carryover into autumn. 
In terms of deliveries, we've made some progress here as well. By far, the most important thing has been the introduction of free Next data store delivery. That service covered stores which accounted for 72% of our sales in October. We sold the brochure over the last 2 -- or so over the last year, we've increased the coverage, and it's now running at -- at the moment, it's running at 94%. As a result of that, we have seen a dramatic increase in the percentage of customers who ordered from home, that had their stock to stores. So 52%. Just over half our orders are now being delivered to stores having been ordered at home. That's not as big a number as it looks, because the orders that go to store, because they have free delivery, and the customers don't want to pay money to have small deliveries sent to them, and actually, it still accounts for 30% of our sales, because these orders tend to be the smallest orders that go to store, it's efficient for the customer and it's obviously also efficient for us. 
We'll be moving the cutoff for our store orders, from 10:00 p.m. to midnight in October. Actually, that service is up and running at the moment, but we're not marketing it until October. But if you go on the website during September, you should be able to order up to midnight for next-day delivery to store. 
Directory overseas, a huge number of very small initiatives, new countries, local languages, new tender types, domestic currencies, these are the ones, these are the changes that we've made this year, the type face in black get the things we've already done, the red ones are changes to come. 
In terms of our sales forecast for the full year, we expect the sales to go from GBP 100 million to around GBP 150 million for this year. What you can see is that the sterling increase we're forecasting is broadly the same as last year, but the percentage increase is much lower. And we think that it's very important not to do the sort of the old analyst trick of taking the 50% growth and compounding it for the next 20 years, and coming up with Amazon. We think that growth in percentage terms will moderate over the next 2 or 3 years, as the changes that we've made to the site in terms of currencies, languages, as those annualize. So you don't get too excited about these numbers. 
The one area where we are uncompetitive overseas is on speed of delivery. Actually our pricing, we believe, in most countries where we're trading, we're delivering stock directly from the U.K. at prices that are competitive with the local market. But our speed of delivery is somewhere between 3, and 5 or 6 days and that is obviously something that our local operators can beat. We are doing a trial in Ireland where at the moment we deliver to Northern Ireland and Era from our trucking stock across -- from our warehouses each day. What that means is that in Northern Ireland, rather than having a 10 PM cutoff for next-day delivery, it's midday. And in Era, it's taking us 2 to 3 days to get the stock to our customers. We are building a small hub in Belfast. It's not huge expenditures, about GBP 1.1 million, and it's included in the CapEx numbers that I've given you already. GBP 1.1 million, that will be a mirror image of our warehouse in Yorkshire. In that, it will hold all the items that we expect to sell in Northern Ireland. Many of those items will only be holding 1 or 2 pieces that we stored as singles in a small warehouse. We will replenish that every day by truck to keep the -- those forward locations topped up with stock. And the stock the customer’s order, inevitably, the customers that order stock that isn't in that warehouse. We'll get it wrong on occasions. We think that the majority of those orders we will be able to fly and get into the warehouse before the parcel leaves the next day, on the majority of items. What that means is that we'll have 10:00 p.m. for Northern Ireland for the next-day delivery. We will also have 10:00 p.m. for next-day delivery in the Republic of Ireland. This operation is something of an experiment. So we're not worried about it. We don't think there's enormous risk. The risk, if you like, is on the cost and management side, rather than the service side. But there is a -- there are, there will be lots of things that we have to learn, not least, about the sort of volumes we need to hold in order to service the demand from these countries. Because it's close to home, because it's an English-speaking country, it's a good place to experiment. If that is successful, and once you've got all the operating systems sorted out, it's our intention to open an Eastern European hub sometime in 2015 stroke, '16. 
Finally, our brands business. Earlier on we were talking about Directory U.K., contributing around 3% growth to the company. Actually, Directory, the whole Directory business, including brands is nearer 4%, and we think the introduction of LABEL, which allows us to bring in brands that don't want to sit in for the Next Directory, gives us another opportunity of growth in the U.K. as our core Directory business matures. We did a trial, we printed 4,000 -- 400,000 books, and it was profitable. And interestingly, and actually, slightly, to our surprise, we saw no evidence of deflection amongst those people who we sent the LABEL brochure to. So we have succeeded, we think, in limiting the brand to noncompeting brands. 
Two modes of operation: Wholesale and commission. The vast majority at the moment are on wholesale. We, over time, we anticipate that more and more retailers will work with us on a commission basis. We make less profit that way, but we think that it is -- the upside of that, is that our partners make more profit, and therefore, we think that will encourage them to give us better stock. 
In terms of the advantages to our brand partners, obviously, we've got an access to the 4 million customer base of the Next Directory, many of whom are already buying their brands. But a lot of them don't live near a High Street that actually sell those brands. They've got the next-day delivery service, so it'd be exactly the same promise, 10 PM cutoff for next-day delivery, the stock can be delivered any one of our stores, for the 52% of our orders that we get from Home to Store. Obviously, we have a catalog production team and photography team, which enables us to put together, the brochure. And the other thing, that I think is important about this business is that it will have exactly the same approach to this to discounting as NEXT. So we will not discount any of the -- of our partners' products, or promote them, price promote them in season. And we think that, that actually -- brands who we're selling to lots of different people, that price integrity will become more and more important. 
It will have its own labels and packaging. And at some point, we will introduce a dedicated sort of stand-alone website, but that's still under construction and in some way off. 
In terms of total brands business, 77 -- we've grown the business from GBP 65 million to GBP 77 million and we estimate it will be in the order of GBP 110 million in the year ahead. The profitability is around 15%, so less than our core business, and that 15% exclude -- on the label profit, that 15% excludes the startup costs, and -- but it also excludes interest income as well. But it is a profitable business. 
In terms of -- this is one of these slightly, airy fairy things that I can't put numbers on, so it will be of no interest to the analyst community. But in terms of what is driving the business, more than anything else, I think it is our -- the emphasis that we are putting as a business on design. We've -- over the last -- this is something that we've been working on, really, for 3 years, and it's this belief, that if we're at the top-end of the mass-market, ultimately, there are always going to be people to be able to sell clothes cheaper than us. And if we are going to succeed, it has to be through the design of our clothing. What we're attempting to do is that every point that we interact with our customers, we want to give them something that is well-designed, and whether that be the clothes that we design -- and we design all of our -- pretty much, all of our clothes, particularly, all of our clothing that we design in-house including the prints which we designed ourselves. Whether that be our shops, where we're beginning to change people's expectations. We've already, I think, changed people's expectations in terms of what they expect on the inside of our shop. But we are slowly, but surely, over the next 10 years, we want to change people's expectations, as to what they can see by way of architecture, particularly, in our out-of-town stores. And we're investing in that in the business. 
So on the left-hand side this is our campus in -- campus is one a bit of a posh word actually. But you know what I mean, our offices in Leicester. This is a new design studio that we've built right in the middle of our campus. And again, it's sort of -- not only is it investing in design, but it's also the message to the rest of the business, is that design is literally at the heart of the business. 
In terms of outlook, economic environment -- and in terms of economic environment we need to talk about the weather. Obviously retailers are allowed to talk about the weather as an excuse for good sales, never as an excuse for bad sales. But really, what I'm doing is, I'm getting excuses in early for next year in a not too subtle way. But what I would point out is that this is the average temperature this year. You can see that actually we have had a much, much better summer than last year, and that has definitely had an effect on our sales. And we can see on a week-by-week basis, when the sun comes out in the summer season, sales go up. That has been a factor. The rest of the economy, employment is still growing, credit is still flowing back into the economy, housing transactions are at very healthy levels, and that's good for our Home business. Real wages, although the gap is narrowing, and has narrowed from where it was in the middle of the credit crunch, but still, there is still a small gap. And I have to say, that is slightly at odds with our general experience and anecdotal evidence we're getting from how our customers are feeling. But the official figure still show a small, although much narrower gap in real earnings. And interest rates remain low. Think caveat, obviously, interest rates remaining low is good for NEXT, because we're at the top-end of the mass-market, which means, our customers have -- a lot of them have mortgages and we have a big tune in that business which means that a lot of our customers are at the peak of their mortgage cycle, obviously good news while they stay low, but health warning on that. Obviously, when they go up, NEXT is likely to be disproportionately affected by interest rate rises in the U.K. 
Outlook for sales, and really, this is just a repetition of what we said in our trading statement. But just to remind you, that's what our growth pattern looked like last year, 1% in the first quarter, 4%, 4% and then 11% in the fourth. In the first 2 quarters, we've grown 11%. The third quarter, we're expecting to be 10%, the fourth quarter, as we reach these very tough comparatives we're expecting that to be 4%. And after everything that we've seen this year so far, in terms of when we come up against the big weeks last year we are seeing an inverse effect. So we do believe that 4% figure. And to give you some comfort on the realism of it, the 2-year growth, if we look at the 2-year growth in quarter 1, quarter 2, 12%, 15%, this is this year's growth from 2 years ago, we're forecasting the same in quarter 3 and actually slightly more in quarter 4. If we achieve our sales range of between 7% and 10% we expect profits to rise somewhere between 11% and 17%. Earnings per share to rise more than that as a result of buybacks, 13% to 19%. Total shareholder return, which in our lingo is earnings per share, plus dividend yield, we expect to be somewhere between 17% and 23%. And just to remind you of the graph that we first put up 5 years ago, in terms of our target range of return, dividends, plus earnings per share, somewhere between 9% and 15%, that's what we've achieved in the past. Last year, it boosted by a big tax gain. This year, we're expecting 17% -- between 17% at the worst case, 23% at the best case.

5687431.eventHeadline: H & M Hennes & Mauritz AB (publ), Nine Months 2014 Earnings Call, Sep 25, 2014
5687431.transcript_text1:
Thank you. Welcome, everyone, to this telephone conference on the occasion of H&M's 9-month results 2014. Our CFO, Jyrki Tervonen is with me, and we'll be happy to answer your questions after the presentation. You'll find the presentation slides to this telephone conference on hm.com.
Please look at the slide, Third Quarter 2014. It was a very strong quarter, both in terms of sales and profits. We continued gaining market share with very well-received collections and we continued our global expansion, with new stores as well as new large online markets. 
H&M Group's sales increased 21% in SEK and 16% in local currencies. Sales were strong for all group brands: H&M, COS, & Other Stories, Monki, Weekday and Cheap Monday. We see this performance as a receipt that customers appreciate our collections. 
Gross profit in the third quarter increased 20% to SEK 23 billion, corresponding to a gross margin of 58.3% compared to 58.8% a year ago. 
Looking at the market situation for some external factors, such as raw material prices, cost inflation, supplier capacity, purchasing currencies and transportation costs, combined market situation for these factors was slightly negative compared to the corresponding purchasing period the year before, mainly as a result of increased cost inflation. 
Looking at the purchasing period for the fourth quarter, the combined market situation for the external factors is also expected to be slightly negative. 
The summer months in fashion retail are generally characterized by clearance sales to make room for incoming autumn collections. This year, markdowns in relation to sales are marginally higher than in Q3 2013. 
Cost control in the group remains very good. Costs in comparable stores were higher in absolute terms than last year but, as a share of sales, costs in comparable stores were lower. 
SG&A increased by 16% in local currencies and translating to SEK, the increase was 20% to SEK 15.7 billion. The increase is mainly related to our expansion, with costs for new stores and to our long-term investments. 
Please turn to the slide, Long-Term Investments. We have continued our substantial long-term investments in IT and online, but also in the broadening of the product range and in our new brands. These are investments that we see as very important for H&M's future success. They cost a lot now, but will be very important for H&M for many years to come. The long-term investments are aimed at further strengthening H&M's market position and securing future expansion.

5687431.transcript_text3:
I was just wondering, on the online, given that you said China was launched a little earlier than expected, what is the potential to accelerate the opening for the coming 8 to 10 markets?

---

Don't get too carried away now. We -- there's intense work going on for the preparation for the 8 to 10 new markets, and we will come back to you in due time when they will open. But it's -- I want to remind you again, it's a lot of work and we invest a lot on this but, of course, it's in our own interest.

---

Can I just follow up on that? Could you just tell us a little how the work on the standardized online platform is going?

---

It's going very well. As you can see, we've now launched 4 new markets within a very short time. So of course, that's boding well for the future.

---

Cedric Lecasble from Raymond James. I have a question on FX. The impact -- the potential impact on sourcing COS. How are you dealing today with rapidly evolving FX, and USD in particular? And what kind of impact could you expect beyond next quarter? Do you think it could change, put a little more pressure on your gross margin?

---

Again, as we've said many, many times before, the gross margin is affected by really 25 to 30 different factors, where FX or currency is one of them. And of course, one of the most important relations is between the U.S. dollars, since we source a lot in U.S. dollar, and the euro because, still, majority of our sales is done in euro. So in a very simple way, you could say that a strong dollar versus a weak euro is negative, all things equal. But things are not equal, so it's not that simple. At the moment, I would say it's pretty flattish. It's no dramatic changes. And then, just to explain a bit further, there is -- as soon as we have placed an order we hedge that, we lock in the markup, so to speak. So the effect on the currencies are, so to speak, postponed until we sell the garment, and you'll see it in our P&L.

---

I wanted to ask you to talk -- you had mentioned the spring/summer collections and, clearly, there've been a lot of strength in the numbers the last couple of quarters. Can you talk about what you think some of the key factors were in those collections that drove such strong sales and margins? And then, maybe talk about the strategies in the future to replicate that kind of success with future collections.

---

Well, I think it's difficult to point out a specific product, a specific factor. I think it's a combination of many, many different factors. But all in all, we believe that -- I mean, we always work with continuous improvement, and we've done a lot of efforts -- we always do a lot of efforts in order to improve the collections. And certainly, we are very happy and the customers seem to be also very happy with the spring and summer collections. But it's very difficult to pinpoint a specific detail or so.

---

And just to follow up. So there hasn't been any change in the design process or the collection rollout process or anything like that?

---

No, not really. I mean, apart from the fact that we continuously work with improvement, and there are always changes going on, but it's more evolution. There's no dramatic change that has been done, no.

---

Just to add, it's the whole customer experience also in the stores, the total customer offering. We have been working a lot with the customer offering. One part is the sustainability work we do. So it's a lot of different factors affecting the turnover. So we shouldn't forget the efforts we are doing in many, many areas, like sustainability and the store experience.

---

Can you -- is your guidance for the longer-term investment package 2014 still SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million? And what would you say -- what would you guide for 2015, please?

---

When it comes to the guidance that we gave earlier, SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million for 2014, we are -- now it looks more SEK 800 million or slightly above for 2014. And for next year, it's too early to give you an exact figure how it will look. We will have to come back to that in connection with the Q4 year-end report. But what we can say is that the long-term investments will be -- be on -- still, on a high level in 2015.

---

Lovely. And could you just give us some idea on CapEx? I think it was north of SEK 9 billion for this year, is that right?

---

Yes. As we've said, we started the year to guide you in a range of SEK 9 billion to SEK 9.5 billion, and now it looks like it will be within that range, but maybe more towards SEK 9.5 billion. But as we always say, it's still, even though we are in September, there are moving parts, still. We are opening, I think, 180, 185 stores still in Q4 and, of course, that could have some moving parts. But that's the best guidance that may be towards SEK 9.5 billion.

---

Right. And for next year, would that grow in line with -- what sort of level of growth would you expect on that for next year?

---

That, we have to come back to in connection with the year-end report to have a better guidance for 2015.

---

Hopefully, there will be some new stores next year as well.

---

Just interested in the markdowns, which you said in Q3 was slightly higher than the corresponding quarter last year. Can you give us a sense of the markdown or if you don't want to do that, just the incremental change, Q3 versus Q3 last year, please, and why that was?

---

Yes. They are slightly higher, less than 20 basis points than compared to Q3 last year. And it's not always as simple that we have a stock problem or too high stock or certain products that is not selling with the planned speed. As we have said, we have been happy with the stock-in-trade level when we went into Q3, and we are happy with the stock level and composition in the end of Q3 as well. But it can also be a situation that we feel is quite common, especially with these past years, that it's still a very high level of price activities on several markets. And then, of course, if we see that the competition is doing a lot of the price activities, for instance, back-to-school activities, then, of course, we also have to react on that. So it's a lot of the salesmanship also included in working with reductions. So it hasn't always to be a stock problem.

---

Okay. Just lastly, a follow-up on the same question, so it isn't an additional one. Given September was a bit weaker than expected, I guess it's going to affect everybody because of the weather. But assuming October, November are a bit stronger, given your stock levels are a bit higher, you'd still be comfortable that there shouldn't be substantial potential markdown effects if the remaining part of the quarter, actually, is back to your sort of growth expectations? You'd still be comfortable?

---

As we said, we have a good level of stock-in-trade as per end August and also the composition, but it's far too early to say anything about the reduction levels for Q4. We still have more than 2 months ahead of us, and especially if the market situation is that it's tough selling figures on the market, it might be that the promotion activities and price activities also will increase during the quarter. So -- but it's far too early to have any guidance when we still left over 2 months in Q4. So we have to come back to that in connection with the next quarterly report.

---

I had a question about the long-term investments online. And just wondered if you could update us on what you're doing to improve your delivery offer and, in particular, moving towards click-and-collect, perhaps. Just looking for an update on some of your key markets.

---

Yes, of course. We are, as you've heard, investing a lot in long-term investments, and a lot of that is, of course, aimed for online. So for us, top priorities is expansion, to roll out into new markets. But parallel to that, of course, we work with a number of things to improve the customer experience, including -- and lots of factors, like click-and-collect, that we're looking at. But -- and gradually, we are improving the customer -- it's not that it's bad today, but it can always be improved, and a lot of things are going on. Any follow-up to that or is that it?

---

Perhaps, I can just try ask you just another slight one. You said last time that you were already online in around 65% to 70% of your market. I'm guessing, by the end of -- by sales. I'm guessing, by the end of the year, you'll probably be somewhere around 75% to 85%. Could you: A, confirm that; and b, by the end of next year, once you've opened another 8 to 10 countries, would you be nearer sort of 95%, 100% -- probably, approaching...

---

We are approaching 100%, absolutely. But I mean, it's been pleasing. If you look at the quarterly report and just take the countries where we have online, they represent, as you say, more than 75% already. And of course, the 8 to 10 new markets we plan to open next year will add that figure even more. So yes.

---

Can we just talk a little bit about the overall impact of the Sport collection and the shoes and all of these other product initiatives in terms of what that's doing to your average prices?

---

Average prices? It doesn't have any material effect on the average prices in the world, but what it does do, of course, is that it extends our offering and we attract even more customers. And the stores we open actually tend to be larger and larger, that I can say.

---

Right. But obviously, a lot of these will be at higher prices generally than your kind of normal offer. So surely, won't it be mixing your average pricing up?

---

I see what you mean. But that's more up to you to speculate in. But it's not the reason that we want to drive the ASP.

---

But it's also widespread in the price range so, of course, they will -- when we are increasing the assortment in shoes, for instance, we will not only increase the higher price group, we will also have the mid-priced, low-priced. So I think that's the mix. So I don't think that will have a material effect on the average sales price. It's looking at the whole H&M assortment.

---

Okay. Could I just also ask about your attitude to other online distribution? I mean, clearly, your primary focus is distributing H&M, in particular, through the -- through your own platforms. But particularly with your smaller brands, what have you done so far in terms of using kind of third-party distribution methods?

---

Well, first of all, if we take the brand, Cheap Monday, that's sold through several different platforms or other companies because it's a wholesale operation, and also including ASOS. And we have there, Monki, it is sold through ASOS as well. And I think that's it at the moment.

---

But of course, we are looking -- but first priority is, of course, to use our own platform. But of course, there are possibilities all around the globe, for instance, in China, Tmall, et cetera. So -- but we will prioritize our own channel.

---

Yes. And do you think that would be appropriate for COS?

---

For COS, I mean, we're very prismatic but, so far, we have COS in, I think, 18 or 17 markets online. And it our own platform and it's very successful.

---

I wanted to pick up from that latest point on -- about Tmall. Wanted to ask about the online in China. You certainly have gone on -- have started very well. Are you planning to go on Tmall? And if yes, how soon? And also, in terms of the online impact...

---

If we just take the first question. As Jyrki just said, I mean, the preferred path is always to do it organic, through our own platform. That's how we have started and we're very happy so far, even though it's very early stage, I must say. But however, we were very pragmatic and, of course, we mentioned Tmall as an option, but who knows? I mean, that's something we will have to follow up.

---

Okay. In terms of the impact of -- that online has to your sales and profits, and I appreciate that China, that's very early. ---

Are you talking about margins or top line or what are you talk about?

---

Top line and margin.

---

Well, we've said many, many times that, for us, online is more or less on the same profitability level as stores. And we also said that online is a very good complement to the offline, and so we're talking about a seamless -- omni-channel shopping experience. So that's clearly why we invest so much and roll it out so rapid now because we see it's a very interesting way going forward.

---

Okay. Last one for me. If we think very long term, because now you do -- your growth markets are China and the U.S. and, I guess, little more emerging markets than your core German and the Nordics countries. If we think that your expansion now is going to be more into the emerging markets, potentially, how should we think about the long-term gross margin? Should we think about a different mix or, more or less, the different geographies have very, very similar gross margins?

---

Of course, there are different margin -- gross margins in different markets, however, for us, it's always about the pricing strategy. We always start from the customer perspective, and we actually have the same price strategy in all markets. Then, of course, gross margin can differ from market-to-market, depending on different cost levels, different import costs, VAT, et cetera. But the spread between the countries, on a price perspective, is -- it's quite limited.

---

And in the long term, it's dependent on what's happening on the market. So if the market is trending towards lower gross margins or higher gross margins, of course, we are following the markets. But as Nils said, we always start from the customer offering, and that's the main focus in our business. As you said, long term, that's a word we like.

---

But as it stands today, can you say that the gross margin, as it stands today, is higher in the emerging markets versus the established markets or not really?

---

First of all, we don't split up the world in emerging markets and non-emerging markets. We look at each markets, per se, and there are differences, but no dramatic differences.

---

I had sort of follow-up questions on the operating cost. Firstly, further to Rebecca's question about the long-term investments. I think given what you indicated through the first 3 quarters, even if we're going to go slightly over SEK 800 million for the full year, that implies a substantial drop in that cost in the fourth quarter. I just want to confirm that I'm interpreting that correctly. And then, I've got a follow-up question on store cost.

---

Yes, we don't give any figures for the fourth quarter when it comes to this. But our guidance is that full year, we'll be slightly above SEK 800 million. So I think, in average, I would say it's more or less on the same level as the third -- 3 first quarters have been, in average. So I think it's no major, major changes. Maybe -- maybe than -- slightly less than in Q3, but no major differences in level.

---

Okay, great. And then, you alluded that costs in existing stores rose, but rose about less than the sales in those existing stores.

---

Correct, yes.

---

So if I just say simply like-for-like store cost rose slightly, that would be the first time that that has happened in over a year. I'm just wondering, is this the annualization of specific cost savings initiatives, and we should, therefore, think that like-for-like store costs might start to creep up again? Or how can we think about the dynamics there?

---

No. I think the normal situation, when we have a sales increase as high as we had in the third quarter, the normal situation is, of course, that we have to add a lot of more hours in the stores, in the logistic organization, et cetera. So I would say that, that's the normal situation. We have been successful in several quarters to have a good balance in the comparable stores. And we still have very good cost controls. As you said, we are increasing the absolute figures but still, as a share of sales, it's better than last year. But for me, there's still very good cost control. A quarter where you have, like, a big summer sale, of course, you handle much more volumes, both in the logistical chain and also in the stores. So it's a little bit tougher to have a leverage during big reduction quarters. So -- but I think I'm convinced that we will, also in the future, have very good cost controls in our comparable stores.

---

Understood. And one final brief question. I know you don't disclose like-for-like sales specifically anymore but, last quarter, you confirmed that the big contribution from new space was running broadly level. ---

Could you rephrase the question, please?

---

Well, I'll put simply, were your like-for-like sales as strong in Q3 as Q2?

---

Yes, absolutely.

---

Yes.

---

---

Was the question the long-term investments, how much of the part from 2015 will fall in, in 2014 or?

---

Yes. For the 8 to 10 online markets that will be launched in 2015, how much of that falls into 2014?

---

Exactly how much but, of course, we will start, and already have been starting to make, preparations with those 8 to 10 new online markets that we are going to open in 2015. But exactly how much of that will land in this current year, it depends on how good we are in getting the process ahead. So that's for sure. We have been working simultaneously with these 8, 10 markets already now, and we'll continue now in the fourth quarter.

---

I'm going to ask on the long-term investments, and there's sort of 2 bits to it, really. The first, when you think about your Conscious collection, your sort of move towards more organic cotton, are these initiatives part of your long-term investment program as you classify it? Or are they just completely separate?

---

They are not included in the long term that we're talking, SEK 600 million to SEK 800 million. They are not included in that figure.

---

But still, they're very long term.

---

They are very long term, but not in that sense.

---

And in terms of your sort of price points on them, are they something that you just absorb the additional cost of any incremental bits that are more expensive or do you pass it through to the consumer and the consumer accepts the -- charge?

---

We absorb it.

---

We absorb it.

---

And in the medium term, would you expect your proportion of sort of sustainable cotton, organic cotton, et cetera, to increase overall?

---

Yes, the goal is that by 2020, all cotton should be from more sustainable sources.

---

And how much do you think that would cost you?

---

A lot. But this is something we think is very -- of course, it's an investment, but for us, it's very -- as Karl-Johan writes in the report, we're, "investing in our common future."

Thanks, operator. Good day, everyone, and thank you for joining us for Sasol's year-end results conference call today. Next, I'll update you on our business performance enhancement program, which is delivering operational efficiencies and driving cost discipline across the group. Paul Victor will then go into more detail on the financial and operational performance of our businesses. Through implementation of our group-wide change program, in 2012, we started to reposition the organization by driving a single set of priorities across the group, with safe, stable and efficient operations at the core. In 2013, to ensure greater focus across the organization, we prioritized our project portfolio, which includes the clear articulation of our near- to medium-term strategy centered on 2 key regions, Southern Africa and North America. In parallel, from 2012 to 2014, we restructured the group and introduced changes to our top and senior management layers and corporate structures and cemented our longer-term strategic direction. These changes culminated in the rollout of our new operating model on July 1, when we implemented our revised structures and processes. 
Next, Slide 6 highlights a few noteworthy aspects of how we repositioned ourselves over the past 3 years. I'll not talk to the specific call-out boxes, but as you can see from the slide, Sasol has strategically repositioned itself to advance our gas-based growth programs concentrated largely in Southern Africa and North America. 
So what is the net result of all of this? Looking at Slide 7, first, our headline earnings per share have, in the last 3 years, increased by 78%. Second, Sasol has increased dividend per share by 65% over the same period. And third, this performance has contributed to our share price increasing by 78%. In addition, total shareholder returns of 103% in rand terms were achieved over this period. Certainly, a very healthy position to build on. 
Turning to Slide 8. In looking at our growth programs, one ingredient is constant and that is natural gas. From 2008 to 2013, 9 of the 17 largest gas discoveries in the world have been in Sub-Saharan Africa. 2 of the top 3 gas discoveries have been in our neighboring country of Mozambique, and we are no strangers to Mozambique, having first entered the country in 1999. And now, 15 years later and with most of the required infrastructure in place, we have been processing and transporting gas for just over a decade.

Here, at the end of last month, we inaugurated Mozambique's first permanent 175-megawatt gas-fired power plant in Ressano Garcia, which will serve to provide electricity to 2 million Mozambicans or 23% of the current power demand.
