Can I just ask on that? So the conclusion of the natural gas growth project, you don't see any real benefits from that in the immediate future then?

---

【回答: Bernard Ekhard Klingenberg (Executives)】
Gerhard, I think there may be upside potential but we'll evaluate during the next cycle to see what other bottlenecks have been created by running at these levels because, I mean, we are running at really high levels for the unit.

---

【回答: David Edward Constable (Executives)】
Great. Thanks, Bernard. On the question of the head office in Houston. If you take a look at Slide 5 there, Gerhard, we've put the titles in on the pictures as Sasol's global headquarters in Johannesburg and Sasol's North American head offices. So clearly, our global headquarters are being built here in Stanton, that will be able to take 3,400 people. We're consolidating 17 buildings into 1 to be much more efficient and productive and looking forward to moving into that global headquarters here in Johannesburg in late 2016. So over in Houston, that's our head office, that's where Steve works out of and that's our -- going to be our new head office in Houston. That will currently house about 350 people and ramp up to approximately 600 or thereabouts as we go into our growth program and build up the projects there. So that's the answer on Houston. Thanks for the questions.

---

【質問: Nishal Ramloutan (Analysts)】
Just 2 things from my side. The one is just, you talk about your strategy focusing on Southern Africa and North America. Can you maybe just chat about how Uzbekistan puts into that? Maybe just give us an update as well on Uzbekistan as you've been pretty quiet on the result commentary on that? And just the second thing, just on the cost savings. I mean, we do see a bit of a moving target. Previously, you were talking about ZAR 3 billion and some upside to that and now ZAR 4 billion and further upside to that. In my understanding, it's a lot of upfront work and even the new operating structure is in place. So when will you have this confidence to actually give us a final number in terms of what that cost savings would be?

---

【回答: David Edward Constable (Executives)】
Sure. Thanks, Nishal, for the questions. I'll take Uzbekistan and maybe you can talk about how we plan to go forward on the Phoenix cost savings. As we talked about it in our presentation today, we've had a two-pronged dual regional strategy at the company focusing on Southern Africa and then North America and expanding the current business activities in Louisiana. Uzbekistan, UGTL is -- as you know, we are looking for another equity partner. We are taking our share from 44.5% down to 25.5%, and the joint venture is looking for another partner for that 19%. There's discussions ongoing as we speak and that potential is still there as a possibility. The feed package, all the technical aspects of the project are basically complete, the estimate's done. You have an EPC contractor ready to go, but it's a matter of finding this additional partner and also closing financing on the project. So that's where we are at on UGTL right now, and I think we'll probably have more to say about that later in the year and into -- probably later in the year, I would think. So that's where that stands. On cost savings and how that's coming along, we continue to see positive savings flowing through. Paul, how would you want to answer that?

---

【回答: Paul Victor (Executives)】
Nishal, we basically at half year indicated that at least ZAR 3 billion, and then we'll update the market once we get better confirmation. As you can appreciate, this project is a 3-year project, and as you move through the different stages of which not only management is one stage, these various projects that we are focusing at, that contributes to towards the ZAR 4 billion. We are currently now in the phase of confirming all the different process improvements and the changes required on the streams for productivity improvement, as well as the inbound supply chain. Those are big streams in the overall benefit delivery and, in a couple of months, we will get clear confirmation on that, and then we will -- that will put us in a position to communicate to the market. I think what you also have to bear in mind and I have stated it this morning, that there is some uncertainty with regards to electricity price increases going forward in South Africa, and we also want to kind of get a view on that and ascertain how  that will affect our savings plans before putting out a final number in the market. Surely the market can appreciate the step change to ZAR 4 billion, which we believe is a real stretch to the organization. But once you've got better clarity, we will definitely communicate further upside savings to the markets.

---

【回答: David Edward Constable (Executives)】
Thanks, Paul. Thanks, Nishal. Operator, we've got time for a couple of more questions.

---

【質問: Alex Comer (Analysts)】
A couple of quick questions, please. Was I right in understanding that you said there was going to be no compulsory retrenchments? I find that slightly surprising out of 34,000 people. Maybe you could explain how that works when you've indicated you're going to contract down the number of businesses and divisions that you've got, and what happens to people if they're job no longer exists within the new structure? That's the first question. Secondly, just perhaps you could elaborate on how some of your term contracts for the ethane cracker, what sort of shape they might take? And just to confirm one other thing. I think you said the dividend was ZAR 20.5 and then the tax, I think, is ZAR 21. So maybe you could just confirm -- sorry, ZAR 21.5, confirm what the dividend actually is?

---

【回答: David Edward Constable (Executives)】
Well we can clear that last thing up right now. I'm sorry, if we said 20.5, it is ZAR 21.50, up 13% on ZAR 19 last year. That's the -- we definitely want to get that correct. Let's talk about -- just to clarify for you, Alex. Just the work force transition process, a large part of our focus in work force transition has been in the staff, in the home offices and on the staffing side, managed primarily, like I said, the top 4 levels of the company is what we've been working on so far. We're now down into the GEC 4 levels, so that's 5 levels down and we're working on that now. So most of the retrenchments -- and again, we follow a voluntary retrenchment, voluntary early retirement and last line of defense, if you will, is forced retrenchments, which is what you're speaking to. We have not seen a lot of those yet and my comment was specific on no forced retrenchments, specific to our union labor employees. Based on the demographics of what we see here in South Africa with more than 2,500 of our union colleagues above the age of 55, we're going to see quite a bit of voluntary early retirements in that space and probably more than what we need to transition. So we need to be very careful from a retention standpoint to keep our colleagues gainfully employed where we need them to be employed. We're also going to be doing quite a bit of redeployment in the monthly salaried employees or the union colleagues. We'll be able to move them around into different parts of the business as well, where, as you know, we have a moratorium on hiring. We've frozen hiring since January of 2013. So the vacancies are still there, and we have quite a bit of attrition in the company that has been building up since we started Phoenix or since we started the enhancement program. So I think from that standpoint, the comment was specific to forced retrenchments at the union colleague level. So hopefully, that answers the question. Over on the term contracts for ethane, I think right now we've got 70% of our ethane requirements under term contracts. I'll ask Steve to give us a little more color on spot percentages and what's outstanding and left to be signed up on the term side, and also talk a little bit about transportation in the various pipelines we've got so that we can play the suppliers off and make sure we're getting the best deal for ourselves.

---

【回答: Stephen Cornell (Executives)】
Alex, we need about 100,000 barrels a day of ethane to supply the 1.5 million ton ethylene cracker. As David said, we have term contracts in place for 70,000 barrels of that. Those are 3- to 5-year terms and most of the contracts are tied to an OPIS price for ethane. A small amount is tied to, actually, a natural gas, Henry Hub posting. We do plan to put about 30% -- to get about 30% or 30,000 barrels a day on spot. And due to the liquidity of the market in the Gulf Coast, that gives us the ability to play the market and take advantage of the volatile nature of the market at times. And we have also contracted for storage capacity so that we can store some for both shutdowns and to take advantage of attractive pricing. And that transportation, we've got firm transportation to allow us to get the ethane all the way from Mont Belvieu over to the cracker. So I think we're in great shape in terms of both the transportation needs and, actually, the molecules themselves.

---

【質問: Alex Comer (Analysts)】
Can I -- sorry, could I just ask one further question? When you say it's tied to the OPIS price, you basically mean that it's pretty flexible then? It's not a fixed-price contract?

---

【回答: Stephen Cornell (Executives)】
That's correct. The majority of it is an OPIS price. It's not a fixed price.

---

【回答: David Edward Constable (Executives)】
Okay. I think we've got time for the last question, please, from, I think, Citi.

---

【質問: Johann Steyn (Analysts)】
Just a quick one on how you -- where you have the opportunities for U.S. GTL and Mozambican GTL? You seem to be pretty optimistic about the U.S., et cetera. I guess it will, in time, become either/or as you probably won't have the financial power to go for both. So how do you think about the timing of pushing either/or of these projects forward?

---

【回答: David Edward Constable (Executives)】
Great. Thanks, Johann. We, obviously, right now are focused on the U.S. GTL, which is in -- the furthest along as it's in FEEDs, front-end engineering design, right now with one of our main GTL contractors. And the way you can look at it and think about timing is we still expect to take a final investment decision on that U.S. GTL plant, call it, 96,000 barrels a day plus up to 10% additional capacity, 24 months after we take the cracker decision. So you can think about late 2016 before we take a U.S. GTL decision. And obviously, that will take into account the microeconomics at that time and the cost estimates and schedules that we'll be developing over this -- during the FEED phase. In addition to your Mozambique -- you've talked about the Mozambique GTL. You'll remember that we also have a feasibility study completed on our Canada GTL. So it also features in this mix. It also has good economics and is in the pipeline to be considered in the early part of the next decade. So I think as we get later into the decade and we start seeing what the pre-feasibility study in Mozambique looks like with our partners over there, plus with the government and with Eni, we'll take a look at that and go through our prioritization process, look at the rolling capital plan. And as you say, we'll have to carefully consider our gearing and our CapEx requirements and the buffer for volatility and our progressive dividend, which we continue to focus on and take decisions on all the GTL opportunities later in the decade. So I think that's how you should look at it, in that order. And with that, I want to thank everyone for joining us today and I look forward to visiting with many or most of you during our upcoming investor and analyst roadshows over the next few weeks. 
So thanks again, and we'll see you soon.

B0L6750.eventHeadline: Sanlam Limited, H1 2014 Earnings Call, Sep 04, 2014
B0L6750.transcript_text1:
Welcome to our interim results presentation. As has become customary, we do it here in Johannesburg. More interest, more money here in Johannesburg. 
Before we start with the presentation, I'd like to welcome a few people specifically. First, some board members. Chairman Desmond Smith; Philip Rademeyer; Paul Bradshaw, one of our directors from the U.K.; Kobus Möller, our Financial Director, who will talk about the financials just now; Yegs Ramiah; Ian Kirk; Themba Gamedze; Yaganthrie Ramiah; Andre Zeeman, who will do the actuarial questions later on, help us with that; some of our business people; and then a whole lot of our analysts and others who support us. Welcome. It's our pleasure to share with you another set of 6 months results. 
The agenda is straightforward. We will start off with talking a little bit about the economy, the operating environment, what is happening and how it's impacting us. Talk about our strategy in Sanlam, how we're trying to run the business to take advantage out of the markets. Kobus Möller, the Financial Director, will come and give us the financial review, and I will end off with a few points on what we're going to concentrate on for the rest of year, what the outlook is and so forth. 
Starting off with the operating environment. I think the overriding thing that we see is the fundamentals, and particularly our major market, South Africa, are weak. So if we really look at things, it is challenging operating conditions, slow growth in global demand, weak economic growth in South Africa combined with industrial action over the past 6 months, and particularly the platinum mines that hurt us, and by and large and increasingly, we see the South African consumer being under pressure. 
In the South African economy, we will have a few slides to show how we're doing and with respect to growth, interest rates, equity markets and currencies, and we'll also remark briefly on what is happening elsewhere in the economy. But if you really look at growth, you can see that growth is not going back to the levels that we've seen sort of 10 years ago, 8, 10 years ago, but we're sort of plodding along at around 2% and a bit -- a little bit below that. And that is not great. It isn't when you talk to -- particularly the investors from the U.S. and Europe, they're worried about it. And as we can see, there's a lot of pressure in our own economy. 
If we look at interest rates, we can see the long-term rate, the 9-year bond rate that we use, by and large, to value our business. You can see that has gone up by about 70 basis points. And of course, because we use that as the discount rate, it had a negative effect on the value of new business to the tune of about 4%, so -- but we were under pressure with the volumes as well. The new business margin went down a little bit because of the higher discount rate. The short-term rate sort of very much the same, if we compared it to the 2 halves from 2013 to now. 
If we look at the bond -- the equity market, it's done pretty well. And because we get the equities, the higher levels actually caused particular investment businesses to do substantially better. You can see the markets were about 11% higher and that has made a big impact for us on the bond market, the returns were 3.4%, which is also substantially better than the previous period. So overall, if we look at the market, a positive effect on our results. 
Similarly with the exchange rate. The exchange rate has weakened quite a bit and that has had positive effects from the income that we've seen, particularly from Europe -- European operations and the U.K., we see that on a period -- of the 2 periods that we're comparing, exchange rate weakened by 26% so of course, the result from the U.K. would be higher. You see the U.S. rate there, Botswana also positively impacted. India and the Rest of Africa, particularly because of what's happening in Ghana, the effect is fairly neutral. But overall, you can see a 5% better result coming from exchange rate movements. New business volumes a 2% effect, on the value of new business a 1% positive effect. 
So the economy. If we look at the economy in more detail, one of our bigger operations in Botswana, I think we're -- results were bolstered by a fairly resilient economy and a consumer base that is on the up. They've struggled for 1 year or 2 years, but I think the economy is well managed and they're doing well. If you look at the Rest of Africa, the GDB growth prospects exceed  South Africa despite slow global -- slow growth in global demand. The Ghana economy is struggling, particularly because of high inflation, devaluation of the currency and so forth. High growth rate, but once you look at the real rates, it is a bit under pressure. In India, we've had a below-trend economic growth, but I think a very buoyant equity market with Modi winning the elections there, being very pro-business, a lot of that has flowed through into the equity markets. And these markets have done extremely well, not only stopping at half year end, 30th of June, but running well into August and even now into September. And in Malaysia, I think the growth prospects remain in place. The economy is doing fairly well. The ringgit is holding up well as a currency. And particularly at that lower end of the market where we're playing, we see a quite substantial growth. So overall, things are fairly positive. 
So from the economy, tough in South Africa, more positive signs elsewhere. Currency helping us, high markets helping us, higher interest rates, particularly in the long term impacting negatively on our results. Within this framework, if you look out a little bit about what our strategy is, nothing much has remained. We'd still focus on returns being the major driver and measurement of our success; return on group embedded value, as we measure it; big focus on the growth component, trying to maintain South Africa; get positive growth from pockets where there is still money to be made, but then trying to get into the higher growth areas offshore into Africa, India, Southeast Asia and also the developed markets in the U.K. in particular, trying to drive new business flows, diversification, operational efficiency. 
Again, the second pillar of our strategy is around capital efficiency. We were able to do quite a bit around that. And going into SAM, I think we're well placed to sort of capitalize on 1 or 2 opportunities that has become available. 
So if you look at the core strategy, about 75%, 80% of our business in South Africa. It's key that we get that to work. We look at lower growth but really focus on sustainability within the businesses. It's much more focused on efficiency and so forth, really getting the returns up, trying to do more with clients and so not trying to add a massive number of new businesses, but trying to do more with clients and so forth. And then through the mechanism of capital management, trying to build a future for us into the higher growth areas, particularly the African markets, the Anglophone African markets, the lower end of the market in India, Southeast Asia, Malaysia and others. 
And also at the high end of the market, trying to capitalize into the opportunities that we see for our clients into places like the U.K, diversifying portfolios and so forth. And by putting all of that together, you get sort of a blended growth. In South Africa, much more stable type of an environment, giving us 12, 13 sort of a percent. Offshore, higher growth, 30% and higher. Lower penetration, less competition. And by putting those 2 things together, you can get to around 16%, 17% in the shorter term. In the longer term, around 15%, which is what we're trying to achieve. So trying to get to around 10% sort of double-digit real growth into the future. 
If you look at the actual results, I think some of the highlights there, the -- certainly, in my mind, the major highlight is the net operating profit per share that increased by 43%. Now that's off the back of most of the businesses working well. Kobus will talk about that a bit later. Santam coming back to the party, having had a difficult year in 2013. They've done pretty well this year. The higher asset base helping Sanlam Investments. Personal individual business, Sanlam Personal Finance, doing very well, and I think a particularly good performance from our Emerging Markets business. We did buy some new businesses, but even when you strip that out, 36% growth in the net operating profit x acquisitions, so a very, very solid base going forward. 
If you look at business volumes, we can see some of the pressure coming through. New business volumes increased by 8% to ZAR 82 billion. That's excluding white label. Our net fund flows were ZAR 19 billion. It's up 40%. We are able to retain more money within the business. Net life value of new business, 7% up to ZAR 600-odd million. I'll talk to 1 or 2 areas where we struggled a little bit and Kobus will show you, coming from the strikes and so forth. Since normalization there, we're sort of back to normal. But the higher discount rate set -- knocked that number by about 4%. 
Our net value of new business margin around 2.68.  On most of the products, we've been able to maintain our margin, but our mix hurt us a little bit. And the Group Equity Value of ZAR 42.77 per share. Remember, we pay dividends once a year. The dividend got paid this year, so it's tough to grow the Group Equity Value during the first half. Most of the growth comes in the second half. 
And if we really look at the annualized return on group embedded value, actual number around 18% against a target that is substantially lower, just above 12%. But on an adjusted basis, if you normalize for the markets that's done particularly well, we're at that level of about 15% that we would like to be at. So plan -- everything is sort of going, by and large, according to plan. 
If you really look at the operational efficiencies, the growth stays intact. We've been able to take Sanlam from a fairly stagnant business, not growing, to a business where the value of new business is now at least expected to be well over ZAR 1 billion on an annualized basis. For the half year, we've done pretty well. You can see how particularly the Emerging Markets have done well, and you can also see the majority coming through in the South African base and the strikes hindering us in the growth area, the lower end of the market in South Africa really putting some lid on the South African growth. But most of the businesses outside of the country growing fairly well. 
If we look at persistency, we're very happy that the persistency is still well within the assumption base. But as the consumer is under pressure, and particularly in the platinum area and a few things, we see the lapses, surrenders and fully paid-ups ticking up slightly. Of course, you have to take into account that the environment in which we operate from a regulatory perspective makes it much easier to churn business, makes it much easier to lapse it in the sense that the costs of lapses are lower. We're not recuperating things as we used to in the past. It's relatively easier to do that. A big part of our lapse base, the Section 14 transfers, regulatory transfers, weren't there 4, 5 years ago and in spite of that, we still run at relatively low numbers in the middle market. So we're very happy with the [indiscernible] and the trend, we think, is fairly healthy. And in spite of all regulatory issues and all sorts of pressures, the core of what we do in our middle-market book, very healthy and doing extremely well. 
If we look at the lower end of the market, Sanlam's Sky business, you can really see how we were able to manage it down to our target of around 10%. And then we can see the latter part of 2013 with some of the industrial action coming through and particularly in 2014, an uptick there. Now virtually all of that comes from the consumer being under pressure and particularly in the Rustenburg area. 
To give you an indication, we sell about -- in this market segment, we sell about 10% of our policies in the platinum belt. And of course, if you can't really get going and sell -- for 3 months, people were striking there, they didn't have income, you would expect those numbers to be quite higher. We've put in special measures there to run that, but overall, I think, still a healthy result, given the composition -- where we're at in the country 
One of our key measures and how we -- the shop window into a contractual savings business like ourself is really investment performance. We're very happy to say both on a 3-year basis and a 5-year basis, we -- more than 90% of our mandates, we've been performing at or better than the benchmark, which is really what we've been aiming for and very stellar performance there. Particularly, we have fixed benchmarks, not the variable benchmark, but fixed benchmarks that you would expect in a life company that you would like to, on an asset liability matching type of a mandate, we've been doing extremely well. So on our big Sanlam book in particular, we're fairly happy with the results over there. I think Herd Kreyvocken [ph] and the team on the investment side has done particularly well here. 
Then as become usual, we talk about our operational efficiencies and positive experience variances. Again, coming from a number of sources, particularly on the risk side, again, close to about ZAR 500 million for the half year as opposed to the other numbers for the full year. You can see, as a percentage of our book, it is in that range of between 3% and 4% that we've been guiding the market and so again, the book performing particularly well. And if you put all of this together, it has really resulted in a return that is substantially higher than what we would like it to be. 
So if you really look at what has been doing, a big part of the strategy is on the diversification side. On the business component, on the left-hand side on the slide, you can see the Group Equity Value. About half of our business is life, then a much better distribution than what we've had in the past between general insurance, investment management, credit and banking, and admin health and then surplus money. If you look at the profit on the right, you can really see which are the most profitable businesses in terms of the component of the value. But much more diversified than what it used to be, and that is why we can also stomach a bit of the difficulties that we see in the economy. 
On the diversification side, in terms of countries, you see still the South African base, around 75% of our activity and profits and investments come from there, with about 25% of our investments mainly into Anglophone Africa, India, Malaysia, the old colonies, the lower end of the market where we have a differential advantage, in many cases a first mover advantage as well, barriers to entry to the big players from overseas who come with very expensive systems, try to penetrate the high end of the market and from there, go to the lower end. Very difficult to do that. I think we have a clear differential advantage in most of these as a first mover. And then on the high end of the market also, mainly in the U.K., having a base where we offer optionality and where we have systems where we can invest in the U.S. and Australia and in several other places. So working fairly well across that international positioning. 
If you look at the diversification a bit further, in 2003, sort of 10 years ago, about close to being 100% South African business with a little bit in Namibia. If you look to the right, about half of what we achieved now in terms of the value of new business on the life side, really coming from areas that we didn't play in. And even within the traditional South African market, quite a bit of new business and innovation taking place. So overall, you get the idea that it's much more diverse and so forth. 
And if you look at the profit, you can clearly see the growth. The circle becoming bigger as we move to the right. And also new components, not all of it coming from a particular business. And even within that, we have credit, we have life, we have savings, we have investments, we have short-term insurance, we have a whole range of businesses, administration and so forth, much more than what we used to have. So the growth comes with much more diversification and, I think, much more resilience. 
Just a picture to show you as we're moving forward, how we're diversifying the base between South Africa; our emerging markets businesses in Africa, India and Malaysia; and in the U.K. The investments there, the value and the profit. Overall, you can see that trend increasing. More of our business is showing -- is being in the high-growth areas. 
Just a few slides on capital efficiency. The final SAM specifications are expected towards the end of the year. We'll be running a sort of a high-level dual process with the new risk-based system and with the old capital system to really see how that will impact us for the rest of the year. The SAM QIS3 results indicate that we have sufficient capital in our life operations and with the level of the markets, in particular. Of course, if markets adjust, we always have to look at those kinds of things. But for the moment, I think we are well-capitalized. We have ZAR 1.8 billion of investments in growth opportunities that we finalized in the first half of the year. We'll talk about 1 or 2 of them just now. And at the end of the 6 months, we had ZAR 3.3 billion earmarked for investment in growth opportunities. We'll come to that particular number and here it is. 
So we started the year with ZAR 4 billion, we did investments of around ZAR 1.7 billion, we've added surplus capital of around ZAR 1 billion that gets us to end off with about ZAR 3.3 billion. And you can see there in Southeast Asia and Malaysia, we did the MCIS transaction, the Zurich transaction where we bought their stake in MCIS, a life business in Malaysia, for ZAR 1.2 billion. 
In Rwanda, we acquired a controlling stake in the biggest insurance and finan --  one of the biggest financial services businesses there. In Botswana, we've bought back some shares of ours. We're up to close to 59% holding now in BIHL. In the Rest of Africa, we spend around ZAR 80 million. From the co-investment strategy with Santam, we realized a net ZAR 43 million that they paid. We bought their stake in Namibia, they bought our stakes or 35% of our stake to get tied into India and some of the other businesses. So we're the net recipient of ZAR 43 million. In the developed markets of the U.K., we spent ZAR 25 million, mainly in FOUR Capital, buying an additional share from our partners over there. In South Africa, we spent about ZAR 90 million. 
So overall, you get the picture. We're continuously pushing on the capital and we have a pipeline available for -- in fact, pipeline that's slightly bigger than the ZAR 3.3 billion that we have over the next year or so that we will work. 
With those few comments, I would like Kobus to come and address you on the specifics of the financial review. Kobus, over to you.

---

Thank you, Johan. Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. It's a pleasure to share with you some of the features of our results for the 6 months. 
Just to start with just a comment on our presentation or the assumptions underlying the presentations. There were no changes in accounting policies fortunately for the 6 months period. Just some minor changes in the allocation of some of the investment businesses -- or some of the businesses within our investment cluster, but those are fairly minor. And then, as Johan indicated, we have seen an increase in the rates at which we discount some of our future cash flows, that had a negative impact on some of our valuations, but also on the value of the new life business and it had a negative impact of around 4% on the growth in the VNB and also margin -- marginally on the actual average margin that we've achieved on value of new business. 
Salient features, you've seen most of this. 18% return on Group Equity Value, which is well in excess of our internal target of just more than 12% for the period and on an adjusted basis, 15.3%. Those are annualized numbers and then some on life because [ph] business within the group remains well capitalized at 4.4x instead [ph] of regulatory capital requirement. Good growth in our operating profits and I'll show you some more detail on that in a while, and then business flows up 8%, and ZAR 5.5 billion increase in the net new flows that we've achieved across the business. 
The next few slides will deal with some of individual clusters -- business clusters in the group, starting with Sanlam Personal Finance. Overall, good new business flows into that cluster, but you will see that in Sanlam Sky, our business at the lower end of the market, we have seen a 6% drop in overall new business flows. It's a combination of 33% drop in group business, where we write scheme -- small schemes. Those are bulky businesses and we didn't have the same level of inflows last year. 
The individual life business is up by 6%. That's also lower than our normal expectation would be. Big reason there is the impact that the strikes in Rustenburg in the platinum belt had on our business. If you exclude that, the growth is more than 10%, which is slightly better performance than individual life. That's both life business and investment business in the middle market, up 8%. 
You see it [indiscernible] are very strong single premium business there, but on the recurring premium, we see the impact of the economy as well in our recurring business, in particular on the risk side, we didn't have good growth in recurring premium business. 
Glacier had another good 6 months in terms of new flows, both Investment business and the life insurance business, we're particularly seeing some very good flows on to the investment platform of Glacier. Thank you, Kobus. Ladies and gentlemen, let me, for the moment, stand still with a few of the priorities that we have for the year that is left. In our Personal Finance business, that's our individual business in South Africa, there will  be a big focus on sales growth and to maintain the margins in the country. So we have some plans to grow adviser force in all the market segments. We fell a bit behind. We're catching up fairly quickly, particularly in the light [ph] of the strikes and so forth it would have been, I think, shortsighted to grow unfettered. But we're picking up there. 
We're really focusing on product innovation. We've launched a number of new recurring premium products. Our market share is substantially low. 
If you look at the savings space, our market share is around 18%, 20%. If we look at the recurring premium products, though, our market share is closer to 10%. And I think there is substantial scope to pick up on that, so we come with a whole range of new products and that seems to gain traction in the market. 
And then in Sanlam Sky particularly, our brokers are struggling. We have a whole range of measures there. Very happy to report, I think in August, it seems that we're already sort of back on track and things are looking well. Focus will be to continue at those levels for the rest of the year. 
Persistency is an issue. We essentially, as a life insurance business, make more money from keeping existing good business on the books rather than writing new business. And therefore, as much as new business is important, it's also important to keep the existing business on the books. So we have a number of measures to get persistency up. Where we do write new business, we really focus on quality. And that focus there, particularly in tough times, is what we think creates some differentiation between us and some of our competitors and there will be a substantial increase on that focus. 
Efficiency. We're driving that hard. We have a history, and I think people ask me what is our core competency in Sanlam? I've said that in the past. A big part of that, particularly in our life book, is the management of costs. And in area -- in times when inflation puts pressure on that, it is critically important that we keep on driving the efficiency. We have quite a few plans there to manage our costs down, not only this year but over the next 2, 3 years, and we have to drive those things a bit forward. 
The transformation and employer of choice issue. Increasingly, our client base is changing. We're trying to change the composition also of our staff to reflect those changes and we're making some progress there on the B scorecard. We're a level 2 provider. There is scope to increase, particularly in the employment equity space and we have some plans there. Yesterday at the board, we also discussed the plan. We will be making additional investments into the space. 
And then the issue in South Africa of regulatory change. I think we've been talking a lot over the past 4, 5 years about changes coming to the fore. I think the time has now come as we're starting to implement them. A big part of that is on the regulatory capital side, the SAM project, where we're now starting to go live on a parallel run. The  QIS3 results are coming out. We have a much better idea of where we are. And by year end we'll have, I think, quite a good feel for how we -- our capital stack up and what can be done and what the future holds with respect to that. We've seen pension fund reform being driven. We think a lot of those things are imminent. Treating customers fairly is coming. We've made substantial progress. I think we're fairly happy with the position that we're in at this moment in time, not only in absolute terms but also relative to our competitors. I think we will set there. And then 1 or 2 missing pieces and particularly the RDR, the retail distribution review, which will have some impact to the way we sell our products, the way we see independents and tied agents and advisors and how that will pan out going forward. The relationships around conflict of interest in that space. I think there will be much more clarity as we move forward. And then the long anticipated move. We've had the Red Book strategy from government coming in 2011, moving to a Twin Peaks sort of a regulatory system with prudential regulation going to the reserve bank, not only of banks but also of insurers and investment managers. And then with market conduct regulation going to the FSB, we expect that legislation shortly, with sort of implementation by April of next year. I don't want to say 1st of April, but maybe 1st of April, and we'll see what that holds. 
So overall, the big market, a few changes. In our emerging markets space, we've seen tremendous growth. You would have seen what's been happening. We've been buying businesses. Businesses have been growing organically and so forth. 
Our focus remains on Africa and then lower end of the markets in India and Southeast Asia, particularly Malaysia. We would like to continue our focus on top line growth, the efficiencies that we drive in the business, getting those businesses on board, and capital optimization in the current operations. Many of the businesses that we bought were relatively small, over-capitalized and as we make them bigger and grow them, we utilize that capital better, the integration, we optimize reinsurance arrangements and a whole range of things that we can do over the short term to drive up the returns. We would like to bed down the new acquisitions in Rwanda and Malaysia. 
And Shriram Capital, the holding company, lots of synergies still between the different components of the Shriram Life business, Shriram General, the truck financing, Shriram truck financing, transport financing business, and then also with the retail operation, the financing in retail. Lots of stuff that we can do between these businesses. Already, the cross-selling is increasing quite substantially, but there's much more work that we can do to drive those businesses forward. 
On IT, we have quite a few changes. We have one set for Namibia. We've implemented Project Mara [ph]. It's not in Kenya. And it's bedding down these things and with support from South Africa, I think we're doing fairly well. 
A key part of what we're trying to do here is do some additional transactions and deepening the existing relationships of partnerships in Africa, India and Malaysia. In Africa in particular, I think we've spoken in the past that we don't have General Insurance operations in Kenya, a big market that we're playing in. We don't have one in Ghana. There are some opportunities with partners and others to do something in those spaces. And across the board in Africa, we have some missing building blocks that we need to put in place. In India in particular, I think it's imminent now the restriction of the 26% FDI limit, foreign direct investment limit in insurance. There's been several discussions. It's been referred. Our understanding is that there will be a joint sitting of the Lower and the Higher House later in the year to address this issue and to get it to a vote. It's being supported by the majority party there and they have the majority in parliament to get these things through. And our expectation is that it will happen.  So we've earmarked the ZAR 550 million to increase our stake from 26% in the Life Insurance and General Insurance businesses from 26% to 49%. And then in Malaysia, there's a whole lot of space and additional things around the takaful, integrating our businesses and so forth. 
We'd like to remain the leading player in Africa. We have 1 or 2 additional things that we're working on. We continuously refine the organizational capacity to support growth. It is impossible to find the talent in each of the countries, so a lot of the support to the countries come from South Africa where we do have, I think, key businesses to pull some people out, not permanently but to address particular issues. So we're working on that. 
And then the whole focus on trying to get governance, ethics, values aligned with what we do here in Sanlam is a major drive. 
So there's quite a bit of work to be done to move, essentially, from where we're an investment holding company in many of these businesses to really make them an integral part and parcel of what we're about in Sanlam. So that's the major focus of the emerging markets. 
If we look at the investment space, key, of course, as an investment business, is investment performance. And because the performance has been fairly good, it's really about maintaining that consistent upper-quartile investment performance to really, at least, outperform the mandates over the vast bulk of those mandates. And I think we have a good track record there and we'd like to maintain that. 
We'd like to grow our market share in the higher-margin areas, particularly on the retail funds flows. I think that is coming through working better with Sanlam, getting the Sanlam money, and we're getting the Sanlam relationships to work. Sort of a project that we have is Sanlam for Sanlam. But then also driving the institutional fund flows. I think that's an area where we're a bit light. Our market share is not where it should be, but some good plans, and we have to start implementing those and getting results. 
I think a very positive part of our business, you would have seen the nice growth in the value of new business coming from EB. This is the more recurring nature and type of business. But on the large mandates side, these ZAR 10 billion, ZAR 5 billion type things, where we've been missing some of them in the past. There is quite a nice pipeline and indications are that in the next 6 months, we'll be able to land 1 or 2 of those things. And if we can do that, it will have a substantial change because these things produce value of new business of -- in excess of ZAR 100 million for one particular client on a particular day. So that, we hope, by bringing 1 or 2 of those on board, we can affect the one area, I think, where we were a bit light on the results. The value of new business, we can set that straight. So we are really looking at the EB pipeline and I'm fairly positive that we can do something there. 
Then it's all about cost-effective solutions to clients from across the Sanlam Investment value chain. I think we're making progress there as well, using the South African base, where people want to go offshore, use those opportunities and getting it right. We're doing well there. 
Active and passive. You know that we bought all of the minorities in Satrix. It is really refocusing that business, getting more money into that, that seems to be working on the passive management capabilities, but without detracting on what we're doing on the active side. So overall, driving that. The African investments proposition is doing well. We have a few African funds, an African property fund, an African debt fund that's been launched recently. Those things are doing well. And then across the businesses to work better together, not to fight inside as much but to collaborate inside and to work on the outside. 
At Santam, we've turned the corner there. We're doing pretty well, but we have to deliver on the diversified growth, the market diversification. We have a whole range of these things, partnering into Africa, India and so forth, the specialist business, Santam Re and so. 
Continued growth at MiWay, which is critical. You  only get it at that level with investment and advertisements and these kinds of things, but we're on track. I think it's a solid business now with relatively low claims ratios on the motor side. 
Our quality of the risk pool is critically important. I think we've done a great job of moving our risk profile down, moving away particularly from climate-type risk, flooding and areas like that, where we've either adjusted the rates or withdrawn from those things completely. But there's still a lot to do on the unprofitable accounts. People who target for things to be carried away and for theft seems to be recurring targets, so we have to really do a lot to rectify our unprofitable accounts. 
We have to drive efficiencies through the value chain. Cost management key in this thing with dropping of the rand vis-a-vis the other currencies as we get motor parts in. We have to look at other solutions to really provide a better service at lower cost. And then the key strategic projects in the Commercial and Personal lines really driving it and the key of them being underwriting. I think we' will set.
Overall ladies and gentlemen, I think the next 6 months will be tough. We won't get to a 44% increase, as Kobus has told you, in operational profit, but we will set, I think, to continue the trend going forward. 
In terms of the outlook, we think we'll see increased pressure from the -- particularly on the retail side. Some market volatility probable, increasingly a bigger probability. We've seen a lot of money has been invested into equities. Market levels are high. But you have to ask yourself: Where else do you put the money? The returns on the other kinds of alternatives to equities are relatively low, even just relative to dividend yields, so you have to weigh these up. But it does -- if you're rational, there should be some increased market volatility, particularly in the equity space. 
We have a few new acquisitions that we've done. We have to bed them down. We have a few in the pipeline, we have to finalize those, and I think 1 or 2 that can make a big difference. And then the issue around the compliance, the regulatory change in the areas that we've mentioned. They are important. To think that regulatory change will go away, I think, is a bit of a fallacy. In our business, you have to be able to deal with change. However, what I do think is we're trying too many things at the same time. It's impossible in a business to try and do 40, 50 things at the same time. We usually focus on 3, 4 major things and so forth. We're trying to work with the regulators and trying to get a bit more focused to look at the big things that can get 80% of the benefit rather than trying to do everything so that we'd quickly fall into sort of a tick-the-box sort of a strategy. 
So overall, I think tough conditions, a few challenges, but we're on track, ladies and gentlemen. We are on track. We've been there for a while. No surprises, really. I think the market is a bit tougher. It shows in the results and the new business. But we're managing it well. It shows in the profit and the way we're coming through. We're much more diversified. We have some resilience. And overall, I think as a business and as a management, we're certainly happy. Been with the business now a long time. It's my 12th year. And a lot of what we've been trying is now coming through. There's still substantial upside looking into the next year or 2. 
And with that, we'd like to take a few questions. Can I ask Andre Zeeman, our Chief Actuary, and Kobus Möller to join me here in the softer chairs for some questions?

Those things are doing well. And then across the businesses to work better together, not to fight inside as much but to collaborate inside and to work on the outside.

Okay. Thank you, operator, and good morning, everyone. I'm sorry, my voice is a little hoarse because we're in an allergy season and this is where I fit.
This morning, we reported our financial and operating results for the second quarter of fiscal year 2015. We are very pleased with these results. You can see that our customers continue to respond favorably to our merchandising strategy to increase same-store sales and our store expansion program continues to fuel the growth of our business across Canada.
I'll let Michael provide you with the details relating to our financial results and our operating initiatives for the quarter. From my perspective, this quarter was defined by the continued organic growth through the  opening of new stores across Canada, as well as the continued uptake of the higher price point merchandise.
In terms of new stores, we opened 89 net new stores over the past 12 months compared to 93 net new stores in the same period last year, thereby increasing our total store count to 917 stores compared to 828 stores at the end of Q2 last year.
During the second quarter of this year, we opened 18 net new stores compared to 22 in the same period last year. Given the pace of new store openings in the first half of the fiscal year, we're now on track to open 70 to 80 stores in fiscal 2015. New stores are being opened at high-quality retail locations across Canada, with most of the new stores located in Ontario and Western Canada, which are markets that continue to be under-penetrated with dollar stores. We continue to focus our efforts on densifying core urban centers in these markets.
From a merchandising point of view, sales of $2.50 and $3 price point items continue to grow. Our customers have been responding positively to the value offered by these products. We believe that these higher price points compliment the lower priced items, provide a more value-added basket to the customer.
Overall, we're very satisfied with our current price/mix as it continues to stimulate sales and attract customers into our stores.
Let me now turn the call over to Michael.

---

Thank you, Larry, and good morning, everyone. So during the second quarter, we increased our sales by 12% to $572.6 million from $511.3 million in the prior year. The increase in sales was fueled by the opening of 89 net new stores over the past 12 months and a same-store sales increase of 4.2% over and above a 6.2% increase reported in the prior year. The same-store sales increase in Q2 consisted of a 3.1% increase in basket size, which reflects the consumer demand for our higher price point items and a 1.1% increase in the number of transactions.
In this second quarter, our gross margin was 36.1% of sales compared to 36.6% of sales in Q2 last year. This decrease is partly attributable to slightly lower product margins as we absorb some of the cost increases in order to maintain the compelling value of our products. As we stated earlier this year, we have been managing our gross margin by continually reinvesting in the value proposition offered to our customers. We expect this trend to continue as we target a range between 36% and 37% in fiscal 2015 in order to stimulate continued sales growth.
Our Q2 SG&A as a percentage of sales was 17.1% compared to 17.9% last year. This positive progression is the result of improved labor productivity achieved through initiatives implemented at store level, including improved labor scheduling and reduction of the number of manual inventory counts. These labor productivity initiatives will help offset the impact of the 7.3% minimum wage increase in Ontario that was enacted on June 1, 2014.
We expect the SG&A to be between 17.1% and 17.5% for the full fiscal -- 2015 fiscal year.
Our depreciation and amortization expense decreased by $2 million this quarter, as a result of the change in estimated useful life of our leasehold improvements, and our store and warehouse equipment as reported in the last quarter. Q2 net earnings increased to $68.9 million or $1.03 per diluted share as compared to $59.8 million or $0.82 per diluted share in the second quarter of fiscal 2014. 
Cash flows from operations increased to $107 million in Q2 F '15 from $98 million in Q2 F '14. This increase reflects improvement in financial results in the quarter. As previously reported, in the month of May, we modified our capital structure by issuing floating rate senior unsecured notes in the amount of $150 million maturing in May 2017, taking advantage of low variable rate opportunities available on the bond market. The proceeds have been used to repay indebtedness outstanding under our revolving credit facility.
Concurrently, with the issuance of these notes, we reduced the aggregate amount available under our revolving credit facility from $350 million to $250 million in order to reduce standby fees payable on the unutilized portion.
During the quarter, we also repurchased for cancellation, 1,394,040 shares under our normal course issuer bid, which was renewed in June 2014 for another 12-month period for a consideration of $126.9 million at a weighted average price of $91.04 per common share. We also announced today that Dollarama's board has approved a 2-for-1 share split by way of share dividend payable on November 17, 2014.
Dollarama is undertaking the share split to ensure that its common shares remain accessible to individual shareholders to increase and broaden its shareholder base and to improve market liquidity for its common shares.
In terms of our productivity initiatives, we continue to leverage off the benefits of several initiatives rolled out in the stores over the past year, including the reduction in the number of manual paid accounts at store level as we increase our reliance on the scan data for replenishment purposes and the productivity benefits of Kronos, which is used to manage time and attendance, as well as advanced labor scheduling in our stores and warehouses.
As mentioned in the past, Dollarama's continuously working to improve the efficiency and productivity in stores by making increased use of technology and eliminating non-value-added tax.
Overall, we are very pleased with the performance of the company this quarter and the progress made on our key initiatives that will support profitable growth in the future.
This ends our formal remarks. And we can now take questions. So operator, I'll turn the call over to you.

Right, well, the -- as you noticed, we were able to explain, clearly, the traffic in Q4 and Q1, which was related to the weather conditions and so that in Q2, the weather impact that we have back in Q4 and Q1 don't exist, didn't exist in Q2. ---

---

---

Well, it's Larry, Perry. I think the opportunities are similar to what they have been, we had to adjust. And -- but as far as the real estate themselves, it's available. It's available. From an expense point of view, it's similar to about a year ago. We have a lot of renewals now. ---

And do you feel, Larry, that you'll have to make any alterations to your format or your operations as those opportunities change or as rents increase?

---

Not yet, Perry. I can't predict the future. I'm no good at that. But I can -- let's put it this way. For this year and next year, the balance of this year and next year, that is not the case. If you want me to predict further into time, I can't do that.

---

---

That's great. So in terms of, let's say, the item count, items priced above $1, that hasn't really changed much?

---

No, well, the percentage -- no, it hasn't changed much and the percentage is in sales dollars but for the rest, everything remains equal, if you want.

---

That's great. And I guess we've now had a couple of years of benefit of those -- of the items priced at the $2.50 and $3 price point. Yes, I think Michael has it there.

And I would agree with that. I don't see it in the future. I -- again, don't want to predict the future but I don't see it in the near future and at all, David, not at all.

Profitable.

---

Profitable as the format we have today, and anything [ph] . So my answer is right now, I'm happy where we are. And I don't know what's going to happen in 5 years.

Nor do we.

---

I know that.

Eventually, we'll have to catch up, but we are very sensitive to that area of our business. And if we can control it, as well as we have been, that would be most satisfactory. ---

Okay, got it. In terms of the 36% to 37% gross margin rate that you've given to us, just given some challenges that you highlighted: FX; tariffs, I know you're dealing with that; competitive pressures and perhaps some challenges that you might not foresee at this period of time, is that a hard stop kind of rate that you would try to work towards or are there periods where you could go below that for a period of time, knowing that eventually you could work yourself out of that. Just wondering your thought on that.

---

I think ideally, we'd like to stay within that range. That's what we're aiming for and you're right, we do have all those challenges and by the way, the tariff and the currency we're on the same level of playing field as the other. So it's a matter of balancing that compelling value if you want, but the idea is to stay within that range.

---

I was just wondering if you could speak a bit about the apparel section of the stores. Is that a section that could be expanded, or do you think it's about where it should be?

---

If anything, it would go the other way. That's a difficult -- we'll call, we'll use your terminology, and say section. It's difficult because there's sizes, there's colors, there's fashion and we threw in modest offerings in the last year or 2. And we've -- again, this is an area that we don't want to expand. Our fixturing is not conducive to it. And if anything, it would go the -- it would contract, it would not expand.

---

And then something like the over-the-counter drugs, I'm not exactly sure what you can offer and what you can't offer. But I think I've seen things like Aspirin, I believe, in your store. If not your store, your competitor's store. But how -- what are the limitations on that category?

---

Every -- it's Neil, Keith. Every province has its own legislation, and so it's a province-by-province discussion as to which over-the-counter drugs are allowed to be sold, but as a category, it's a very small category for us. And we have no intention of growing the category. We offer a limited range of the most consumed, let's say, over-the-counter drugs, and we have no intention of growing it because the sales fall very far off, after the top sellers.

---

And then just in terms of the health and beauty assortment, you mentioned the -- some of the big brands are paying more attention to the dollar store channel. Would you see maybe going to more national brands in your health and beauty sort of section?

---

I think we'll take the same approach we have always taken with national brands, which is because they come at a lower markup at all times, we will continue to sprinkle national brands into our imports. But at a very slow pace and just enough to offer a balanced mix.

---

Yes, no intention of going there.

---

And then I guess a bit out of left field, would you look at the Internet as an Internet offering?

---

Keith, it's Michael. This will be the last question because we still have other analysts to go, sorry. So if you could repeat that question, Keith?

---

I was just wondering whether there's any consideration of going to the Internet?

---

No.

---

I agree with Michael.

---

I just had a very high-level question at this time. You've had a couple of quarters recently where you've gotten off to a slow start recently and it's typically due to inclement weather. So I really just have two minor questions, maybe one for Neil and then one for Michael. One, was there a notable expansion in your back-to-school offering this year? And then second, Michael, I don't expect you go into much detail, but the late August, early September time frame seemed very busy in the store and I just wonder if it's fair to say the start to this quarter might be a bit more encouraging?

---

So I'll answer the first question. The first question can be answered rather easily. The assortment has never changed. What we have done is we've made a bigger effort at store level and in store operations to put a better showing of our current and everyday offering on the front end and do a better job of merchandising it. And so it would be to the customer a new look and a new push, although the offering didn't change whatsoever.

---

Seems to work well.

---

Okay, and for the second part, Brian. I can't, obviously, disclose too much, but what I did say earlier is that to-date Q3, nothing unusual. Weather is certainly not a factor as it was in Q4 and Q1. For Q3 at least as of today, and we're just in the beginning of the quarter. We've got Halloween coming up and we're just anxious to see how that will come out and excited by it. And so that's about as much as I can tell you right now.

---

Can you please remind us just your CapEx budget for the year?

---

We did not disclose a CapEx number. But what we did say is that the total envelope would be less than last year; even though we are growing, the total envelope is expected to be lower. A big part of last year's CapEx was the deployment, the rollout of our NCR cash registered -- registers, so that was a good part of the CapEx, which we don't have this year.

---

Okay, great. And as you gradually grow into your 1,200 store count, do you have enough capacity to do that or when would you have to envision building a new DC, if at all?

---

Yes, absolutely. First of all, just to be clear, Montreal, it's not a capacity issue. The reason we are thinking about a DC or warehouse out west is for economic reasons. And as we get more and more efficient down here, it just pushes back the business case. So we've been telling you for the past 4 years that it's going to be in 3 years and that's still the case now. So nothing new and in fact it's much better that we get more efficient here and push that business case.

---

We hope we never have to, let's put it that way.

---

Okay, great and maybe just 2 more quick questions, if I can. Can you just remind us your view in the U.S. This is still not an attractive market for Dollarama, is that correct?

---

Pardon me?

---

The U.S. market, I'm just thinking in terms of Dollar General and Family Dollar, if those stores...

---

Oh, no, no, no. We're focused in Canada. And we, as you all know, have some -- we're spending a bit of energy in Central America and that's our main focus.

---

Okay, and then lastly, just on credit card, anything up -- new to update us on your thoughts?

---

No. The debit card penetration continues to increase, obviously that's -- and it doesn't cost us anything that we'll speak to that, and we'll see in the future for the credit card. All right, thank you very much, everyone.
