【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
Traffic, same-store traffic back in positive territory, what were the dynamics behind that and does -- lapping a bunch of target openings in Q3 last year, will that have any impact on your traffic for the remainder of this year?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
I'm sorry, Perry, this is Michael. Could you -- I had problems hearing you.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
Okay, so, just a question about the same-store traffic. It's back in positive territory. Just what were this dynamics behind that? And what do you expect for same-store traffic for the next couple of quarters, since you're lapping some target openings from last year?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Right, well, the -- as you noticed, we were able to explain, clearly, the traffic in Q4 and Q1, which was related to the weather conditions and so that in Q2, the weather impact that we have back in Q4 and Q1 don't exist, didn't exist in Q2. So certainly, that was a factor. But again, it's making sure that we've got as usual, we've got some good pickup at store level in terms of sales. And that's the best we can do to explain that. It's hard to pinpoint exactly.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
And do you have any expectations for Q3 or Q4?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well we're hoping certainly that, that will continue. So we're doing everything we can to stimulate that. I think it's hard to say right now. We've just started Q3. So we've got some big seasons kicking in soon, Halloween and Christmas. And again, if Mother Nature for Q4 is a bit more on our side, well, I think we should expect positive transactions.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
And what's the current state of real estate opportunities for Dollarama in Canada? And have you had to adjust your criteria over the past year to maintain your store opening pace?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, it's Larry, Perry. I think the opportunities are similar to what they have been, we had to adjust. Not really, we just recognized that some of the locations that you we're taking are going to cannibalize some others. Those are just a fact of life. And -- but as far as the real estate themselves, it's available. It's available. From an expense point of view, it's similar to about a year ago. We have a lot of renewals now. And every year, we're going to have almost 50, 60, 70 renewals. And they're being renewed at, let's say, less expensive than new stores but more than -- slightly more than what they were 10 years ago, which we would expect.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
And do you feel, Larry, that you'll have to make any alterations to your format or your operations as those opportunities change or as rents increase?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Not yet, Perry. I can't predict the future. I'm no good at that. But I can -- let's put it this way. For this year and next year, the balance of this year and next year, that is not the case. If you want me to predict further into time, I can't do that.

---

【質問: Perry Caicco (Analysts)】
All right. And then just one last question, if I could. The improvement in your scale over the past couple of years, has that had a material impact on your purchasing power and your cost of goods?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I would say not. I think that generally speaking, especially from the Orient, the size of our orders were such that whether you buy 1,000 -- 5,000 dozen or now you're buying 10,000 dozen of an item, it's not going to improve very much at all. What it may do is domestically, make us more attractive from that point of view. They may be more willing to look at dollar stores in a more favorable light going forward. And I think that's happening in the states, too. You see the big boys, the major companies like P&G and those -- the ilk of those, Rubbermaid, opening up a little bit more and trying to be more creative with Dollar stores than they have in the past but from that point -- having said that, that's just about all I can comment on that.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
Just if we can look for a moment at your mix in the quarter with 67% of sales from items above $1. That was a very strong increase, both from prior quarter and from prior year. So just wondering whether it's a seasonal issue, whether we saw significantly higher penetration, kind of what was going on there?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay, hello, Irene. It's Michael. We -- if you look back, the 4 -- 4 years back, you'll see there's a similar bump in Q2 in all of those years and it's 4 or 5 points, if you want. So it went from 62 to 67 so that's an increase of 5. You've seen a similar increase over the past 4 years in Q2. So it's a seasonal thing. Typically in Q1, you have Easter and Valentine, and they sell more lower price point items than when you get into the next quarter.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
That's great. So in terms of, let's say, the item count, items priced above $1, that hasn't really changed much?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No, well, the percentage -- no, it hasn't changed much and the percentage is in sales dollars but for the rest, everything remains equal, if you want.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
That's great. And I guess we've now had a couple of years of benefit of those -- of the items priced at the $2.50 and $3 price point. As we get into the very important Q4 season, how are you guys thinking, feeling about the offer that you have this year based on the data that you've been able to have from prior years?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Well, as buyer of both Halloween and Christmas, there's a marginal increase towards $2.50 and $3, not serious at all, because I personally try to keep that $1 price point, or in and around the $1 price point whether it's $1, $1.25 as much as possible. So I don't think there's going to be a substantial difference in the seasonal offering of Halloween and Christmas in the price point area. We try to maintain it as much as possible, proportionately per price point as in the past, Irene.

---

【質問: Irene Nattel (Analysts)】
That's great. And one more question, if I could. And this goes to productivity initiatives. On the last call, you mentioned that over the next few months, you're going to be -- you're really going to be changing some of the in-store procedures, particularly around cash management, as a result of the rollout of the new POS terminals. I'm just wondering where we stand on that, and whether you've been pleased with returns that you've been getting?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay, yes. So from a G&A standpoint, here's the latest. We did -- to tell you the truth, we did a bit better than we had anticipated. There's the annualization of the beginning of last year's initiatives. And in that sense, I'd say the initiatives that we have are the ones that are last year initiated, continue this year and there's no real new big initiative that's generating the savings that we expect this year. The new initiatives and you're referred to 1 of them, cash management, it's something that will trickle in over time. It's something that is just at its beginning stage. However -- and that's why we gave you a bit more guidance, a bit more color on the G&A side for the fiscal year '15, ranging between 17.1% and 17.5% -- there are expenses that will be incurred in Q3 and Q4 that were not there last year and they simply relate to different initiatives that we'll be working on. So you should be careful in trending what you're seeing in Q1 and Q2 for Q3 and Q4. So that's why we came out to guide you through to the 17.1% to the 17.5%.

---

【質問: Kenric Tyghe (Analysts)】
In terms of your merchandise mix, could you sort of refresh us on where you are on seasonal versus consumables and general merchandise? If I recall, sort of back in time, your seasonal was sort of in the mid-teens. Is that still a good proxy to use and could you perhaps speak to the evolution of that mix, even if you're not inclined to be giving specific sort of breakdowns?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay, so it's Michael. No major change from what was disclosed in the AIF. So 50%-ish general '13, '14 -- that range of seasonal and the balance consumables.

---

【質問: Kenric Tyghe (Analysts)】
Michael, I just want to check on any changes sort of in-year. Could I then just, Michael, switch to inventory productivity, obviously very good numbers on tough comps. You do have some FX-led gross margin pressures on your inventory yield. Could you sort of speak to what kind of runway you have left with respect to the initiatives, or how you view the sort of evolution of your productivity initiatives given some of those challenges with respect to your gross margins?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, as we stated in the past, we -- now the major initiatives you're all familiar with. And so those are the ones that will, as we turn on the functionalities of those more and more will continue generating benefits in the future. Now I can't speculate on, given that I don't know what the headwinds can be in the future, as to where that will take us. I've given you guidance for this year. Obviously, we are working to reduce that as much as possible. But there's so much that we can predict. And we do expect to have more and more initiatives in the future kicking in. So that we're definitely working on. And so for the currency, that definitely has been a strong headwind. We decided to absorb part of that and not transfer it to the customer so -- and that was expected and communicated to you, and so we will continue to manage that balance between compellingness and return to shareholder.

---

【質問: Peter Sklar (Analysts)】
I just wondered if you could discuss a little bit the -- the change in Canada's trade status with China and the increase in tariffs that will be effective, I believe, January 2015. Do you have any estimate of what the magnitude this will impose on your costs, on your COGS? And can you talk a little bit about the philosophy of the company, how you're  going to approach this as a -- are you going to absorb this in your margin or will there be some erosion in the consumer proposition? Can you just talk a little bit about those things.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, I think that we have to put in the same basket as foreign exchange. It's an extra cost to doing business, and -- as the dollar is, and we're going to handle it the same way. If the duties have increased by 3% or 4%, we're factoring it into our costs and making a decision as we would the FX. So we just can't absorb everything. It's being treated in that -- in a similar fashion. And not every category has been affected but those that are being affected, all our buyers are aware of them. And, again, it's being lumped into -- similar to FX.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
And maybe let me just add a bit of color to that, Peter, by stating that nothing -- that in reality, there's nothing special to signal -- relating to the general pattern [ph] of differential tariffs. Otherwise, it would have been -- if it would have been material, we would have disclosed more information in the MD&A. It's less significant than the currency impact. And again, as Larry said, we're treating it the same way we've been treating forever inflation, wage increases, currency fluctuations and so on. So I hope that helps.

---

【質問: Peter Sklar (Analysts)】
Right, and just one other question, if I may. You've talked about in the past, what you think the ultimate store count could be for Dollarama when the -- when your footprint achieves maturation in Canada. I'm just wondering if there's been any change in your view, and how much you could densify the store penetration in urban areas?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay, so maybe I can begin, Larry, if you want. So  our figure out there right now, and I'll explain how we got to that figure is 1,200. So and 1,200 is our estimate with the current format we know and hopefully, the same financials or economics surrounding that. So that's our view, and we worked that with consultants. So we mapped out the whole country and that's how we arrived at that figure. We have visibility on our current store pipeline. And we -- so we've addressed that more specifically for this year's target. So we -- that's still the number that we're working by.

---

【質問: Derek Dley (Analysts)】
Can you just update us on the percentage of your products now that are priced at those higher price point levels? For example, the percentage of products priced above $2?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, we don't disclose that. I'm sorry, Derek.

---

【質問: Derek Dley (Analysts)】
Okay, but maybe if I ask it another way, are you guys comfortable with your current range of price points? Is there room to sort of manage some of the increase in costs?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, I mean, to be fully clear, it's business as usual. It's -- we haven't changed our approach. You have seen consistently the penetration rate going -- in terms of sales dollars going up, especially in Q2 and then it kind of stabilizes for the -- for a few quarters and then kicks back up. So as of now, there's nothing different that we've done internally.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, and I would back Michael up on that. I think we're happy at the price ranges that we're in, the mix we're in, and we'll stay with that mix of prices as long as we can. To predict the future, again I can't do that. And am I happy, to answer your question directly, with our price/mix today, I think the answer would be yes.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Just back to the tariffs question. So it's one more factor that when you're purchasing, your buyers have to deal with -- so when we're thinking about gross margins going forward, all else being the same, I mean, would you concede that it is definitely a pressure?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes. I think the pressure of the dollar at $1.08 and $1.10 is a pressure, that I would think that a one-time tariff increase is more pressure once, then we know where we're going after that. Bad weather is pressure. Yes. I can't deny that.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
And as you know also, Dave, we've had time to see that coming and so there's definitely -- there's been sufficient time to deal with that question beforehand. But as Larry said, also, it's going to be a one-time pickup and then we continue.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
Is there any more color you can give us in terms of the percentage of your sales or unit sales or something that will be affected by this?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
It's nonmaterial. Otherwise, as I said we would have -- if it would be something special surrounding that, we would have disclosed it in the MD&A.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
I guess that's the bottom line, it's not material. Just wanting to kind of look further afield. I know  you're comfortable with the range of price points you have now. What about other categories that you may not be in today that might be a bit of a step-out from what you currently offer. Have you given more thought to that or are there initiatives potentially in place that you might want to pilot or categories you might want to pilot in your stores? Could you talk a little bit about the future as -- in terms of your offer?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
For me, the future is the present. In terms of -- I'm very happy with our offering today. You've seen so many American dollar stores go to consumables, more consumables that's -- basically, we can't get into pharmaceuticals here, and can't become a Canadian Tire. So I guess, you can go to consumables, we're not interested in doing that. We are -- I think the grocery industry here is very mature and very competitive. I think the offering that we have today and the categories we have are exactly what the customers expect. And we don't want to transition our store into a grocery store, absolutely not. Because we don't -- we like the margins we're making, and we're not favorable to the margins of the grocery industry -- if we keep going that way, which is not our intention. So I think that by just tweaking whether the craft department is strong from 1 year to the other, whether the demand is as strong for craft as it is from 1 year to the other, then we can increase another department by either 5% or 10%, decrease craft by 5% or 10%, but work within the departments we have. I think that answers your question.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
It does. And just last one, if I may. Just on the competitive front. Could you talk a little bit about the competitive environment and maybe how it's changed and also maybe again looking into the future, when if or if do you see a need to perhaps become promotional at advertising or some kind of marketing to drive increased traffic?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Maybe if I could start, Larry jump in. So we anticipate that competition as has done in the past year will continue increasing, so that's why we're constantly reviewing our processes and trying to get more and more efficient and investing into the product. And so -- and right now, so it's business as usual on that side. We don't see any structural competitive change, major change, but definitely, as we've stated in the past, we compete against it, all the other retailers out there, we don't sell anything unique. Everything we sell, someone else sells, too. So it's a matter of making sure we've got the most compelling value out there.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, I think Michael has it there.

---

【質問: David Hartley (Analysts)】
And on the advertising marketing front, I mean, it seems inconceivable today, but is that something that you think about, look at, contemplate to help bolster sales at some point in the future?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Well, no, that's not something right now. I mean, obviously, the future depends where you are in the future. But for the time being, we're sticking to what we're doing right now.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
And I would agree with that. I don't see it in the future. I -- again, don't want to predict the future but I don't see it in the near future and at all, David, not at all.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
I just want to go back to the store network opportunity. You mentioned 1,200 stores but on sort of existing template. I know you had been trying smaller stores. Where are you at with the smaller stores? Have you grown into being happy with the performance of those? Or where else would you think you might at some point in time start to think about testing different formats as we get closer to the 1,200 number?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I think the smaller store idea comes from the fact that we're trying to get into more Metropolitan areas in Toronto, Montréal and Vancouver, period -- maybe Winnipeg. And because those areas are not covered by dollar stores, they present opportunities and you can't find 10,000, 12,000-foot stores there. You're going to find maybe a 5,000, 6,000, 7,000-foot box. You usually will find that with a basement. So we're taking advantage of those opportunities. We rent the ground level at a price and we -- they throw in the basement obviously -- most of the time. I don't want to give anybody any ideas, but -- so it's not because we're trying to change and try a new format called smaller stores, it's because the opportunities don't exist in those particular areas. The smaller store format may be out there. It's not something we have to think about today, or in the near future again, but I don't see it quite as being as "rentable" -- how do you say that in English?

---

【回答: Unknown Executive (Executives)】
Profitable.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Profitable as the format we have today, and anything [ph] . So my answer is right now, I'm happy where we are. And I don't know what's going to happen in 5 years.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
Nor do we.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I know that.

---

【質問: James Durran (Analysts)】
I just wanted to double back on something you said, make sure I heard you correctly with respect to consumables. Do you continue to see consumables as just a category that you'll modestly grow as opposed to taking a different view of consumables and going at it more aggressively?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I don't even want to say that we would modestly grow it. We're going to try and keep the proportions in our store as they are today. Again, if craft sells less, we will move somewhere else and would it be to consumables? Maybe, but there's no design to that. It's whatever seems to be in demand by the consumer. So there's no intention to increase the consumable grocery, consumable, non-consumable area in our stores. We like the mix of our offering at the moment. We see that being the same in the future. And again, I don't know what's going to happen in 5 years.

---

【質問: Vishal Shreedhar (Analysts)】
Just wondering if you're seeing any benefit related to your value improvement initiatives that you have going on, and if it's possible to measure it or in sales or perhaps customer SAT?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
That's a tough one. You're saying, because we're saying that we're not -- we're going to watch or be conscious of our markup, are we seeing more customers? It's too early to predict that. We're saying we're sensitive to that area, where we just don't want to arbitrarily markup everything by the increase in FX and preferential tariffs just because they're there. Eventually, we'll have to catch up, but we are very sensitive to that area of our business. And if we can control it, as well as we have been, that would be most satisfactory. But to say if it's had an impact, it's almost too early for that. And I'm not sure in a year if I can answer that question but at the moment, I couldn't answer that question, Vishal.

---

【質問: Vishal Shreedhar (Analysts)】
Okay, got it. In terms of the 36% to 37% gross margin rate that you've given to us, just given some challenges that you highlighted: FX; tariffs, I know you're dealing with that; competitive pressures and perhaps some challenges that you might not foresee at this period of time, is that a hard stop kind of rate that you would try to work towards or are there periods where you could go below that for a period of time, knowing that eventually you could work yourself out of that. Just wondering your thought on that.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
I think ideally, we'd like to stay within that range. That's what we're aiming for and you're right, we do have all those challenges and by the way, the tariff and the currency we're on the same level of playing field as the other. So it's a matter of balancing that compelling value if you want, but the idea is to stay within that range.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
I was just wondering if you could speak a bit about the apparel section of the stores. Is that a section that could be expanded, or do you think it's about where it should be?

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
If anything, it would go the other way. That's a difficult -- we'll call, we'll use your terminology, and say section. It's difficult because there's sizes, there's colors, there's fashion and we threw in modest offerings in the last year or 2. And we've -- again, this is an area that we don't want to expand. Our fixturing is not conducive to it. And if anything, it would go the -- it would contract, it would not expand.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And then something like the over-the-counter drugs, I'm not exactly sure what you can offer and what you can't offer. But I think I've seen things like Aspirin, I believe, in your store. If not your store, your competitor's store. But how -- what are the limitations on that category?

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
Every -- it's Neil, Keith. Every province has its own legislation, and so it's a province-by-province discussion as to which over-the-counter drugs are allowed to be sold, but as a category, it's a very small category for us. ---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And then just in terms of the health and beauty assortment, you mentioned the -- some of the big brands are paying more attention to the dollar store channel. Would you see maybe going to more national brands in your health and beauty sort of section?

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
I think we'll take the same approach we have always taken with national brands, which is because they come at a lower markup at all times, we will continue to sprinkle national brands into our imports. But at a very slow pace and just enough to offer a balanced mix.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
Yes, no intention of going there.

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
And then I guess a bit out of left field, would you look at the Internet as an Internet offering?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Keith, it's Michael. This will be the last question because we still have other analysts to go, sorry. So if you could repeat that question, Keith?

---

【質問: Keith Howlett (Analysts)】
I was just wondering whether there's any consideration of going to the Internet?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
I agree with Michael.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
I just had a very high-level question at this time. You've had a couple of quarters recently where you've gotten off to a slow start recently and it's typically due to inclement weather. So I really just have two minor questions, maybe one for Neil and then one for Michael. One, was there a notable expansion in your back-to-school offering this year? And then second, Michael, I don't expect you go into much detail, but the late August, early September time frame seemed very busy in the store and I just wonder if it's fair to say the start to this quarter might be a bit more encouraging?

---

【回答: Neil Rossy (Executives)】
So I'll answer the first question. The first question can be answered rather easily. The assortment has never changed. What we have done is we've made a bigger effort at store level and in store operations to put a better showing of our current and everyday offering on the front end and do a better job of merchandising it. And so it would be to the customer a new look and a new push, although the offering didn't change whatsoever.

---

【質問: Brian Morrison (Analysts)】
Seems to work well.

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Okay, and for the second part, Brian. I can't, obviously, disclose too much, but what I did say earlier is that to-date Q3, nothing unusual. Weather is certainly not a factor as it was in Q4 and Q1. For Q3 at least as of today, and we're just in the beginning of the quarter. We've got Halloween coming up and we're just anxious to see how that will come out and excited by it. And so that's about as much as I can tell you right now.

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Can you please remind us just your CapEx budget for the year?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
We did not disclose a CapEx number. But what we did say is that the total envelope would be less than last year; even though we are growing, the total envelope is expected to be lower. A big part of last year's CapEx was the deployment, the rollout of our NCR cash registered -- registers, so that was a good part of the CapEx, which we don't have this year.

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Okay, great. And as you gradually grow into your 1,200 store count, do you have enough capacity to do that or when would you have to envision building a new DC, if at all?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Yes, absolutely. First of all, just to be clear, Montreal, it's not a capacity issue. The reason we are thinking about a DC or warehouse out west is for economic reasons. And as we get more and more efficient down here, it just pushes back the business case. So we've been telling you for the past 4 years that it's going to be in 3 years and that's still the case now. So nothing new and in fact it's much better that we get more efficient here and push that business case.

---

【回答: Laurence Rossy (Executives)】
We hope we never have to, let's put it that way.

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Okay, great and maybe just 2 more quick questions, if I can. Can you just remind us your view in the U.S. This is still not an attractive market for Dollarama, is that correct?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Pardon me?

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
The U.S. market, I'm just thinking in terms of Dollar General and Family Dollar, if those stores...

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
Oh, no, no, no. We're focused in Canada. And we, as you all know, have some -- we're spending a bit of energy in Central America and that's our main focus.

---

【質問: Chris Li (Analysts)】
Okay, and then lastly, just on credit card, anything up -- new to update us on your thoughts?

---

【回答: Michael Ross (Executives)】
No. The debit card penetration continues to increase, obviously that's -- and it doesn't cost us anything that we'll speak to that, and we'll see in the future for the credit card. All right, thank you very much, everyone.

BP9DL90.eventHeadline: Industria de Diseno Textil SA, H1 2015 Earnings Call, Sep 17, 2014
BP9DL90.transcript_text1:
Good morning to all the participants in this webcast conference call regarding Inditex's results for the interim half year 2014. I am Pablo Isla; and here with me today are Ignacio Fernández, our CFO; and Marcos López, Capital Markets Director.
The results for the half year 2014 showed that Inditex continues its global multi-concept, multi-channel growth. Inditex operating performance in the period has been strong. Store and online sales in local currencies grew 11%. Our operations have also shown high-efficiency and tight operating control over the period. Let me also tell you that in terms of expansion, our space growth and online launches for the year are on track. We have opened stores in 40 different markets over the period, demonstrating the global reach of Inditex business model. We have continued our global online rollout and added Mexico to our platform. The next step will be the launch of online sales in South Korea later this month. We will also open Zara in Tmall in China in October. We continue to see significant growth opportunities for Inditex globally.
In terms of growth, we have maintained a strong expansion. We have achieved positive like-for-like sales growth in all geographical areas in the first half of 2014. We have a global presence, and we have further diversified our operations over the period. 
Let me now hand over to Ignacio, who will provide you with some detail behind the headline numbers, and I will join you later for the outlook section.

---

Thank you.
In the half year 2014, Inditex achieved net sales of EUR 8.1 billion, EBITDA of EUR 1.6 billion and net income of EUR 928 million. Inditex has had a strong operating performance. As you can see from our financial release, currency translation, due to the strong euro versus several currencies, has been a feature of the period. 
Starting with sales, I would like to tell you that Inditex performance in the period has been satisfactory. Store and online sales in local currencies have grown 11%. Like-for-like sales growth has been strong. Store and online launches for the year are on track.
Breaking down sales, let me highlight that like-for-like sales growth was very strong at 4.5% in the first half 2014 on top of 2% in the same period last year. New selling space contributed 6.5% to total sales. The translation of sales in currencies different to the euro has reduced reported sales growth by 4 percentage points due to the lower exchange rate versus our reporting currency. In line with our comments at the time of our fiscal 2015 results, we expect the impact of currency translation to diminish markedly over 2014. So currencies remain at current levels. Additionally, the change in the consolidation method of Tempe has deducted around 1% from reported sales.
Gross profit has increased 4% to EUR 4.7 billion, resulting in 57.6% gross margin on sales. We have sustained our commercial policies over the period.
Operating expenses are tightly under control. They have grown 6%, facilitating mainly the growth in space and include the start-up costs for new openings.
Operating and working capital remains negative as a result of the business model. The working capital evolution is in line with the performance of the business.
I will now hand over to Marcos, who will elaborate on the performance of Inditex concepts.

---

In terms of space addition and online launches, we are on track. Continuing with our global expansion, we have opened stores in 40 markets over the period. Regarding the performance by concept in the first half 2014, Zara and the younger concepts grouped together have performed broadly in line with each other, with some minor differences.
As we mentioned to you earlier, currency translation has been an issue in this period. In the case of Zara, let me tell you that comparable sales growth is in line with the group average in the period. I would like to highlight that both Oysho and Zara Home have performed very well. And finally, Uterqüe achieved very strong like-for-like sales growth in the period.
I will now hand over to Pablo for the outlook section.

---

For the remainder of 2014, we will continue to invest in the expansion of our business across a number of markets, all of which offer attractive long-term returns to our store and online platform. Inditex is present on 5 continents and in all the key markets, demonstrating the group's global reach. We manage a diversified sales platform in 88 markets. The current base offers huge growth potential for the coming years.
Inditex enjoys a fully integrated, globally scalable online operation, which fits perfectly with its business model. This has allowed a rapid growth of our online presence in conjunction with our retail expansion. We have established online sales in Europe, the United States, China, the Russian Federation, Japan and Canada, the world's main economies. We launched Zara online sales in Mexico on the 3rd of September.
We will continue rolling out online sales in selected markets to enhance our global presence. To this end, Zara will launch online sales in South Korea on the 24th of September. We also plan to open Zara in Tmall in China in October.
With respect to expansion in 2014, let me highlight that the space growth and online launches are on track. Ordinary capital expenditure for 2014 will be around EUR 1.35 billion. For the coming years, we'll continue to see strong growth opportunities, with capital expenditure growing below space growth. Regarding the outlook for the second half of 2014, I would like to add that the store sales in local currencies from the 1st of August to the 12th of September have grown by 10%. Just as a reminder, we will make our final 2013 dividend payment of EUR 0.242 per share on the 3rd of November.
And this is all from us. Now we will be pleased to answer any questions you may have.

BP9DL90.transcript_text3:
My question is regarding the domestic market. Apparently, with the figures you published, I believe that you posted very strong growth, probably in the region of 6% like-for-like, we estimate, which has surprised us. Would you please elaborate a little more on this? Which are the main drivers of this very unexpected growth in the domestic market?

---

Thank you. Well, first of all, I would like to say, as we were saying during the presentation, that during this first half, our global like-for like sales growth has been 4.5%, and we have achieved a positive like-for-like sales growth in all the geographies. Regarding Spain, we were saying in the full year results presentation that in the second half of last year, Spain had returned to growth, and this growth have accelerated during the first half of the year. As you were saying, sales growth in Spain in the first half is around 6%. Well, what we can say is that we continue to be very active in the market. We have had very relevant openings, of course, in Madrid, this relevant Zara flagship in San Sebastián. Now very recently, we have opened a very, very relevant Massimo Dutti flagship also in Madrid in Serrano Street in the former Zara building. So we'll continue very active in the Spanish market.

---

I wonder if you could make a comment on your inventory growth. That seems to be around 21% over 1 year and nearly 40% over 2 years, if I've done my math correctly. Maybe I haven't, but it would be great if you could comment on that, please. And then secondly, could you flag the exposure of the group to markets such as Russia, Ukraine and Poland, please?

---

Well, what I would tell you is that you are -- regarding the inventory; we have talked several times about this in previous results presentation. The inventory position is just a snapshot for us. What is relevant is the level of commitment at any point in time. What I can tell you regarding the autumn/winter season is that -- you have seen, well, the trading update. Store sales in local currencies are growing 10%. We feel comfortable about the evolution of our business and no concern from that point of view. And you were mentioning different countries. What -- also, the answer is that you are mentioning countries in which we are present since many years ago. We always have a medium- and long-term approach. Our business is developing in normal conditions in all the different geographies.

---

And just on that inventory point then. So you maintain your plus or minus 50 basis points guidance. We hear your stable gross margin guidance. How do you think about the second half given, obviously, the developing dynamic for autumn/winter?

---

Yes. Well, I would answer you that our guidance for the second half in terms of gross margin would be a stable gross margin for the second half. You know that the gross margin is a combination of many different things. It has to do, of course, with markups, with markdowns, with fashion trends, with product mix. It has to do with currencies. In the first half, we have had a relevant currency impact on the gross margin. We have -- you have a currency impact on sales on the gross margin. And then thinking about the second half, what we could tell you at this stage of the season is a stable gross margin for the second half of the year. Let me remind that even in the first half, gross profit has grown 4%, which is a relevant figure, having in mind everything which has been going on with currencies.

---

Just a quick question on your online sales. Can you give us a sense of the trends there in terms of the growth of online and maybe a bit of color on certain of the key markets and start-ups, U.S. online sales growth, please?

---

Well, thank you. You know that we do not like to elaborate very much regarding online-specific sales evolution in the different markets. What we can tell you is that we continue very satisfied with the evolution of our online business. In fact, what -- the best way to say it is that we continue very satisfied with the evolution of our multi-channel business because for us, this multi-channel approach, as we have talked in previous conference calls, is something very, very relevant. Our online and store operations are fully integrated from every point of view. You may have in-store deliveries, in-store returns. You could even order online from many of our stores. So it's something which is fully integrated. We have a lot of people buying online, but we have also a lot of customers seeing the product online, buying in the stores. So this approach is very relevant. We continue with the rollout. Very recently, we have also begun our online operations in Mexico. We will begin next week in South Korea. And then in October, we will begin -- well, of course, we are already present in China with our online business, but we will also offer online sales through Tmall, which is something that we think is going to be quite relevant. What I can tell you is that we continue growing regarding our online sales in a significantly way in all the different geographies, of course. In terms of the most relevant markets, it has to do with the -- what are the most relevant markets, in general, for online. So -- and you were mentioning the U.S. Of course, the U.S. is a very relevant market because online penetration is very strong in the market. So it's also a very relevant market for us. So this approach with space growth plus online growth is what we are planning to do in the coming years.

---

Two follow-up questions, please. In the world of online, are you finding that promotional levels have intensified over such the recent times?

---

Promotional levels, you mean?

---

Online.

---

Yes, and the -- in -- on the online.

---

No, not -- no, not for us. You know how do we manage our online business. We are offering our full range of product -- no, no, nothing in a particular way.

---

And you don't feel that competition is sort of putting -- sort of forcing such as increased competitive promotional pressure?

---

No, no. Normal environment, I would say, no.

---

Could you elaborate a little bit on the net cash evolution for the -- what are your expectations -- or expect net cash to increase considering the decline that you have in the first half?

---

Well, José, in general, as you know, the cash position has to do with the evolution of the business, with a calendar of CapEx in a very special way and the dividend payments. And the dividend payments have increased 10%. So those are the key drivers.

---

I am fully aware that there's plenty of drivers for gross margin, but I was just wondering if we were to look about second quarter performance, whether there is some weight from currency, whether there's anything specific within there that we should be thinking about that can give us a bit of comfort that second half gross margin will be more stable as you've talked to earlier?

---

Well, the first point, Simon, I think is gross profit again has increased 4% to EUR 4.7 billion on top of EUR 4.5 billion. So the evolution is positive, right. In the first half, as we have mentioned, obviously, currency has been an issue, okay, because there is a significant translation effect. All in all, what we can tell you is that taking into account that the business model of the company provides a very strong stability, what we expect for the second half is a stable gross margin, and this is very much the spending we would like to make forward.

---

And were there any kind of particular currencies within there in the second quarter that are worth highlighting?

---

I think that the main driver is the strength of the euro, not to any specific currency to talk about because we're present in 88 markets. As you can imagine, we cannot get in a detailed analysis of a small factor over a period.

---

My question is about the cost efficiency that you've been demonstrating really for the last 18 months. It's been extremely impressive, and you've been able to grow costs slower than space growth. And I was wondering if you could just talk about how much of that is due to operational efficiencies relative to currency translation

---

Well, what I would like -- first of all, as we were saying during the presentation, we'll continue managing tightly our costs. What -- the main driver behind cost growth is always space growth, as you perfectly know. Then there is a second driver, which has to do with the evolution of sales because of variable -- we have part of our costs, a relevant part of them, which are variable. And then, of course, we also have currencies. And currency impact on costs is more or less half of currency impact on sales. So what we can tell you is that we'll continue trying to find efficiencies in the way we operate our company. This is a permanent effort. And if you analyze what -- coming from our results, what could be our like-for-like cost growth, you can see how tightly managed are our costs.

---

I've got 2 questions. First of all, does your stable gross margin guidance in the second half mean absolutely flat? Or do you mean plus or minus 50 basis points as you often do with stable? And then the second question is about currency. I think your full year guidance is a 3% currency translation hit to sales, but with euro having weakened recently, might it be nearer to 2%?

---

Well, regarding your first question, we always warn because the gross margin is not mathematics. It has to do with many different things. So we always -- when we say a stable gross margin, we are always thinking about plus, minus 50 basis points. It's impossible to know at the beginning of any season what the exact, final figure is going to be the gross margin. So what we can tell you is a stable gross margin for the second half, but we all know that, for us, stable means plus, minus 50 basis points. Regarding currencies, what we could say at this stage is that we continue expecting, in terms of currency impact for the year, a similar impact as we had in the previous year, which is around 3%. And I think because of -- there is some volatility regarding currencies. So we prefer to maintain this assumption, instead of estimating every week what is going to be the final currency impact on -- during the year. You know that we manage our business for the long term in all the different geographies. So, of course, this is something we monitor, but we are not obsessed with what would be the evolution of currencies in every particular week.

---

Just one question, really. The 4.5% like-for-like, could you split that down between volume and value, please?

---

It's mainly volume-driven. Globally, we have maintained our prices stable in the different markets. Globally -- there could be some elements here and there, but globally, we have maintained our prices stable in the different markets. So as usually, with our like-for-like sales growth, it's mainly volume-driven.

---

One question from me on the Americas. So I've noticed that the percentage of sales coming from the Americas has declined in the first half, and I wanted to find out if this is mainly FX-driven. Is it less store expansion in that region? Or have you seen of any Europe growing faster than the Americas? Any more color you can give there, please.

---

Yes, it's mainly currency-driven. What we were saying during the presentation is that we have had positive like-for-like sales growth in all the geographies. So it's mainly currency-driven.

---

And in terms of your store growth, the way that we should think about it, if we think your 8% to 10% space growth -- sorry, do you think your 8% to 10% guidance will -- is it focused market? Other than China, is U.S. one of them?

---

In the U.S., our approach in terms of growth is a combination between store openings and online sales growth. We have had relevant openings during the period, particularly. Well, we could mention different openings, but I could mention the opening in Miami in Lincoln Road. So we have had relevant openings during the period. And this is our idea. We will continue opening relevant stores in the different U.S. cities, and then combining these with our online business. If you will remember, we were talking in previous presentations that regarding online in the U.S.; we used to have one stockroom in the East Coast. Now we are operating a second one in the West Coast in order to serve -- enable the way our customers in the West Coast. So we'll continue operating our business through this combination between store openings or enlargement of existing stores because this is something which is also relevant in the U.S. market, and then online growth. So this is the approach we have for the online market for the U.S. market. So you should expect store openings, and then you should expect online growth. And then in Mexico, of course, we'll continue opening stores every year. In Brazil, we'll continue opening stores every year. So a combination -- in general terms, we're doing a store growth and then online growth. When you analyze the evolution in this first half, as I was mentioning to you before, it is mainly driven because of the currency impact.

---

This is Vick Mohan in for Omar. Could you talk a little bit about competition, especially in your home European markets, and whether you're seeing a rise in your Indian competition?

---

I would say that all the markets are very competitive, and this is always the case. And this is an environment in which we -- I don't know what word to use, but we like to operate in a very competitive market. I think competition is good for everybody. It's good also for us because you need to innovate permanently, so nothing special to mention, but as always, all the markets are very competitive.

---

If -- at constant currency, if inventory growth was 21% in the first half year-on-year, but what it's been on a constant-currency basis, please?

---

Could you repeat your question, Rebecca?

---

Inventory growth in the first half was 21%. What was it on a constant-currency basis?

---

Not very different, not very different, but again, I would not put too much emphasis on inventory. That commitment is very much the figure we follow. This is a snapshot at the beginning of the season. So I wouldn't read anything specific at all in the sense that to look at the figure for the first 6 weeks when we're talking of 6 months is not very relevant. So we don't have any significant concern then. Commitment remains very tightly managed.

---

Could you just talk about your online delivery proposition? You obviously launched in the U.S. with free delivery. You're charging in Europe. What will you do around the rest of the world as you roll out?

---

It's something we need to analyze on -- in every market. There are several countries in which we have free deliveries. There also several countries in which we have free deliveries who have bought a certain amount. There are countries in which we have a small charge for the standard delivery. In all the countries, we offer express delivery. We offer free delivery in every market when you have in-store delivery. In every market, we have free returns. So we analyze each market. We decide what to do depending also on what is the environment in each of the different markets. So it's something very flexible, and it's something that can change in any particular market at any point in time, so something very flexible depending on the competitive environment in any of the different markets.

---

And what impact does that have on basket size?

---

No, it doesn't have a relevant impact in terms of basket size.
